title: Welcome
text:
Hi everyone,

We're using Ed Discussion for Q&A this semester.

This is the best place to ask questions about the course, whether curricular or administrative. You will get faster answers here from staff and peers than through email.

Here are some tips:

Search before you post

Heart questions and answers you find useful

Answer questions you feel confident answering

Share interesting course related content with staff and peers

For more information on Ed Discussion, you can refer to the Quick Start Guide.

All the best this semester!

Shu-Yi

title: Discussion Forum Guideline
text:
Discussion forum Guideline: 
The discussion forums are a way for you to share your thoughts about course material, learn from your fellow students, get to know them better, and report problems.
If you have an urgent matter -- such as needing to report a video or other course component that isn't working properly -- you can get the attention of course staff by creating a new post and putting [STAFF] in the title.
 
There are a few other ways you can participate:
 
Select the "heart" icon to like  posts and good responses (so the post will move closer to the top of the discussion thread)
 
Select the “star” icon to follow posts for updates
 
Use “watch” to be notified of all activities in the thread
 
You are part of a diverse learning community that forms the heart of a meaningful learning experience. Be it online or in person, a healthy online learning community starts with some basics:
Be respectful. Please respect your fellow students. Debate and pushing on ideas is part of a healthy and thriving learning community, but only when that is done in a polite and respectful manner. Insulting, condescending or abusive words will not be tolerated and will be reported and removed.
Be constructive. A learning community is about learning with and through engagement with one another. When commenting on others' projects, try to offer constructive feedback and suggestions that help them improve it.
 
Be sensitive. This is a global forum with participants from many different cultures and backgrounds. Be sensitive when discussing race, religion, gender, sexual orientation, or controversial topics since others may be more sensitive about them than you are.
 
Post appropriately. Content that violates the Terms of Service is not permitted. You may not post inappropriate (e.g. pornographic) or copyrighted content, advertise or promote outside products or organizations, or spam the forums with repeated content.
 
Users that repeatedly post inappropriate content (see above) may lose their posting privileges, at the discretion of the course staff.
 
Please help us create a healthy learning environment by respecting these standards. We do not expect to see many of these issues because we trust students like you to keep our forum communities strong and healthy.
 
In addition, please consider the following guidelines when posting in the course forums. These guidelines were created to serve the community and make the forums welcoming and easy to use. If you have other suggestions to add, please let us know!

FORUM POSTING GUIDELINES

What makes a good post? The main goal of the forums is to provide a place where dialogue can build as the collective learning community digs into this content together. The forums are there for all learners to have a deeper, more meaningful learning experience, but there are a few things to consider when posting in the course forums:
 
Read before posting. Your comment or question should build on what’s already been discussed. If you have a question, scan through to see if it’s already been addressed and use the search function to avoid creating duplicate threads and find the most appropriate topic thread to post in.
 
Use informative titles. Keep your post titles short and on-topic so the forums are easier to navigate. If you’re asking a question, it should go in the title.
 
Make it easy to read. Present facts and background in your post. Don’t capitalize or bold entire sentences since this makes the forums harder to read. Check your posts for spelling or grammatical errors.
 
Stay on topic. Don’t change the topic of a thread or split a thread into multiple discussions. If you are discussing something that is not directly related to the course materials, pick one thread instead of discussing over multiple threads. And please, don’t post the same post/question in more than one forum.
 
Help keep the site friendly. Any comment which is mean, insulting, too violent, or otherwise inappropriate will be removed by the staff. 
 
Thanks for keeping the conversation lively and respectful!

title: What is "Weekly Reflection" ?
text:
What is Weekly Reflection?

Weekly Reflection module is designed to help you build a habit of planning your study of the upcoming week. 

It includes 3 sections:

Course Progress*: Review your learning records and self-evaluate your learning progress to adjust your learning strategies

Study Planning*: Set learning goals, to-do tasks and reminders 

Study Tip: comics with some wisdoms to share 



It locates in the beginning of each week and you have to complete Weekly Review before proceeding to the course videos. Click here to checkout the Weekly Review Tutorial. 





Let us know if you have any questions!



p.s The Course Progress and Study Planning are only available for the verified track learners.

comments.text:
Hi Dr_Darnell, 

No, you have not missed any deadline yet. 

Here are all the deadlines: 

Verification due 12/11/2020

Assignments & Quizzes due 12/13

Courses ends 12/21/2020

Certificate available 1/3/2021



Please read through the getting started section to learn more about the logistics information Course information

All students (verified and audit) have access to the lectures and self-assessments. However, only verified students have additional access to the graded assessments such as weekly quizzes, projects and the final exam. 

For the audit track learners, if you are considering to upgrade, you can take advantage of the 14-day full refund policy to sample the course. If you do not earn a passing grades, you can come back to join us again in the future run.

Also, please tag your questions with  [General] or [Lecture] properly so your posts would be reviewed & answered in a timely manner. 

Thank you and welcome to the course.

Hello, does "Weekly Reflection" which is to "help you build a habit of planning your study of the upcoming week" affect our final score in the course if we don't do it? Can it please be made to be an optional tool for those who want and need it?

Just my 2 cents of feedback about this: If someone doesn't have proper study habits and voluntarily signs up for a graduate level MOOC and fails to do their assignments in the specified time frame, then they should fail. I hope that study habit fundamentals can be an unsaid prerequisite of people attending the course (just like calculus, linear algebra, python), and if they need the help they can find many free resources online (e.g. for time management). Personally I graduated university while doing 2+ years 100% online and didn't need this help. Making basic time management and study habits a prerequisite and this reflection optional will give people more time to study more about AI or Python. 

Thanks! :-)

title: Multiple submission for project
text: Can we Submit out projects multiple time for grading? Is there any penalty for not getting it right on the first try?
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Can we Submit out projects multiple time for grading? Is there any penalty for not getting it right on the first try?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text: Yes, you can submit as many times as you want up until the deadline. The latest submission will count for your grade. There is no penalty associated with how many times you submit!

title: SciPy and Pandas
text:
Can you please provide links to install SciPy and Pandas.

I found this site but wanted to be sure before installing:

https://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/

comments.text:

and

should work in the terminal without downloading the wheel file from gohlke
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>conda install pandas </paragraph><paragraph>and </paragraph><paragraph>conda install scipy</paragraph><paragraph>should work in the terminal without downloading the wheel file from gohlke</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
Hi there,

Anaconda should come with SciPy, Pandas and a bunch of other Data Science packages preinstalled. With that said, if you don't have Anaconda installed, but have Python3 along with an associated version of pip, then the following command should work on your terminal/command line:

pip install scipy pandas

If you have multiple versions of pip/Python installed, then you may have to run:

pip3 install scipy pandas


Keep in mind that we do not expect you to develop code locally. In fact, we expect you to work on Vocareum(our cloud-based development platform) for the most part. Ultimately, all submissions will have to be made there and Vocareum will have all the packages you may need.



I hope this helps.

pip install scipy pandas
If you have multiple versions of pip/Python installed, then you may have to run:
pip3 install scipy pandas
Keep in mind that we do not expect you to develop code locally. In fact, we expect you to work on Vocareum(our cloud-based development platform) for the most part. Ultimately, all submissions will have to be made there and Vocareum will have all the packages you may need.I hope this helps.

title: We might be doomed?
text: If we go by the assumption that AI is developed without the school of thought of acting morally, then worries aren't unwarranted. It might be trite, but we've all seen how the AI ends up either enslaving the human race or trying to exterminate us. Taking this into account, one might wonder are we already on the path to creating our own exterminators? Throughout history, humans have consistently fought wars in one sense or another, so who's to say AI won't learn from our own history and go to war for it's perceived freedom? Only time will tell...

title: what  is markov desicion theory?
text: what is markov desicion theory?
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>what is markov desicion theory?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Given the present, you don't need the past to know your future states.

$$\left(\left(p\left(s_{n+1}\right|s_n\right)\ =\ p\left(s_{n+1}\right|s_n,\ s_{n-1},s_{n-2},\ ...,\ s_0\right)$$
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Given the present, you don't need the past to know your future states.</paragraph><math>\left(\left(p\left(s_{n+1}\right|s_n\right)\ =\ p\left(s_{n+1}\right|s_n,\ s_{n-1},s_{n-2},\ ...,\ s_0\right)</math><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Simple and well defined.

In addition to it, the Markov Decision Theory finds it's application in Markov's Decision Process(MDP). It's a part of reinforcement learning in which random state are chosen and the corresponding reward is received.

It's a part of reinforcement learning in which random state are chosen and the corresponding reward is received.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: @nawalesanket what do you mean by random states are chosen and corresponding rewards are received?
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph> @nawalesanket what do you mean by <bold>random states</bold> are chosen and corresponding rewards are received?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text: It's a pretty in-depth topic.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>It's a pretty in-depth topic.</paragraph></document>

answers.text: You will learn more about it in the Reinforcement Learning section, but the answers above do a good job of summarizing the basic concept. The theory provides a framework for modeling decision making in an environment. The way we study this in the course, we have states which have rewards associated with them, and we have policies for each state detailing what decision to take to maximize reward. The aim is to find this policy. You will learn this in more mathematical detail later on.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>You will learn more about it in the Reinforcement Learning section, but the answers above do a good job of summarizing the basic concept. The theory provides a framework for modeling decision making in an environment. The way we study this in the course, we have states which have rewards associated with them, and we have policies for each state detailing what decision to take to maximize reward. The aim is to find this policy. You will learn this in more mathematical detail later on.</paragraph></document>

title: Maybe never?
text:
We're still in the early days of autonomous vehicles judging by this video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aCirDhz4jGA

It's still progress and I'm not discrediting the technological achievement, however there is a sentiment behind some of the comments on the video which I found myself intrigued by. Does the general populace even want driverless cars, or would people prefer to trust in their fellow drivers on the road? While I'm a firm believer in technology, I personally would prefer if autonomous vehicles weren't a thing in the first place for a few reasons like:

Machines do in fact fail, just like us. They're not infallible.

I personally don't believe AI could make a moral decision on the road if it came down to it (i.e Trolley problem)

comments.text:
I personally don't believe AI could make a moral decision on the road if it came down to it (i.e Trolley problem)

It is interesting that you should mention the trolley problems in relation to morality as almost all the scenarios can be justified in some way despite the decision a person would make. In the problems, both action and inaction are arguably moral decisions, and with access to large masses of information in the moment, which is something that humans are incapable of achieving, one could say that AI would make a better 'informed decision'. Of course, the sentiment that humans might involve in making decisions can't quite be replicated by AI, and if we were to say that moral decisions that take sentiment into account are of higher quality, then you would be right in saying that AI could not make the best moral decision.

text:

Aslo I doubt he ability of the systems to function as the reflex action enable for example a sudden stop to avoid knocking down a child who suddenly runs into the road. 

Also, in case of an accident who will be held accountable; the owner of the car or the company? From the current state of things and given the rapid evolution in technology, I think that self driving care will be used in developed countries within the a few decades from now.

answers.text:
There are a lot of things to break down in this, but as an autonomous vehicle fiend, I will give it a go!

"how atomous will these cars be?"

This depends on the timeline you are looking at. Currently, there are various forms of automation that are implemented. These include collision avoidance, route planning, lane detection, and some fully autonomous features, such as Tesla's "summon" feature. There are a lot of predictions about when we will have fully autonomous cars, but it's completely dependant on the development race which is going on. But honestly, I think it's closer to being possible than most people think.  



"Will they depend on internet connection to function properly?"

To a certain extent, but they do not require a consistent internet connection. All of today's cars with autonomous features have onboard computer systems that are able to perform operations that are not solely dependant on a continuous stream of information. For example; collision detection is able to work without a persistent internet connection due to it using onboard sensors, cameras, and algorithms that detect surrounding objects, calculate the likelihood of a collision, ad take evasive action. However, something like optimal route calculation, which requires a consistent stream of information from other cars, cellphones, and central monitoring stations, would not work without a semi-persistent internet connection. There are also a lot of benefits to having a persistent connection, as the more information you are able to give to an autonomous vehicle, the more likely it will be to be able to function in a manner that a human could not. We can only see what's in front of us, but if a vehicle can get information about an accident ahead, a course correction can be made and you won't end up in that terrible traffic jam that you always seem to hit at the worst times possible. 

"Aslo I doubt he ability of the systems to function as the reflex action enable for example a sudden stop to avoid knocking down a child who suddenly runs into the road. "

I understand your skepticism, and I think that everyone will have second thoughts if it's one of their loved ones in front of the car. But I will just leave the link below to show you where the technology is already at, nevermind in a few years. 

https://insideevs.com/news/439094/tesla-collision-avoidance-bypasses-massive-accident/


"Also, in case of an accident who will be held accountable; the owner of the car or the company? "

I am not a lawyer, and will not comment on this. But there is a lot of questions around this topic. It will probably be the biggest speedbump in the road to fully autonomous vehicles, and it's something that is an extremely deep and existential question that requires smarter people than me to answer. 

I hope this answers some of your questions. I'm just a fellow student who loves this topic but I am not an expert or even in the field. 

I hope you have a great day and an even better course further!

ChrisH

title: AI does not have to be a threat
text: I believe that with the proper ethical and practical concerns in mind artificial intelligence can progress in a manner which is safe to humanity as a species. With the proper mindset we can harness the power of artificially intelligent software to help solve some of the worlds most important problems. AI can help increase human life spans and time spent healthy, improve technology and processes to combat climate change, make governing less corrupt and more efficient, etc. The more pressing problem, in the near term, is the need to contend with the massive wave of unemployment that will arise as AI becomes more pervasive in the economy. Someday soon we will have to deal with the fact that there will be 0 jobs in trucking, taxi services, train operation, and potentially even airplane operation. Not to mention the countless other industries built on the production of a mass unskilled labor force. AI will push unskilled laborers out of their jobs and will force nations and peoples to contend with the ramifications. There is the potential for AI to devastate humanity in the far future however in the next few decades or even years the more real threat is a wipeout of financially insecure and unskilled people's access to economic activity. This harms not only those directly affected but the world as a whole.

This harms not only those directly affected but the world as a whole.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Hi Patrick,

In the literature, there has been a great deal of discussion and research around AI's disruption of labor due AI's ability to complete tasks that is (or was) done by a human labor force  (Autor et al., 2003; Brynjolfsson & McAfee, 2011; Frey & Osborne, 2013).  It is certainly true that AI will--to some degree--change, dislocate, and / or eliminate task and, therefore, impact the nature of work and job roles (Iansiti & Lakhani, 2020).  However, in more recent years, it has been observed that businesses who are leading AI adoption are finding ways to incorporate AI and employees into collaborative teams that leverage their strengths to create impactful business solutions.  According to the 2020 Global Human Capital Trends report by Deloitte, business are finding ways to mitigate the loss of employees by providing various resources to help re-integrate them in a way to work with AI technology.  Yes, even as jobs are eliminated and the nature of work will change; new tasks and new job roles will be created. The key will be how companies are successful in creating and developing ways to augment their workforce rather than replacing them.

Patrick, personally, I am hopeful that in the future, the nature of work will be a positive evolution and we will find ourselves as a society in harnessing the power of AI that will benefit us all.

Thank you for sharing

title: Self Driving AI
text:
What kind of artificial intelligence should be embedded in autonomous cars? 

Autonomous vehicles will need to blend many of the different fields of AI in order to operate at the level of a human being. They will need: computer vision (to see their environment), NLP (to interpret road signs), speech processing (to interpret passenger inputs), robotics (to control their roadway actuators), as well as the ability to make fast rational decisions on how to act using their available information.



What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life? 

The technology will have to be overwhelmingly proven as safer than human beings in every road environment (rural, city, windy, raining, snowing, etc.). At that point the general public will need to be convinced that this technology is safe (hence the overwhelming evidence requirement). Once the public is ready for the technology then there will be enough political will to push through the regulation.

In terms of infrastructure, we may need actual physical infrastructure (one German company has constructed pylons along German roadways which its cars use to assist with navigation and internet connection https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l3ELVACR2VY&ab_channel=CarThrottle). We may also need better code infrastructure to allow autonomous cars to communicate with one another, base stations, and other physical infrastructure in a more efficient and secure way.



and when do you think this will happen?

I believe we will continue to see improving driver assistance systems for the next 5-10 years until technology and regulation allow for full self driving sometime in the 2030s. I base my thoughts here on what I have learned from articles and journalistic videos (business insider, 60 minutes).

title: General
text: I am enrolled in this program (MicroMasters), but all of them finish in December 2020 and they are instructor-lead. What happens if we pay fees and could not complete in December 2020? Will we still be able to get certified (if we pass all the exam) after the courses are archived? Thank you.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I am enrolled in this program (MicroMasters), but all of them finish in December 2020 and they are instructor-lead. What happens if we pay fees and could not complete in December 2020? Will we still be able to get certified (if we pass all the exam) after the courses are archived? Thank you.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
Hi, 

Thank you for joining the MicroMasters Program. The courses are instructor-led so that's why the course have fixed course schedule, due dates and final exams. 

If one doesn't pass at the end of the course (total grade below 60), he or she has to pay again to enroll in the next course run in the verified track. 

That says, you can, choose to change the course run or un-enroll some of the courses given that you are in the grace period (first 2 weeks of the course). See edX refund policy here. 

If you have any question or change of enrollment, please submit a ticket to edX help. If you have any other questions or concerns, please let us know. Thank you. 

Cheers, 

Shu-Yi

comments.text:
Hi Shu-Yi

Now, I’ve two different answers to the same question. I had also submitted a ticket to edx help and their answer was different from yours. I have included the answer from edx team as follows: 

“Hello,

Thank you for your participation in edX. We're glad you're interested in pursuing one of our program credentials.

If you purchase the program using the "Pursue the Program" button, you can still take each course in the session that works best for you. After you purchase the program, you’ll have 24 months to select a session for each course.

You can also complete and purchase the courses one by one. After you’ve earned a verified certificate from each course in the program, you’ll automatically receive the program credential at no further cost.

You don’t need to complete all of the courses at once in order to earn the program credential. Courses will be re-offered on an ongoing basis, and all certificates count towards the program credential. There is no overall deadline to complete the program, but individual courses do have deadlines that you can see on the course homepage when enrolled.

The program page lists all future course sessions that we have scheduled at this time. Try looking for the “more dates” option above the enrollment button to see future course listings.

For more information, please see this guide in our Help Center for completing a program:

https://support.edx.org/hc/en-us/articles/115015861488-How-do-I-complete-a-course-when-multiple-sessions-are-available-

I hope this is helpful. Please let us know if you have further questions.

Best regards,

……………..
the edX team
Find more answers in our edX Help Center”

I look forward to hearing from you.

comments.text:
Hi there, 

Great job for reaching out. The edx support explains 2 things in the letter.

1. For those who want to earn a Micromasters program certificate (meaning complete four courses), there is no deadline. As long as one completes four courses, then he or she will be awarded a Micromasters certificate.

2. Individual course has specific deadlines. AI, ML, Animation has assignments due on 12/13/2020 23:30 UTC. 

Robotics' assignment deadline is 11/29/2020 23:30 UTC. 

After the deadline, there is no more submission for all assignments and quizzes. And the last week is scheduled for the  final proctored exam. 

You then have one week to schedule your final proctored exam. After the course is finished, verified track will still be able to access the course videos, but audit track will not. 

If a student doesn't pass the course (total grade < 60) and wish to take the course again, it is welcomed. However, to enroll in the verified track in another run, one has to pay again to be in the verified track. And no course records can be transferred. 

Hope this explains the logistics. Please let me know if you have any other questions. I'd be happy to help. 

Cheers,
Shu-Yi

title: Hello from Tasmania, Australia!
text:
Hello all!



This is my first ever proper MOOC, and I'm looking forward to digging in! I'll be a bit slow to begin with as I'm a current full-time Master's student in another course at the moment (MA in Writing and Literature), but before embarking on that road, I completed philosophy, finance, and mathematics degrees! So I feel well-qualified to engage strongly with this unit, albeit a lack of Python knowledge (yet!). I have programmed in Java, C++, and Maple though, so I think this should be OK, and especially once I'm only studying one unit!



I'm probably much further south than most on this course, so hello from well south! I've just upgraded to the verified track. :) Looking forward to the various projects and such. My intention is to complete the full MicroMasters and develop projects of my own afterwards. Definitely some entrepreneurial ambitions there too, and, well, I wanted to upgrade my CS education and I feel it essential, especially coming into a post-2020 world, to understand the fundamentals of AI and Machine Learning, etc! I think this will complement my philosophy background nicely as well quite apart from the very important ethical considerations we must take into account as budding practitioners/theorists/both in the field!



Best wishes,

Davin

title: Artificial intelligence that should be embedded in autonomous cars
text:
Interacting park system maybe?
nowadays we can easily find Park assist option in our cars, but imagine a fully interacting autonomous park option that will interact with other cars to ask the neighbour car to move a little bit so the car can fit? or to check wether the car is going to leave the park soon or not! this will be intresting :)

What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life?

Infrastructure Level:
- we will need to adopt the current roads and this will need time and money.
- we need to build new traffic system as the current one will be obsolete(traffic lights, traffic signs,....etc)
- consider other autonomous vehicle like bikes? trains? trams?

Research Level:
this will need a huge researches and tests to be done to determine the unknown risks of it which also need time, money and resources.


Policy Level:
this technology will have a huge impact on many organisations that can't adopt to this technology so I guess it won't be easy to apply it as some parts will be with it and others will be against so it will requires some policy decisions to be made.

title: AI can be a Threat, Only if we Let it!
text: Due to technological expansion, there is no denying the potential existence of artificial super-intelligence in almost a century from now. On a daily basis, better algorithms are being written, computer architectures are being improved at an exponential rate, thus at some point, machines will start thinking beyond human capacity; but definitely not in a few decades. What the human race needs to develop however is a saturation point of how much these computers can learn, enough to solve the problems the world is currently facing. Eliminating the entire idea of AI would create even more problems as AI aims to combat a large number of challenges. In short; AI can indeed be a threat, only if we let it!

On a daily basis, better algorithms are being written, computer architectures are being improved at an exponential rate, thus at some point, machines will start thinking beyond human capacity; but definitely not in a few decades. What the human race needs to develop however is a saturation point of how much these computers can learn, enough to solve the problems the world is currently facing. Eliminating the entire idea of AI would create even more problems as AI aims to combat a large number of challenges. In short; AI can indeed be a threat, only if we let it!</paragraph></document>

title: With great AI comes great responsibility
text: I don't think AI will inevitably threaten the entire human race. Yes, new developments will make some jobs obsolete that can be done more efficiently by AI . But it is possible to adapt to these changes and it opens up new possibilities. However, intelligent systems can only be dangerous if they are allowed and able to act freely in the physical and virtual reality. If scientists succeed in creating an universal and conscious artificial intelligence, they and their political leaders are responsible to ensure that its powers will be limited to be used for the benefit of mankind.

title: What is AI?
text:
The authors of the book “Artificial Intelligence – A Modern Approach” raises the question “What is AI” on the first page, and then at the second page gives a few answers to that question. Once I believe that “acting rational” would be sufficient, but it is not. Drop a pen and the intelligent behavior for the artifact is to fall down until it hits the floor. In my opinion that is not sufficient for successful AI. Likewise, “acting humanly” is not enough, that is only about deception. Take a look at John Searle's “Chinese room” argument, and it is pretty obvious that this isn't enough. Embodied AI is about maintaining this deception. “Thinking rationally” is somewhat better, but it is still nothing more than a machine with some logic.

The only description that holds some merit is “machines with minds” (Haugland 1985), but this is also the most difficult to create. It is not only about reasoning and behavior, but how to actually create the mind. I would say this answer does not belong in the upper left quadrant of the matrix, as it is in a separate domain; what AI should be, and not how AI can be simplified.

Note that when the authors later tries to elaborate on “thinking humanly” in 1.1.2 they very quickly dig into “acting humanly” and computationally simulating human behavior. This is nothing but the script from the “Chinese room”.

Note also that some points referred don't even try to satisfy weak AI, while “machines with minds” goes further than strong AI.

I wonder if the authors fail properly identify the problems with simulation contra duplication, and due to that conclude computational intelligence is satisfactory. This is one of the core problems in AI, and is why I find the book to be somewhat questionable.

I should probably add that I am one of those that claim we should distinguish between “smart machines” and true “artificial intelligence”.

title: From AI-driven cars to AI-managed streets
text:
I think in the future we will have networks of interconnected autonomous vehicles. These networks will coordinate different vehicles to move around the city without problems. For example, if there is an accident, these networks will prioritize the movement of the ambulance and other emergency vehicles. In rush hour, it will change the way of some avenues to reduce the slow traffic. Instead of an AI managing one car, maybe in the future we'll have an AI coordinating the traffic.

Regarding the question 'What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life?' I think along with mature technology, we'll need people used to this type of driving and regulations to incentive AI-driven vehicles.

I think along with mature technology, we'll need people used to this type of driving and regulations to incentive AI-driven vehicles.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Yes, though I believe the idea is to have a network of "things" interconnected with several public systems of information. The concept of a city that uses data to behave optimally but also gives data as a public resource that private machines can use it's at the core of the concept of 'smart city'.

In my city there was a project from a few years ago, where they placed sensors all over the roads to track traffic. The idea was to use that real-time information (you can actually see the data online) to give input to traffic lights and improve traffic.

They did not reach that point because when the mayor changed, they reduced the budget and although we still have quite a few in place, but the concept of smart city keeps active in other ways: it is mandatory for people to scan their bus pass when they get on their buses and that data is used to manage bus frequencies on a daily basis. Also some tram lines have systems that allow permanent green lights by checking where the tram is at that moment and acting in a way that the tram always finds the green lights when it passes at that traffic light.

I believe it is more likely that cars can connect to a public, free, network of information from the city that allows them to take the best roads and decisions; than it is for a network to control all the cars which would have ethical problems because if it's public will mean that the government will be able to overcome the privacy of the cars owners and if it's private would be a pretty clear case of monopoly.

title: Teaming up with AI
text:
If Bill Gates, Elon Musk, and Stephen Hawking are all in alignment about AI being a real and formidable threat to humanity, that alone is worth paying attention to. My overall impression after doing the course readings, however, is the anticipation of a pleasant future where humans and AI work together. I was particularly struck by the example in 'Preparing for the Future of AI' where a human and machine team outperformed humans and machines acting independently. A human pathologist identified images of cancer-containing lymph node cells with a 3.5% error rate, AI with a 7.5% error rate, but working together they achieved an error rate of only .5%!

No matter how advanced our AI technology becomes, it will always be the fact that human brains and machines 'think' differently. This results in an important diversity which, I believe, will outperform homogeneous teams most, if not all, of the time. Fast-forward to a future world where AI really does become super-intelligent, I think it would do them well to remember that the smartest strategy is to stay on the same team.

This results in an important diversity which, I believe, will outperform homogeneous teams most, if not all, of the time. Fast-forward to a future world where AI really does become super-intelligent, I think it would do them well to remember that the smartest strategy is to stay on the same team.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
When AlphaZero handily beat Stockfish in chess, 28-0-72, it "proved" to me that ML systems can outperform GOFAI (Good old fashion AI - the human expertise assisted kind) , and that was in 2017.  Software-wise, ML enabled AI systems will not benefit from human "assistance" much longer.  We'll be more like interlopers.   

Hardware is where humans will add value to machines for years to come.   Until machines can auto-design, build, and assemble themselves at miniature scale, hardware AI / Artificial Lifeform cannot be ubiquitous.  Size and the need for physical distributions will significantly impede hardware intelligence growth.  Humans can live with software intelligent agents symbiotically by being their hardware intelligent agents/partners.

title: Can all problems be solved with search algorithms?
text:
Besides the toy problems and in the real world, is it possible to always resolve a problem with search algorithms?

Is there any other approach?

Thanks!
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Besides the toy problems and in the real world, is it possible to always resolve a problem with search algorithms?</paragraph><paragraph>Is there any other approach?</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Hey there,

This is a great question. Truly understanding the power of search algorithms starts when you begin to see the high level idea of what they are doing.

The high level idea of what search algorithms do is quite simple: they find a sequence of actions(among a choice of many) to find a solution to a problem. And so, anytime you have to make a choice among many actions repeatedly and the order of those choices matter, you can model your problem as a search problem.

For example, writing a proof(a direct proof, in this case) can be considered a search problem. 

You start with your given axiom(a start state), and are asked to sequence other facts or axioms to build an argument that lets you verify the truth value of a statement(goal state).

The key insight here lies in one simple fact. Once you are given an axiom, you can go in any possible direction from there, however you are supposed to choose an action that will lead you down the right path to solving your problem.

If you were to see the set of axioms you are given as a graph of interrelated ideas, then the path from the given axiom to what you are trying to prove is the solution. A search algorithm would be able to find such a path, and a search algorithm like UCS would find the shortest(and arguably, most elegant) proof.

Hope this helps.

Truly understanding the power of search algorithms starts when you begin to see the high level idea of what they are doing.</paragraph><paragraph>The high level idea of what search algorithms do is quite simple: they find a sequence of actions(among a choice of many) to find a solution to a problem. And so, anytime you have to make a choice among many actions repeatedly and the order of those choices matter, you can model your problem as a search problem.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, writing a proof(a direct proof, in this case) can be considered a search problem. </paragraph><paragraph>You start with your given axiom(a start state), and are asked to sequence other facts or axioms to build an argument that lets you verify the truth value of a statement(goal state).</paragraph><paragraph>The key insight here lies in one simple fact. Once you are given an axiom, you can go in any possible direction from there, however you are supposed to choose an action that will lead you down the right path to solving your problem.</paragraph><paragraph>If you were to see the set of axioms you are given as a graph of interrelated ideas, then the path from the given axiom to what you are trying to prove is the solution. A search algorithm would be able to find such a path, and a search algorithm like UCS would find the shortest(and arguably, most elegant) proof.</paragraph><paragraph>Hope this helps.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Hey, 

I am glad you found the answer useful. I'm also very glad to hear that you're willing to put in the work and learn more; that kind of mindset will greatly benefit you.



With that said, Logic does appear in AI. You will begin to see basic formal logic used in the context of AI to build what is known as a Knowledge Base. Formal logic will be used to represent what an Agent perceives in it's world. In many ways it is powerful, and you could definitely incorporate search algorithms to see if a certain conclusion is "reachable" from a given set of facts, and a "starting fact".

I hope this helps.

title: Turing
text: I found the paper from Turing very insightful. I had read about it and his definition but I had not read the full paper until now. He had very good and interesting ideas about machines, and intelligence. Definitely very advanced for the time he wrote them. Looking back, what people could do with computers in 1950 were actually great considering the technology and capacity of those computers. Those computers took us to the moon, but those computers didn't have the capacity of what our smart watches have today. It's just amazing how far we've come. We can now talk to Alexa and expect she understands what we want, and we get a little frustrated if she doesn't, but come to think of it, natural language is quite complex. In another 50 years, we will chat with our equivalent to Alexa and have conversations like they are human. This is just the beginning.

title: What AI 'is'...is what AI 'does'
text: Learning about the four schools of though for AI has really provided a deeper understanding and broader perspective of the various ways AI is regarded and interpreted.  In my opinion, in defining what AI is; it is important to understand what AI does.  The definition of AI provided by Russel and Norvig ( 2015) coincides with the fourth school of thought as presented by Pool et al. (1998).  The 'Acting Rationally'  theme of the the fourth school of thought speaks to what AI does.  Thus, according to the definition of AI presented by Russel and Norvig, AI does two things: 1) perceives its environment; and 2) takes action to maximize its chances for success.  AI is an emergent technology and the major components as defined by Turing (1950) is how AI is able to interact intelligently in an environment in a way that mimics human intelligence.  How AI is able to mimic human intelligence is what makes AI so powerful and versatile. AI can process all types of data, i.e., text, sound, language, images, and video through machine learning, natural language processing, robotics, etc.  As we continue as a society to study and learn about Artificial Intelligence; hopefully, many will come to view AI as a technology that could be leveraged for the good of human kind rather than fear it as a phenomenon that will eradicate our very existence.

AI is an emergent technology and the major components as defined by Turing (1950) is how AI is able to interact intelligently in an environment in a way that mimics human intelligence.  How AI is able to mimic human intelligence is what makes AI so powerful and versatile. AI can process all types of data, i.e., text, sound, language, images, and video through machine learning, natural language processing, robotics, etc.  As we continue as a society to study and learn about Artificial Intelligence; hopefully, many will come to view AI as a technology that could be leveraged for the good of human kind rather than fear it as a phenomenon that will eradicate our very existence. </paragraph></document>

title: Autonomous Driving - An exiting challenge
text:
"We are heading toward autonomous driving" is the first sentence of the second discussion question of week 1, and what a statement to kick the course off with. Some people will agree, others won't. I believe agreeing or not is merely a question of perception. Are we talking about full autonomous vehicles (level 5) on large scale in the coming 10 years, then I agree to disagree. However when we move the time horizon to +30 years, I tend to agree with the statement. A statement for which the author, most likely, chose the words carefully: "heading toward" does not specify a how fast or which level of autonomous vehicles (1-5)...

So what will it take us to get there? In terms of artificial intelligence a few aspects immediately jump to mind: computer vision detecting road signs, people, other vehicles and much more in a vast amount of driving situations (city, urban, highway, off-road) and conditions (sunny, rain, snow, fog,...), connected networks able to communicate with one another in real-time and optimize traffic flows, autonomous fleet management, human-machine-interface (HMI) able to communicate with passengers without having to learn to recognize their voice commands, ... only to say a few. 

Personally, as I am a simulation engineer of innovative hybrid powertrains, I also have a strong believe autonomous vehicles, combined with additional artificial intelligence, can be used to reduce the carbon footprint of the transport industry on the planet. A lot of research has been done and some vehicles even already include some kind of "predictive control", however this is still rule-based at this time. Taking the joystick away from the driver, allows not only the optimization of the individual vehicle on its journey, but could open the gate to so called "co-operative driving strategies", allowing a multitude of vehicles to align their driving style to reduce overall energy consumption (reduced braking/acceleration, reduced stops). Aside from the benefit for the planet, the passengers would also experience a more fluent and probably even quicker journey to their destination.

But before we get there, we will need to remove some big roadblocks and overcome challenging hurdles. On technological level, artificial intelligence is expected to get better and better with more training (more data), just as we do when we learn how to drive. However in order to obtain level 5 autonomous vehicles, the requirements are very high: "At Level 5 autonomy we arrive at true driverless cars. Level 5 capable vehicles should be able to monitor and maneuver through all road conditions and require no human interventions whatsoever, eliminating the need for a steering wheel and pedals."(https://www.truecar.com/blog/5-levels-autonomous-vehicles/). 

A first challenge that is unavoidable is that not all vehicles will immediately be autonomous. It is much easier to ensure safe operation in a controlled environment. When all vehciles would be autonomous, a proper communication system will result in rather safe operation. However human actions are unpredictable and it is hard to train an artificial intelligence to anticipate the, sometimes flawed, decision making of human beings. This is why the first "autopilot" systems are always in highway or in traffic jam conditions. City driving is much more dynamically changing and requires many more inputs to be processed which could (should?) influence the decision making process. However this point is, I believe, more of a hurdle than a roadblock. Many companies and research institutes are already investigating city driving with autonomous vehicles and I am quite certain this will become possible within a reasonable timeframe. 

One of the major real roadblocks according to me is regulation: car manufacturers require legislative institutes to clearly define which tests a vehicle needs to pass before a vehicle can be called "level 5 autonomous". Without such a definition, level 5 autonomous vehicles can never become a reality. But the definition of this legislation is not a task that should be taken lightly and can take >10 years (as a reference the definition of the "new" WLTP took ~20 years).

Another roadblock is the ethical decision making question: in an accident that cannot be prevented, who lives and who dies? Without a steering wheel the passengers have nothing to say in the answer to this question.

Then there is the hurdle of liability: what if an accident happens, who is responsible? The car manufacturer? The sensor manufacturers? The company who trained the artificial intelligence? How much redundancy is needed to ensure a failproof system on a worldwide scale?

And finally, and probably even most importantly, security: handing the control of a car to a computer system makes it very vulnerable to dangers which are currently not existing on a road. Imagine if all vehicles would be autonomous and a terrorist group is able to obtain control, the amount of casualties would be countless. Ensuring the highest level of security in a product that should be sold in mass for a reasonable price is not an easy task.

To summarize, I believe a lot needs to happen on...:
(I also added some points I didn't discuss above)

Policy level:

Legislation

Liability

Privacy (connected networks: how much data can be recorded and saved?)

Technological level (research)

Interactivity of autonomous vehicles in a human-driver populated city. 

Security

Horizon for connected networks

Infrastructure (didn't go into detail here but feel free to ask if anything is unclear):

Data processing facilities (centralized/decentralized)

Autonomous-only driving zones in cities

Are traffic lights still necessary?

Back-up systems (redundancy)

Connected networks data centers

Even though this is a challenging task, I am certain we have the capability to overcome them in the coming 30 years and am looking forward to order a self-driving car via my app to bring me to the supermarket to do grocery shopping.

Looking forward to read your opinions about my view on this topic.

Kind regards,

Nathan

PS: for who would be interested: I am an automotive powertrain simulation engineer and have also previously followed the courses from Dr. Lex Friedman at MIT (MIT Deep Learning and Artificial Intelligence Lectures).

answers.text:
Hi Nathan!

Cheers from Italy. My name is Victor.

I see a trend in this forum to create a single thread to give opinions of DQ2 topic but I think it is pointless since it will not lead to an actual dialogue. I'd rather give my opinion by introducing myself in the discussion thread that you started (and obviously by using as a starting point your opinion).

First of all I want to thank you because you have given me a broader view on the actual development of autonomous vehicles (I have not read about the 5 expected levels of autonomy).

I think by definition when we talk of actual autonomous vehicles we are talking of number 5 ones, although the idea of reaching autonomy by steps it is very practical since full autonomy might be far ahead in time.

(As I write this, I heard a car crash just in the street in front of me: a car did not respect the traffic lights on an avenue and the car who was passing crashed with it)

I believe the promise of autonomous vehicles, that has recently become material for us with the advent of powerful AI algorithms, processors and robotic systems, should point the finger to the actual technology that we must be developing: autonomous vehicles roads.

You point out that an immediate problem for Autonomous Vehicles (A.V.) development would be the coexistence of not autonomous vehicles in our roads.

I think that AV will not be possible at all if we do not design their own roads. Not only because it will avoid the problematic coexistence of AV and traditional vehicles, but also because AV will need roads that are able to offer to them information in real time, and modifying our own roads to implement sensors and so on in order to make the information available to the vehicles makes no sense. We should develop road already designed to fit the purpose.

This is already happening in an experimental way in Nord-Rhein Westphallia, a region from Northern Germany. I remember reading a few months ago they have several kilometers of road especially made for AV with dedicated sensors. They have made this road to experiment AV but I guess it makes more sense to promote these roads to "production" in the future (these roads I am talking about if I remember well pass along small cities so they might be able to connect them in the future).

The creation of dedicated roads would also make legislation easier by letting legislators come up with rules specific to those roads.

Implementing this in cities might be difficult, especially in big cities like New York or Paris where there is already little space for road development. That said the process might follow a similar pattern to that of bus or bike dedicated lawns that have flourished all across the world in the last decades.

This means money but it might be well invested money.

Security from the point of view of undesired access to the controls of a car (or even its position) is a very interesting topic I have not thought about. It is a topic that pertains all AI developments and all technological developments that have the capability to be remotely controlled. Cybersecurity in my opinion will also have to stop being seeing as a matter of protecting private (be it truly private or state private, in the sense of confidential state records) information and more as a matter of protecting the interactions between the individuals and machines so that they are legit. In that sense I believe cybersecurity will have to develop into a police force that patrols and control our roads, so the thread of cyber attacks it is not solely on the hands of car makers but also in the hands of our governments.

comments.text:
Hi Victor,

Thank you for your response and opinion. 

The idea of having dedicated roads for autonomous vehicles seems interesting and could avoid the problem of interaction with human controlled vehicles (I don't think this "solves" the problem, but rather avoids the conflict). However, I believe this would limit to great extent the implementation of autonomous vehicles on a wide scale. Imagine building a road between 2 cities which is only allowed to be used by autonomous vehicles. The passangers can travel between the 2 cities but they don't have a means of transport aside from public transport inside the cities. Certainly in Europe (but I expect in most developed countries) this is a big change of attitude for a lot of people. And unfortunately, people in general are reluctant to change (certainly when it means reducing luxury). I do however agree with the necessity of change but I believe this will take a lot of time. 

My long term view for cities is that we will change from owning a car out of necessity, to owning a "traditional" car for pleasure while the daily transport activities will be covered by transport service companies that own fleets of autonomous vehicles that can be ordered for transport (such as Uber for example). In that regard, travelling by car inside a city will also become a kind of "public transport" and cities could, eventually, ban the use of "traditional" vehicles (at least in specific parts). Combining this together with your vision of dedicated roads for autonomous vehicles connecting cities and a change of mind of the population could pave the road towards autonomous vehicles.

Kind regards,

Nathan

title: Is Artificial Intelligence Permanently Inscrutable?  I'm not sure.
text: If we look at a definition for the word inscrutable, we discover terms such as cryptic, incomprehensible, enigmatic, etc. In Bornstein's (2016) discussion, he addresses the challenges associated with interpreting the results of complex neural networks.  Neural networks are designed to behave as that of the neural networks in our brain. However, what I find interesting is that scientists are still trying to discover all there is to discover about the nature of neurological networks response to stimulus in our brain.  I expect that due to the complex nature of biological neural networks that some level of complexity could equally be expected in the design of technology that is trying to emulate neural networks.  It is my opinion, that the evolution of AI may be outpacing societies ability to reconcile and understand the full potential of the technology. But as our knowledge expands we will come to understand AI better to which there will be a new set of challenges to grapple with.

comments.text: I finished an interesting  book titled Rage Inside the Machine by R E Smith. It offers a different point of view on the topic. Smith argues (very convincingly, in my opinion) that the artificial neural networks we have are a pale parody of their biological namesakes, and how most of the machine learning algorithms today work on an excessively simplified version of the world - we remove the outliers, slice and dice the data (PCA etc.), and have altered the meaning of the words like communication, information, knowledge, intuition etc. removing all the nuance from them. The algorithms might be fine for recommending music and movies, or detecting cancer from scans, but when it comes to fields like criminal justice, or targeted advertising, this 'streamlining' of data and deriving insights from it without proper oversight might cause more problems than it solves.

The algorithms might be fine for recommending music and movies, or detecting cancer from scans, but when it comes to fields like criminal justice, or targeted advertising, this 'streamlining' of data and deriving insights from it without proper oversight might cause more problems than it solves. </paragraph></document>

title: The only "real" danger of AI and how to prevent it.
text:
Putting aside all the safety issues such as self driving cars, automated surgery etc, and ignoring the inevitable addition of AI into the workforce whether it be in simple automation of work, or helping with decision making or aiding in research and development (These points have all been argued to death from ethical and moral standpoints), the real problem we face occurs the moment we start creating an AI which is sophisticated enough to be able to rewrite its own code.

I won't bore you with the "blah blah blah singularity" speech, but effectively, the only "real" threat which we may not be able to overcome is when we start writing AI to improve AI. To put it simply, the only rule we should never break is that General Purpose AI should never be allowed to rewrite its own code WITHOUT supervision unless inside a closed system. Now this might seem like some alarmist remark due to the fact that if a General Purpose AI were to be written today with the ability to absorb any information and rewrite itself, it would obviously be greatly limited by our current technology, ie its speed of learning and acquiring/processing new information.

However, think about Allan Turing's example. Imagine the AI finds that in order to maximise its success, instead of trying to perfectly emulate a human, it finds that emulating a human "attempting to emulate an AI" (poorly) succeeds more often. It then learns that a viable winning strategy is not to perfectly emulate a human, but in fact to emulate a human poorly emulating an AI. (Now I don't propose to be anywhere near as smart as Alan Turing, as states that he finds it unlikely that this situation should arise, but lets explore the situation a bit more.)

Why is this even relevant? Lets think of a scenario in which we are training an AI to make its self smarter. Its goal is then abstractly coded to be "Learn to learn". Lets suggest that the method we are using gives it access to a vast database of information (Pictures, books videos, newspapers, conversations between people, etc). Now lets even go as far say that our method actually works, and we can see the the AI becomes more capable of understanding information and learning from it, which in turn lets it process more complex information and so on.

I think the first question becomes, "When do we stop it from learning? How far do we go?" You might be tempted to say "Well, once it reaches a certain learning rate threshold, we need to somehow handicap it to slow down its rate of learning or turn it off altogether." This seems like a reasonable solution, except lets think back to the Turing test example.

The AI learns that learning too fast is actually an obstacle, and so in order to maximise it's chance of success (learning to learn), it needs to emulate being worse than it currently is, thereby enabling it to learn exponentially without being turned off or handicapped. This may a first glance seem identical the the so called "singularity" - a point in time where AI experiences massive growth enabling it to learn faster, leading to a positive feedback loop of exponential learning. But there is one subtle difference, and that is the fact that we might not even know what is happening. Not because it is happening too fast, but because it has already happened, and the real results are being hidden from us.

Ok now that the scare mongering part is over, congratulations if you've made it this far. Lets get to actually solving this very hypothetical and unlikely scenario (debatable).

Rule 1. Don't code an AI with the ability to modify its own code.

Rule 2. When rule 1 is inevitably broken, make sure there are HARDWARE limitations in place to prevent exponential learning rates.

Rule 3. When both rule 1 and rule 2 are broken, how about we DON'T supply the AI with limitless access to an abundance of information (Internet?...).

Rule 4. You already know the deal, when all 3 rules are broken make sure that every child, woman and man have access to military grade EMP devices.

In all seriousness though the moment we start coding AI that learns to learn by re-coding itself, we should never break rule 2 and rule 3 simultaneously. Thanks for reading.

This seems like a reasonable solution, except lets think back to the Turing test example.</paragraph><paragraph>The AI learns that learning too fast is actually an obstacle, and so in order to maximise it's chance of success (learning to learn), it needs to emulate being worse than it currently is, thereby enabling it to learn exponentially without being turned off or handicapped. This may a first glance seem identical the the so called "singularity" - a point in time where AI experiences massive growth enabling it to learn faster, leading to a positive feedback loop of exponential learning. But there is one subtle difference, and that is the fact that we might not even know what is happening. Not because it is happening too fast, but because it has already happened, and the real results are being hidden from us.</paragraph><paragraph>Ok now that the scare mongering part is over, congratulations if you've made it this far. Lets get to actually solving this very hypothetical and unlikely scenario (debatable).</paragraph><paragraph>Rule 1. Don't code an AI with the ability to modify its own code.</paragraph><paragraph>Rule 2. When rule 1 is inevitably broken, make sure there are HARDWARE limitations in place to prevent exponential learning rates.</paragraph><paragraph>Rule 3. When both rule 1 and rule 2 are broken, how about we DON'T supply the AI with limitless access to an abundance of information (Internet?...).</paragraph><paragraph>Rule 4. You already know the deal, when all 3 rules are broken make sure that every child, woman and man have access to military grade EMP devices.</paragraph><paragraph>In all seriousness though the moment we start coding AI that learns to learn by re-coding itself, we should never break rule 2 and rule 3 simultaneously. Thanks for reading.</paragraph></document>

I have seen way too many lackadaisical software engineers in my time to have confidence that we won't get something so wrong that we don't get the chance to fix it. Sort of the 'Jurassic Park syndrome' if you will.

title: "Should we be concerned about Artificial Intelligence? Is AI a threat to humankind?”
text:
Hi everyone!



I actually think it would have been better if we had a single discussion thread about the proposed argument in DQ1 instead of several single threads. That way we could have more dialogue and it would easier from everyone to read... (As a suggestion to the staff, we should have a pinned thread for DQ1).



My opinion on this question is that, first of all, it is a good idea to consider how much journalists in the articles proposed are trying to overblown the statements of Gates, Hawking and Musk to create some sort of fear effect that they know will create discussion around the articles and generate more clicks, shares and sales for their newspapers.

That said, reading their own words I think the generally consensus among them is that AI poses a threat if leaved unruled. Most of them are not saying that AI is a danger regardless of how we develop it, they are saying that if we do develop AI in the wrong way we could face extinction, in the worst case.

It all boils down to the fact that there must be regulated ethics to the development of AI.

In particular I think that one has to always remember that AI can bring us an increased likelihood to survive as much as it can give us the opposite. We are not developing AI because we are "crazy scientists". AI can tackle already existing problems for our survival, like the use of natural resources, climate change, society and political problems that may lead to unrest and war like poverty among others, diseases that may be unexpected (like the current pandemic) and so on.

AI can actually help us avoid extinction and that is why we are developing it. However, and here are the words of Musk, Gates and Hawkins, we can develop it in a way that leads to extinction on itself.

It is human's duty to work on this.

I would like to add two more points to the discussion on the topic:

First, that the development of AI is inevitable. The option is not whether to develop AI or not but whether to develop AI ourselves with the right ethics or leaving it to others that may have the wrong ethics. Especially with the current availability of a set of principles and technologies that are leading to AI development, the choose to develop or not AI is not possible on a global scale. We can choose as research teams or even as nations to not develop ourselves such systems, but we will be leaving that option to terrorist, hackers or simply any groups of individuals (companies, etc) to do so. AI development is not an option, it is a global race towards a goal and if we really care about AI not becoming a human destruction weapon we must be the first to actually develop and master AI with the aim to increase likelihood of human survival even in circumstances when that means counteracting bad AI.



Second, and this would be a very controversial opinion and I beg pardon from whomever may feel offended for what I am about to say, the idea of superintelligence subsiding human intelligence and causing human extinction sounds more to me like evolution than  anything else. What if we imagined the transition from human intelligence to general artificial superintelligent systems in the same realm of the transition from homo erectus to homo sapiens? Not all evolutionary steps have to be identical though they are all probably caused by the environmental needs and the adapting behaviour of the species so why cannot we tell that we are at a more complex stage of evolution where we actively participate with the use of our intelligence in the development of our own next evolutionary step? What if the future species in human species path is GAI? I do not want for sure to be killed by an android or other kind of GAI but I do not mind our species being replaced by it in the arch of generations. In fact, the very concept of extinction in this regard is complex. I think we want better lives for ourselves and probably for our children, but isn't species survival beyond the actual scope of individuals? If a superintelligent agent far ahead from us in terms of intelligence as to be able to develop itself even more intelligent is possible, I do not think they will have any interest in directly killing us. We have come up as humans with systems that actually preserve other species in the animal world so I cannot imagine such superintelligent system seeing us an actual threat to them and thus they will not have any need to kill us, unless they understand we represent any threat to the whole environmental system of this planet and they are not able to come up with a solution other than intentionally eliminating us. But since they will be in this hypotheses pretty far ahead in terms of intelligence,  shouldn't they actually be right and shouldn't our elimination actually be good for the universe? These are complex question but since the question at the base of this discussion is are we not doing the wrong thing by developing artificial intelligence I think from a very philosophical point of view the answer will always be "development of intelligence, by definition, is never the  wrong thing".

answers.text:
Hi everyone, I also agree with Victor we should have just one single discussion thread for DQ1, so allow me to answer in this same thread.

"Should we be concerned about Artificial Intelligence? Is AI a threat to humankind?” 

I’ll also not comment on the position of Gates, Musk and Hawking’s because I also believe that the press as took them out of context and took them out of proportions.

The answer to these questions is not easy, and I dare to say it might have two possible answers. 

The answer to "Should we be concerned about Artificial Intelligence?", can be yes if we take as reference the impact that AI will have in the human society in a near future, when reading the article “Is Artificial Intelligence Permanently Inscrutable?” it is described an experiment at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, which shows how AI gave unexpected results due to the data used for training the model, meaning that AI might produce wrong results which will harm other human beings. The AI agent was not programmed to harm humans, nevertheless it would have done exactly that, I strongly believe ethics will play a major role in defining how AI will affect us. 

But the answer can also be no, if we look into AI in an evolutionary perspective, I do not agree that AI will evolve in the shadows against the human beings, and that AI will rewrite himself becoming a super intelligence. I do believe in John Searle “Chinese Room Argument”, if we give a formal program to an agent in how to perform a task that seems to the naked eye intelligent, it will not make that agent understand the process. 

The definition of intelligence is not an easy task, agents with artificial intelligent will be able to outperform humans in specific tasks, will support humans daily, but they will be only good for those tasks.

Let’s suppose for the sake of this discussion that we would use neurons to build a CPU, the same architecture as the transistor CPU, we all agree that the neuron CPU will perform the same arithmetic operations as fast or even faster that of the transistor CPU, meanwhile we as humans having neurons do not perform as near as fast as a transistor CPU, this is because evolution took a different way, in order for we as human beings to survive being good at arithmetic probably would not take us very far I suppose, all these million years of evolution allowed the human brain to evolve, but not only the brain, also our “sensors” and “actuators”. Transistors do not beat neurons; cameras do not beat eyes, time is part of the process and so evolution, human technology is far from mimicking nature. 

The argument here is that if we know how the process is done we will only be able to replicate the process, make AI be good at it ( playing chess, translating languages, planning, etc ),  we will not be able replicate the system nor the “intention” behind it. 

In the same perspective the answer to “Is AI a threat to humankind?” is no, as a specie, humankind will not be threatened by AI, although it might threat our way of living or freedom, biased results might create segregation on our society creating deeper distances between different social layers.

Of course, the argument changes when our technology starts to integrate biological components, or if we start using the same building blocks of biological structures in that case, we will start having the same evolution working with us. But this is probably another topic of discussion.

answers.text:
Hello everyone,

I also agree with having a single thread for a topic rather than multiple single message threads, kind of difficult to follow people's opinion that way.

And first of all kodus to everyone here to have such thoughtful opinion on the topic.

I will start by saying that probably it is too early for me to make such a strong opinion about the impact of AI on humankind, I am just starting to learn the idea of AI and its impact. Of course I posses basic understanding and being in IT industry for 10 years has given me enough opportunity to be at least early consumer of first few applications of early AI.

So with that let me try to articulate what I think of AI and if that can be a threat to the humankind.

Yes is my short answer. It can be a threat to the humankind, but we have to be super wrong in the process of developing/enhancing AI capabilities. The current applications of AI as we read in the articles referred in here are actually applications of narrow AI, now we all understand that narrow AI exists to solve a specific problem  and it can definitely cause some undesired outcomes like human fatalities but is not any close to causing human kind to extinct. What we are talking about here is AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) and its advanced levels/stages. 

As I understand it, we are nowhere close to achieving AGI, a lot more has to be learned and experimented to reach that level. The narrow AI can take many forms and uses different methods to solve different problems and has no common sense and is purely driven by data, whereas AGI is thought more like a child in its initial phases, where a singular system would be able to learn all the complexities and we will be able to apply AGI to solve varieties of the problems, it will also be able to apply its learnings from solving a problem while solving completely different set of problems and will posses common sense and will be nourished and taught like a baby and will be taught the purpose of its existence which will be to guide and help the human race. 

Now if you think about baby and how/what we teach them. We teach them how to behave in the social world, what is accepted and what is not. And it of course is not acceptable to hurt anybody, is it? I believe the AGIs are going be taught all these fundamental human social behavior/values and develop its common sense before anything else. And everything that they will learn will be on top of that. One additional thing that I believe will be engrained in these AGI systems is purpose of their existence which is to serve human race.

And just like a baby if you think about it, they will be able to unlearn what they were taught and make their own perception about the things based on their own experiences, the same can be applicable to AGI systems and which means one day these AGI systems will be grown ups and would want to do things how they want to do them. And they will be able to lie and hide things from human race just like an adolescent sometime behaves with his/her parents. And that will be the moment when human race will be able to understand why an AI system does what it does. 

But in the mean time until such AI system is close to be ready which is many decades from now, AI and its applications will greatly benefit the human race, will help in making new discoveries and will open completely new fields of research and science and will solve many unsolved difficult problems and will also help its own evolution. Because both human race and at some point AI would want to learn more and more and then reach a stage when AI do not need human race to teach them anything anymore.

Given all these things the development/deployment of AI based systems will need to be continuously monitored and validated, governments will have to come together to make some sort of world organization to keep things under check.
