title: Autonomous Driving: Morality and Economics
text:
I have a thought on the idea of autonomous driving and why it may be years before we (as humans) are willing to adopt it as a standard.  This comes down to: how comfortable are we with allowing machines to make moral decisions?  Or perhaps more colloquially put: what happens when the poopoo hits the fan?  Will the machine make the right decision?

I think we will totally get there for the simple situations.  There is a car in front of the autonomous vehicle (AV), so the vehicle stops, avoiding a collision and damage to property and people.  Or, it is rainy and the AV has detected wheel spin.  Slow down and / or engage traction control mechanisms.  Conditions have gone from light to dark, so activate external lighting.

These are simple scenarios, in the grand scheme of autonomous driving.

There are some that are much more complex and touch on ideas of morality.

As an example, consider an autonomous vehicle that is on a collision course with a broken down vehicle.  This autonomous vehicle is traveling too fast to avoid collision, but it could drive off the side of the road, potentially injuring its own occupants.  It may know nothing about the passengers in the other vehicle or if there are any.

What does it do?

Yes, it will most likely be able to act faster than a human driver but what if the decision it arrives at is the wrong one?  What if there are passengers in the other vehicle and the AV makes the decision to hit it anyhow, thus minimizing damage to its own occupants but almost certainly causing harm to the passengers of the other vehicle.  Or does it drive off the road, thus avoiding the stopped vehicle but causing harm to its own passengers?  Will it weigh the perceived value of the lives at stake and make a simple if else decision?

This is an ethical paradox I'm not sure we are comfortable handing over to machines right now.

The scenario I'm describing is a bit dramatic but almost certainly similar situations will arise.  This moral / rational decision making may not always be in line with human thinking. 

THAT is the type of issue I see being problematic with autonomous driving.  We may not solve this problem for decades or maybe we will just be willing to accept that risk.

title: Greetings from Florida!
text:
Hello everyone!

My name is Mark and I am a software developer, entrepreneur, and life long learner.  I'm hoping to leverage this class to both satisfy my desire to learn and open new career opportunities. title: Autonomous driving cars - it will happen
text:
Like any new technology, there is pros and cons. It is only a matter of time. The pros will inevitably outweigh the cons. Humans can make very fast and good decisions when focused, but driving is tedious and boring after a while. We have statistics about accidents and deaths due to distracted drivers. Autonomous vehicles have come a long way and can handle most scenarios but they are not at a point that can be fully trusted. There are still so many exceptions that need to be modeled and tested. Many people (including me) would not fully trust autonomous cars yet. Eventually, as we see the benefits for people that can't drive (for many reasons, age or disability), commercial use, and we'll come to accept some level of risk, the same way we accept the risk of air flight. 

Challenges that autonomous cars need to deal with are mostly ourselves, humans, which are unpredictable, can cross street without paying attention, other human drivers, etc. 

In a much distant future, all cars will be autonomous, they will go much faster and will be in synch, communicating with each other to avoid collisions. Imagine Waze but among cars being the ones alerting each other of hazards in the road, traffic, people or dogs in street, etc. Street lights will not be needed for cars but for pedestrians only.

title: The threat of AI
text:
I am optimistic. The discussion about intelligence, consciousness, intentionality is very interesting, but ultimately, we don't fully understand how our own brain works. The focus of AI should be to create behavior to achieve a specific goal. But machines don't have the same feelings and emotions, ambition than we do. They perform tasks, and we can teach them to do them better than we can, in the same way robots can perform tasks in a factory much better and faster than humans, because they are specialized. AI will help us solve problems we may need too much time to do ourselves. AI will continue to evolve and be more precise. How it is being used is what people are concerned about. There will be bad actors that will continue to use AI to advance their goals, like create confusion in elections or bring people against each other with false ideas in social media. At same time, there will be good actors that will also use AI to defend against the bad actors. It is not all AI being good, and all AI being bad. It will be both and how it is used.

Do i think, at some point, AI systems will become too intelligent to want to be independent of humans and get rid of us? Not any time soon! I am not going to worry about that.

title: Autonomous vehicles - what will it take?
text:
What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life (on the policy level, infrastructure level, research level, etc.), and when do you think this will happen?

Autonomous vehicles can make roads safer without necessarily having to invest (and fix) large amounts of capital in asphalt and concrete. I work in the construction industry and I have been involved in large infrastructure projects which are built to improve the time it takes to get from A to B and doing so safely as well as to a specific level of quality. We have been doing that for centuries. What if instead of building new roads and bridges we could actually focus on the instruments we use to drive with, so that, they themselves adapt more rapidly and efficiently to the road conditions we are driving on? 

Before jumping onto what the technology can or can't (yet) do, I think the conversation needs to focus around aligning the interests of all stakeholders, setting up KPIs to track real progress, and keep all parties accountable. It will not be an easy task to align the interests of players who would naturally differ. However, in my view, it is a task that shall be prioritized over continuing to widen our roads or building new highways.

I would also like to challenge all of us to look at how cities that were built before motorised vehicles existed, were planned and organised. What was there before a road was built? How did they operate when there were only man-propelled methods of transport, such as bicycles, horses, donkeys, or just pedestrians? 

In those cities, roads did not need to have a separated space for pedestrians only (walkway) and then one (fairly large) for cars, trucks, and the rest. Everyone shared the same space. Traffic lights and other signs were introduced to establish a hierarchy for who needs to give right and who needs to wait until the traffic light turns green. In the many decades, we have had motorized vehicles introduced in cities, we have retrofitted our urban spaces to the needs of 'dumb' machines at the expense of diminishing the experience of pedestrians, cyclists, and anyone who chooses active transportation methods. 

Wouldn't it be nice if autonomous vehicles would be able to share the road and give right to pedestrians and cyclists regardless of whether they are using a designated crossing point? Think about India and how people use roads there. It reminds me of a swarm of bees, birds, or fish in the sea. Autonomous vehicles powered by AI could behave like swarm of bees and be programmed to avoid us as if we were predators. Getting back the spaces once stolen from us to introduce vehicles in cities would definitely make, in my opinion, a good case for cities to support the development of autonomous vehicles.

title: Quiz Options Including None
text:
Hi all,

How is it possible to have a "None" option being a choice when one of the other options is also a choice?

In other words for example; is it possible to have choice 2 AND "None", I'm asking because "None" means you don't select any of the other choices.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi all,</paragraph><paragraph>How is it possible to have a "None" option being a choice when one of the other options is also a choice?</paragraph><paragraph>In other words for example; is it possible to have choice 2 AND "None", I'm asking because "None" means you don't select any of the other choices.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
I was confused by this too for a while. I selected "None" by itself and was told it was partially correct. I eventually figured it out and got the correct answer.

"Partially correct" is misleading in this case because I think it is verifying not only that you have the correct options "selected", but also that you have the incorrect options "not selected".

title: Should we be concerned about AI?
text: I think that while AI has the ability to think and act rationally, we cannot always be 100% certain as to how they come up with their results and what they may do with them. There is some danger to that, but the Chinese Room Argument has me optimistic that AI will not become more than we make it. AI can mimic human practices with logic but it will never be human enough (with emotions) to outsmart the human race.

There is some danger to that, but the Chinese Room Argument has me optimistic that AI will not become more than we make it. AI can mimic human practices with logic but it will never be human enough (with emotions) to outsmart the human race.</paragraph></document>

This will allow us (humans) to focus more on the "human" side by looking into ourselves, our emotions, our needs as humans to connect, socialize, and become better humans in dealing with each others. 

As any other field, AI can be misused (think of cellular phones that enabled us to stay connected, yet can be also used by bad people to spy and attack). That explains the rise of the Ethical AI community to ensure we use AI to the benefit of humans

title: Autonomous cars
text:
What kind of artificial intelligence should be embedded in autonomous cars?

There is ton that's needed to make the autonomous cars work reliably

Computer vision to start with, and it needs to be able to do image detection/recognition very well to make a distinction between a human vs an object. It might even need to understand a distinction between different human beings for cases when a car will have to make an important difficult decision to choose a human over another if that's the only option car has.

Robotics - It needs to be able to move/drive reliably of course.

Smart networks - Cars need to be able to form a smart intelligent network among each other and talk to each other to assist each other to make better decisions. This will help in so many cases like where a car in trouble can warn other vehicles near it about its condition and help itself and others too from getting into a serious situation. The smart network can enable so many use cases like smart navigation, where cars can guide each other to make a best possible decision to choose a best possible route.

Speech recognition/NLP  - It will help riders to be able to freely communicate with car and be confident that car will do whatever it takes to keep the rider safe. 

Smart diagnostics- Cars will have to understand its own health and warn/alert users in cases where undesired signals are detected.

Cars will also need to be connected to various external systems for possible alerts and act reasonably, signals like extreme weather alerts, natural disaster alerts, terrorists attacks alerts, crime reported alerts, etc will be some of the sources that cars will have react to.

Etc



What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life(on the policy level, infrastructure level, research level, etc.),

Of course policies will have to adopt new environment, the most challenging part of the policy will have to consider this hybrid system where smart cars will have to exist along with non smart vehicles for a long time. The policies will have to open enough to not harm/stop the innovation while keeping safety/risks in mind. 

The current generation of autonomous cars are built on the bases of existing infrastructure and rules and of course the infrastructure is not in absolute needed shape everywhere an autonomous will have to operate, the standards for infrastructure will have to be high and strict than before. It is going to play equal role in the interim before autonomous cars become an application of AGI, when it will be operate in any condition like a human being can.

The research will have to be continuous, the thing about AGI and machine learning algorithm is that they will require continuous testing/validation to make sure that the system behaves in an expected in unforeseen open environment. The research in this domain will help us understand the AI better and make it more efficient and safe with each iteration.

When do you think this will happen?

It is definitely is close at least for the first generation of autonomous cars , I would way we might see autonomous cars operating without requiring drivers to keep their hands on steering within a decade from now.

title: Heads in the Sand on AI?
text: AI is such a great threat, greater than climate change, greater than nuclear weapons, that many will choose the "Heads in the Sand" objection as observed by Turing.   It's much more comforting to rationalize that AI or AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) can be controlled, or is far in the future, or even can be directed to our benefit.  Though I hope to be wrong, I think AI will threaten humanity's purpose and existence within our generation.  From unintended consequences to AI as weapons, to eliminating jobs and upending Capitalism, to Super AIs deciding that humans are obstacles to efficiency, any and all these disaster scenarios can occur at networking speed.   It only took 4 hours for AlphaZero to learn how to play chess for it to beat a world-class computer chess-engine (Stockfish, 2017) .    In 2018, teamAI beat professional DOTA2 players in a very complicated MMO.    When networked AI start teaching each other in a general sense, it may take just hours for AI to achieve superintelligence, with consequences to follow.   Future of Humanity Institute of Oxford and Institute for Human Centered AI at Stanford are trying to right our path to AI use.  Let's support them for our own sake.

In 2018, teamAI beat professional DOTA2 players in a very complicated MMO.    When networked AI start teaching each other in a general sense, it may take just hours for AI to achieve superintelligence, with consequences to follow.   Future of Humanity Institute of Oxford and Institute for Human Centered AI at Stanford are trying to right our path to AI use.  Let's support them for our own sake. </paragraph><paragraph/></document>

title: Autonomous cars of the future
text:
More than just self-driving vehicles that take passengers from point A to B, I hope to see cars that can:

coordinate with intelligent agents at next stops (e.g. concierge service, prep ER receiving)

be tour guides to new and possibly surprising destinations

self-fueling; self arrange and acquire maintenance

be the eyes and ears of law enforcement

Basically I want an Alexa/iRobot with God's Eye (ala Fast and Furious) built into all future cars.

Policy-wise, there needs to be good data to show the benefits of autonomous vehicles (AV) against their problems before opening up the AV tech to the general public.  While transitioning from Human-controlled vehicles (HV) to AVs, we can approach it block by block, city by city, road by road, perhaps with dedicated lanes for AVs or Autonomous trucks.  We need the auto-insurance industry to significantly lower rates for AV owners.

Infrastructure wise, we need to build special roads and entryways for AVs while redirecting HVs safely into and out of AV zones.  We need fast charging stations for AVs.   We need enhanced signal tranceivers to communicate with AVs, especially in cities with tall building where signals bounce all over.

Many of AV tech is already in trials.  Let's hope to get much wider deployment (say 10x of today) in 10 years.

title: Augmented AI
text: I would rather have AI augment Human Intelligence and help us reach new levels of thinking rather than developing AI for AI's sake. This is the source of all the fear and imaginative AI Dystopia that the movie industry and other media feed from. If we put ourselves at the center of the AI revolution then we can control what AI future we will ultimately have.

title: Machine Learning - a generalization of four types of agents?
text:
The second lecture on Intelligent Agents mentioned a couple of times how machine learning, or learning agents, are a generalization of the set of four types of agents that were described - simple reflex, model-based reflex, goal-based agents, and utility-based agents. 

The learning agents have four components, a learning element, performance element, a critic, and a problem generator. What I don't understand is how the learning agent could be a generalization of, say, the simple reflex agent. Unless I'm misunderstanding the statement, does the simple reflex agent have a learning element? And a critic? 

Perhaps what this means is that machine learning can be used to generate a simple reflex agent, but the simple reflex agent itself is not a learning agent?  Please help me understand what I'm missing here.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The second lecture on Intelligent Agents mentioned a couple of times how machine learning, or learning agents, are a generalization of the set of four types of agents that were described - simple reflex, model-based reflex, goal-based agents, and utility-based agents. </paragraph><paragraph>The learning agents have four components, a learning element, performance element, a critic, and a problem generator. What I don't understand is how the learning agent could be a generalization of, say, the simple reflex agent. Unless I'm misunderstanding the statement, does the simple reflex agent have a learning element? And a critic? </paragraph><paragraph>Perhaps what this means is that machine learning can be used to generate a simple reflex agent, but the simple reflex agent itself is not a learning agent?  Please help me understand what I'm missing here. </paragraph></document>

comments.text: Learning agents being a generalization means that they have the properties (could simulate) a simpler agent. That means, for example, that a learning agent encapsulates the properties of a reflex agent, and not the other way around.

That means, for example, that a learning agent encapsulates the properties of a reflex agent, and not the other way around.</paragraph></document>

title: Embedded in autonomous cars
text:
What kind of artificial intelligence should be embedded in autonomous cars? 

Maybe an unpopular opinion, the concept of animals (prior to being roadkill) should be something that is embedded in autonomous cars. Thinking a real life example - WAZE is fed information by humans who can see things on the road. They can indicate when a dead animal is there but not when a live one is. This does not need to be a motion sensor but maybe a feature that can show learnings on allowing the machine to observe what is around them. 

What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life (on the policy level, infrastructure level, research level, etc.), and when do you think this will happen?

to an extent i think this is already a reality - for example how they are using postmates self driving delivery men

title: Should we be concerned about AI?
text:
I personally believe that AI is a great opportunity to improve the quality of life. With AI investments and improvements in sectors like health, environment, transportation, etc. we have already started seeing improvements such as precision in diagnostic of diseases, precision in defining care plans, and others. This will allow us (humans) to focus more on the "human" side by looking into ourselves, our emotions, our needs as humans to connect, socialize, and become better humans in dealing with each others. 



As any other field, AI can be misused (think of cellular phones that enabled us to stay connected, yet can be also used by bad people to spy and attack). That explains the rise of the Ethical AI community to ensure we use AI to the benefit of humans

title: Autonomous cars - yay!
text:
DQ2: We are heading toward autonomous driving. What kind of artificial intelligence should be embedded in autonomous cars? What will it take to have autonomous driving be part of our daily life (on the policy level, infrastructure level, research level, etc.), and when do you think this will happen?



I think autonomous cars should have all the AI they need to make them safer and more efficient for humans. We'll of course have to create new laws about certain safety standards, when companies are liable for mistakes their AI make, and where the cars can exist(e.g. highways vs. roadless environments). I think autonomous cars will be a reality within 10 years, although to get to that point we'll be in a transition period where it'll simply assist humans in staying safe.

These autonomous cars will have accidents every 2 million miles or more, versus humans having accidents on average every 100,000 miles. This will save many more lives and prevent more injuries than it could cause.

title: The threat of AI depends on human variable
text: There can be several schools of thought regarding whether or not artificial intelligence is a threat to humankind. First would argue the benefits of artificial intelligence would greatly improve our capacity to solve and automate workloads in numerous aspects of our lives. The second that once you start to make machines that are rivaling and surpassing humans with intelligence, it's going to be very difficult for us to survive. What both do not take into account is what ultimately decides this question, the human element, or more specifically intention and ethics. Intention is a variable that is ever-changing and unpredictable. The best hope for humankind is to use the inevitable technological advances ethically. As with anything else there would always be situations of outliers.

answers.text: There is no error in the quiz. However, the partial credit system is a bit tricky. Each of the 4 options has 2.5 points associated with it. If an option is meant to be selected and you select it, you get 2.5 points, and if it is meant to be unselected and you leave it unselected, you get 2.5 points. So, if you select an incorrect answer and leave everything else unselected, you will get 5 points for leaving the other two incorrect options unselected. You will get full credit only if you select the right answers, and leave the incorrect answers unselected. Hope this helps clarify things!

So, if you select an incorrect answer and leave everything else unselected, you will get 5 points for leaving the other two incorrect options unselected. You will get full credit only if you select the right answers, and leave the incorrect answers unselected. Hope this helps clarify things!</paragraph></document>

title: DFS implementation
text:
Hi,

In the DFS pseudocode in the lecture, there doesn't seem to be a removal of explored states as soon as all of their children nodes have been visited. (I see "explored.add(state)" but no "explored.remove(state)")

However, I understand that this removal of exhausted nodes is what makes the algorithm so memory-efficient.

Should we implement this state-removal feature in the project?

Thanks,

Julien
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi,</paragraph><paragraph>In the DFS pseudocode in the lecture, there doesn't seem to be a removal of explored states as soon as all of their children nodes have been visited. (I see "explored.add(state)" but no "explored.remove(state)")</paragraph><paragraph>However, I understand that this removal of exhausted nodes is what makes the algorithm so memory-efficient.</paragraph><paragraph>Should we implement this state-removal feature in the project?</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks,</paragraph><paragraph>Julien </paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
I think we shouldn't remove the state from the explored set since we check if the state is explored before frontier.push(state). 

And the line state = frontier.pop() is where we remove the state from the frontier. pop method generally removes and returns the last element.
comments.document: I think we shouldn't remove the state from the explored set since we check if the state is explored before frontier.push(state). And the line state = frontier.pop() is where we remove the state from the frontier. pop method generally removes and returns the last element.

answers.text: A node moves from unexplored to frontier to explored and that is its final resting place. You retain it in the explored space forever so that you don’t add it again to the frontier and expand it and retrace the same path. You might come upon an already explored node via some other connection, but the second time (and all times after that), you’ll ignore it because you see that it’s already present in the explored space.
answers.document: <document version="1.0"><paragraph>A node moves from unexplored to frontier to explored and that is its final resting place. You retain it in the explored space forever so that you don’t add it again to the frontier and expand it and retrace the same path. You might come upon an already explored node via some other connection, but the second time (and all times after that), you’ll ignore it because you see that it’s already present in the explored space.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
This is true but it doesn't answer the concern of use of space. 

I believe the comment about the space advantage being reliant on clearing the explored branches is correct. 

The algorithm given in the lecture is a graph search because it retains explored nodes in memory. Page 87 of the text (2010 edition) states that DFS does not have a space advantage if implemented as a graph search. 

I won't do it here (not sure I'd be able to prove it myself) but I think if you work through the space complexity of a DFS graph search you'd find it to be O(b^m), which is at least as bad as O(b^d).

Furthermore, I don't think that a DFS tree search would fail in a finite state space if it keeps the branch being explored in memory. Even though you will reexplore nodes a bunch, it will not go back and forth along the same path forever. See page 86 of the text (again 2010 edition, sorry...). This page states that a complete DFS tree search can be implemented at no extra memory cost. 

Probably because tree search keeps a frontier anyway, which would be the current branch being explored. In a finite space, the frontier would, at worst, contain every state, then no nodes would be able to be expanded and the search would move onto to the next branch. It sounds bad (and I guess for time complexity it is) but the memory complexity in this case would be O(bm).

I think what I've said is correct but please point out any errors, this stuff is very new to me. I'm mostly just parroting the text book.

Page 87 of the text (2010 edition) states that DFS does not have a space advantage if implemented as a graph search. </paragraph><paragraph>I won't do it here (not sure I'd be able to prove it myself) but I think if you work through the space complexity of a DFS graph search you'd find it to be O(b^m), which is at least as bad as O(b^d).</paragraph><paragraph>Furthermore, I don't think that a DFS tree search would fail in a finite state space if it keeps the branch being explored in memory. Even though you will reexplore nodes a bunch, it will not go back and forth along the same path forever. See page 86 of the text (again 2010 edition, sorry...). This page states that a complete DFS tree search can be implemented at no extra memory cost. </paragraph><paragraph>Probably because tree search keeps a frontier anyway, which would be the current branch being explored. In a finite space, the frontier would, at worst, contain every state, then no nodes would be able to be expanded and the search would move onto to the next branch. It sounds bad (and I guess for time complexity it is) but the memory complexity in this case <italic>would</italic> be O(bm).</paragraph><paragraph>I think what I've said is correct but please point out any errors, this stuff is very new to me. I'm mostly just parroting the text book.</paragraph></document>

Hi Mark,

This is exactly what I meant.

I believe it is necessary to remove the explored states from the "explore" set once all children nodes have been explored. Otherwise, the memory benefits of DFS can't be realized.

The question is how to check against explored states. One option could be to keep a reduced version of the explored states (just the info that matters, not the entire class element). But that wouldn't solve the issue of O(b^m) vs O(bm).

With a recursive function, you don't need to store the explored and frontier in a separate data structure. The iterations of the function and their location in the stack equates the storing of frontier.

I believe the instructors decided to do this implementation to ease the understanding on the first project.

title: Should we be afraid of AI?
text: I'm answering the discussion question above. I think that, given the scope that AI intends to converge on, we should be afraid of AI, at least those whose work invovles manual labor. Unless laws are put in place to protect manual labor, or if an alternative is put in place for them, then companies will act in their best interest and use AI instead of humans for their work.

title: Autonomous Driving
text: For a car to dive autonomously, it must be indistinguishable from a human driver, with no physical connection to the road itself, like a train. It would have to have an very strong collision detection system, possibly even a sensor to track its surroundings from a wide distance. It may be a while before technology catches up to this task however.

answers.text: The order in which you add the children to the frontier is not specified by the algorithm. So, if you add the left child first and then the right child, you will pop right child first (because of LIFO) and vice versa. They are both correct implementations of the DFS algorithm in general, but if the assignment specifies a certain order you should stick to that to get similar results.

text:
On the UCS question on the quiz for going from Los Angeles to Portland

My Answer was:

Los Angeles, Las Vegas, San Francisco, Phoenix, Salt Lake City, El Paso, Portland

I got it wrong, the solution seems to go through Santa Fe and Denver as well.

To go to Santa Fe and Denver you would have to go after passing through Phoenix (109)

My question is why would you go through Phoenix (109) if San Francisco (100) costs less and the goal Portland is connected to San Francisco? Wouldn't you stop when you find Portland connected to San Francisco?

Last part of the UCS is not done on the video class so I think I might have missed something.

Hope I made sense.

Thank you

answers.text: According to the UCS algorithm, the goal test happen only when the state is dequeue from the Frontier.  i.e. not when the neighbor is added to the Frontier.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>According to the UCS algorithm, the goal test happen only when the state is dequeue from the Frontier.  i.e. not when the neighbor is added to the Frontier.</paragraph></document>

title: "Is AI a threat to humankind?"
text:
It is inevitable that AI will become a threat up front.

We have some cases that unintentionally took courses that were "dangerous" like Tay from Microsoft or Bob and Alice from Facebook.

Fantastic cases like Tesla and SpaceX, who knew?

Inevitably, we will debate on the development of AI. We have a lot of responsibility in the paths we are going to take: removing a hereditary disease from our DNA, or simply changing the color of our children's eyes. These are some very controversial items, not to mention the science fiction Own! "Terminator", "I, Robot" or "Transcendence"

These are some very controversial items, not to mention the science fiction Own! "Terminator", "I, Robot" or "Transcendence"</paragraph></document>

title: autonomous driving, perfect!
text:
It is fantastic to see Elon Musk's work, both at Tesla and SpaceX. Both have "core" to drive autonomously, of course dealing with different variables, each with its own complexity.

I imagine perfect "autonomous driving", when all cars have this behavior, for that it is necessary a large network, where all cars transmit information between them, thus defining the ideal speed for a route, depending on the number of vehicles, a " internal redesign ", thanks to the security, of this large network, where our attention would not be needed on external events, as we would have enormous confidence in the model. Do I see a transformation of the car into a "living room"?

I know that it is not easy to reach these points, it will require a lot of work. Beginning the implementation of this system in a large model, and after it has been validated, produce and deploy in a small city, exhaustively test the model, and then expand in another.

It would be fantastic to participate in this revolution, I imagine that we will have something like this in about 12 years.

title: Quiz 2 - Question 3
text:
This problem is phrased ambiguously. The meaning of the words in it are used differently in the lectures.

The question is "If there is a solution, Uniform-cost search is guaranteed to return the optimal one. True or False ?", and the correct answer here rests on assuming that an infinite cost path is not a solution. 

That is a reasonable assumption, but that is not how that language is used in the lectures. In video "Week 2/ 2.3 Uninformed Search / Uniform-Cost Search Criteria", the instructor says the following:

"So first of all, is [Uniform-Cost Search] complete? Yes it is, assuming that the solution has a finite cost. The problem would be complete."

Which implies that solutions can have infinite costs, and the existence of a solution (but not a finite solution) is not sufficient to guarantee that UCS completes.

This equivocation in how language is used makes answering this question a crap-shoot.

The meaning of the words in it are used differently in the lectures.</paragraph><paragraph>The question is "If there is a solution, Uniform-cost search is guaranteed to return the optimal one. True or False ?", and the correct answer here rests on assuming that an infinite cost path is not a solution. </paragraph><paragraph>That is a reasonable assumption, but that is not how that language is used in the lectures. In video "Week 2/ 2.3 Uninformed Search / Uniform-Cost Search Criteria", the instructor says the following:</paragraph><paragraph>"So first of all, is [Uniform-Cost Search] complete? Yes it is, assuming that the solution has a finite cost. The problem would be complete."</paragraph><paragraph>Which implies that solutions can have infinite costs, and the existence of a solution (but not a finite solution) is not sufficient to guarantee that UCS completes.</paragraph><paragraph>This equivocation in how language is used makes answering this question a crap-shoot.</paragraph></document>

answers.text: I understand your confusion, but yes in this case we are assuming that the problem is complete, that is, the solution has a finite cost.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I understand your confusion, but yes in this case we are assuming that the problem is complete, that is, the solution has a finite cost.</paragraph></document>

title: Week 1 DQ 1: Dangerous of AI
text: I believe AI can get very dangerous if we do not put legal boundaries around it. There should be laws that protect us and make big corporations accountable for full disclosure of potentially harmful effects the technology can cause. Recently it came out that AI behind social media, mail, news applications are designed to make us literally addicted to them. That should not have happened and we should protect our children from becoming depressed zombies unwilling to focus on any task. Artificial intelligence should not be trained to manipulate our vulnerabilities and emotions since that might be our only disadvantage against artificial intelligence, and if they learn how to train us and make us puppets then we are doomed. Artificial intelligence is not constricted by slow evolution, but we are, and it might take us too long to evolve our brains to be at par with will power, emotion control of that of artificial intelligence.

title: W1 DQ2: Autonomous driving
text:
We are indeed heading towards autonomous cars. We already have those cars out in the streets, but one thing that is holding back the full adoption of them is that they cannot guarantee a hundred percent safety. Those cars would have to have absolutely no error tolerance when it comes to safety. That can be achieved with the right infrastructure. Think about metro trains, they can be regarded as the first autonomous vehicles in a constrained environment that we adapted to. If we could build cars so that they track surroundings not only by vision control systems but also by detecting signals from other cars and possibly anything that moves, that would potentially help us reach 0 percent accident rates. It would require everyone to have some sort of signal chip to use when they are going outside - maybe embedded chips. That would mean that we are going to be part of the infrastructure. 

I believe we will adopt self-driving cars very soon, maybe in the next decade.

title: DFS version of the Map example (2.4  Uninformed Search Examples)
text:
Hello everyone,

In the DFS version of the Map example (2.4  Uninformed Search Examples) shouldn't the order be 'Atlanta, Charleston, Miami, Nashville' instead of 'Atlanta, Charleston, Nashville' ?

Because of LIFO and the lexicographical order, Miami should be in the stack before Nashville right?

Regards,

RM1989
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello everyone,</paragraph><paragraph>In the DFS version of the Map example (2.4  Uninformed Search Examples) shouldn't the order be 'Atlanta, Charleston, Miami, Nashville' instead of 'Atlanta, Charleston, Nashville' ?</paragraph><paragraph>Because of LIFO and the lexicographical order, Miami should be in the stack before Nashville right?</paragraph><paragraph>Regards,</paragraph><paragraph>RM1989</paragraph></document>

answers.text: for LIFO and lexicographical order, the "larger" one should be pushed to the stack first before the "smaller" one.  So that the "smaller" one is always pop out first before the "larger" one.  i.e. Nashville should be pushed in the stack before Miami.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>for LIFO and lexicographical order, the "larger" one should be pushed to the stack first before the "smaller" one.  So that the "smaller" one is always pop out first before the "larger" one.  i.e. Nashville should be pushed in the stack before Miami.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph/></document>

title: Why does the expand method in the skeleton code adds already visited nodes as children?

Hi, I have noticed the expand method doesn't check if the new configuration has already been visited. For example, it is very common to see the parent node as one of the children when expanding a node.

This is not affecting the solution since before adding a node to the frontier we check if the node has not been visited or is not already in the frontier, but I guess it might be related to those max-depth discrepancies , for example max-depth when doing dfs 1,2,5,3,4,0,6,7,8 ... 66126 or 66125?

Is there a reason why this verification is not done?

Thanks!

title: DFS test case... what is going on?
text:
Hi everyone!



I had done the implementation of both BFS and DFS algorithms for assignment 1.



The test case for BFS works perfect and I tried it with a real 8-puzzle online and the path (sequence of actions) given for that particular puzzle was perfect.



For the DFS one I am finding something strange when comparing my results to the test case... My algorithm finds a better (time-wise not cost wise) and completely different solution (path) than the one in the test case shown which is Up, Left, Left.



My solution is way longer to execute, but I tried it for real on an 8 puzzle I draw and it works! And the DFS algorithm actually found it by just exploring 31 nodes... ??!! Which are actually the 31 steps I have to follow for the solution...



My solution goes depth-first without repeating any given state of the puzzle, but the one in the test case goes back to the third level at some point, that is why it finds a solution at the third level (Up, Left, Left)...

How is that possible? How is it that I am finding the solution of the test case at level 31 after exploring 31 nodes and the test case finds a solution at 3 after exploring 181k nodes? I am following Up, Down, Left, Right priority...

Is it possible that the test case is wrong?

My algorithm finds a better (time-wise not cost wise) and completely different solution (path) than the one in the test case shown which is Up, Left, Left.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>My solution is way longer to execute, but I tried it for real on an 8 puzzle I draw and it works! And the DFS algorithm actually found it by just exploring 31 nodes... ??!! Which are actually the 31 steps I have to follow for the solution...</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>My solution goes depth-first without repeating any given state of the puzzle, but the one in the test case goes back to the third level at some point, that is why it finds a solution at the third level (Up, Left, Left)...</paragraph><paragraph>How is that possible? How is it that I am finding the solution of the test case at level 31 after exploring 31 nodes and the test case finds a solution at 3 after exploring 181k nodes? I am following Up, Down, Left, Right priority...</paragraph><paragraph>Is it possible that the test case is wrong?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text:
Sorry guys...

I read the FAQ for the assignment and found this issue is already handled there.

My implementation had the fringe state as a queue of states objects (a class I created) and not the actual representation of the puzzles, so new states where added regardless if the solution was already on the queue.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Sorry guys...</paragraph><paragraph>I read the FAQ for the assignment and found this issue is already handled there.</paragraph><paragraph>My implementation had the fringe state as a queue of states objects (a class I created) and not the actual representation of the puzzles, so new states where added regardless if the solution was already on the queue.</paragraph></document>

title: Process killed in Vocareum
text:

When running the code in Vocareum, I get the following error code and the run stops: 

../resource/scripts/run.sh: line 3: 28829 Killed        python3 GameManager.py


Any clue as to why the process is killed?



More detail:

This only happens many steps after passing the tile 2048 (but not yet reaching the 4096 tile). I am wondering if this is linked to the depth of search exceeding a threshold due to less breadth of search (less empty tiles, more depth). Or more generally, the stack limit being exceeded.

I reduced the maximum breadth to 12. On my laptop, the maximum breadth reached is usually 6 to 8, so I doubt it reaches 12 on Vocareum but I don't know. Even with 12 as limit, I still get the issue.

Thanks!

title: data structures
text:
Ok so, I found these readings useful, or a good starting point, when trying to implement adequate data structures 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_data_structures

https://docs.python.org/3.6/contents.html

https://wiki.python.org/moin/TimeComplexity
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Ok so, I found these readings useful, or a good starting point, when trying to implement adequate data structures </paragraph><paragraph><link href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_data_structures">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_data_structures</link></paragraph><paragraph><link href="https://docs.python.org/3.6/contents.html">https://docs.python.org/3.6/contents.html</link></paragraph><paragraph><link href="https://wiki.python.org/moin/TimeComplexity">https://wiki.python.org/moin/TimeComplexity</link></paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
These links are great. As for more resources, I'd like to add two books

Introduction to Algorithms, by CLRS: This book has an incredible selection of Data Structures and Algorithms, and is usually used in an Advanced Algorithms class.

https://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Algorithms-3rd-MIT-Press/dp/0262033844

Artificial Intelligence, A Modern Approach: This book is a must have if you are serious about Artificial Intelligence. This book covers so much about AI from classical methods, to probabilistic methods, to RL, NLP and Computer Vision and Robotics. It is a great introduction to the field if you are starting out.

https://www.amazon.com/Artificial-Intelligence-A-Modern-Approach/dp/0134610997/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=artificial+Intelligence&qid=1601913397&s=books&sr=1-3

Hope this helps!

As for more resources, I'd like to add two books</paragraph><list style="bullet"><list-item><paragraph>Introduction to Algorithms, by CLRS: This book has an incredible selection of Data Structures and Algorithms, and is usually used in an Advanced Algorithms class.</paragraph><list style="bullet"><list-item><paragraph><link href="https://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Algorithms-3rd-MIT-Press/dp/0262033844">https://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Algorithms-3rd-MIT-Press/dp/0262033844</link></paragraph></list-item></list></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Artificial Intelligence, A Modern Approach: This book is a must have if you are serious about Artificial Intelligence. This book covers so much about AI from classical methods, to probabilistic methods, to RL, NLP and Computer Vision and Robotics. It is a great introduction to the field if you are starting out.</paragraph><list style="bullet"><list-item><paragraph>https://www.amazon.com/Artificial-Intelligence-A-Modern-Approach/dp/0134610997/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=artificial+Intelligence&qid=1601913397&s=books&sr=1-3</paragraph></list-item></list></list-item></list><paragraph>Hope this helps!</paragraph><list style="bullet"><list-item><list style="bullet"><list-item><list style="bullet"/></list-item></list></list-item></list></document>

title: Anyone working on Mac OS 10.15.5 (Catalina)

Hello there,

I was wondering if anyone is working with Anaconda (Latest version) on Catalina?. I have not been able to install Git yet...Any suggestions?



Cheers

R

answers.text: What trouble are you having?

comments.text:
Hello Tanvi, 



It was just an issue of installing Development Tools, but I got them from the Dev Site :)

title: MemoryError
text:
"MemoryEorror" encountered when trying to convert the result of the vectorizer.fit.transorm() to array (for subsequent passing to SGDClassifier.fit()) .  Understand that it should be due to the huge size of the vocab (118350).

Any hint?

X = vectorizer.fit_transform(corpus)

X = X.toarray() ...................MemoryError
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>"MemoryEorror" encountered when trying to convert the result of the vectorizer.fit.transorm() to array (for subsequent passing to SGDClassifier.fit()) .  Understand that it should be due to the huge size of the vocab (118350).</paragraph><paragraph>Any hint?</paragraph><paragraph>X = vectorizer.fit_transform(corpus)</paragraph><paragraph>X = X.toarray() ...................MemoryError</paragraph></document>

comments.text: Problem solved.  No need to convert toarray().
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Problem solved.  No need to convert toarray().</paragraph></document>

title: Vocareum Walkthrough
text:
Hi,

This is my first time using vocareum. Is it only used for submitting the assignments or can we also write and run the program on vocareum.If yes, i am not getting any run option to execute the code. Can anyone just walk me through this vocareum workbench.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi,</paragraph><paragraph>This is my first time using vocareum. Is it only used for submitting the assignments or can we also write and run the program on vocareum.If yes, i am not getting any run option to execute the code. Can anyone just walk me through this vocareum workbench.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Vocareum is not very intuitive. First time for me as well, but what I figured out is that you can upload the program or files that you want, and you can run them like you would using a terminal on your PC or Mac. You should see a list of files / directory on the left, and a terminal prompt on the right (bottom section). You can basically type python3 xxxx and that would execute the program. You can create folders, rename files, upload files from your computer. 

I hope this helps.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Vocareum is not very intuitive. First time for me as well, but what I figured out is that you can upload the program or files that you want, and you can run them like you would using a terminal on your PC or Mac. You should see a list of files / directory on the left, and a terminal prompt on the right (bottom section). You can basically type python3 xxxx and that would execute the program. You can create folders, rename files, upload files from your computer. </paragraph><paragraph>I hope this helps.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: When you're generating the output.txt file, you'll need to refresh your browser window the first time the file is generated. For every subsequent update you can click on your driver.py file then click back to output.txt to see the update.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>When you're generating the output.txt file, you'll need to refresh your browser window the first time the file is generated. For every subsequent update you can click on your driver.py file then click back to output.txt to see the update.</paragraph></document>

title: When will the Machine Learning course be offered again?
text: I'm really enjoying this course - it's really broad and touches a ton of topics, with very interesting reading assignments to go along. title: psutil has no max memory function
text:
Memory usage measurement is of course optional, but I found that Windows users must install and use psutil (a standard Python library) to get memory usage because the skeleton code's provided "import resource" only works on MacOS / Linux systems. However psutil doesn't have a peak memory measurement function like resource does, so I'd have to use a 3rd party library.

My problem now though is how the instructions imply there's a lot of risk in trying 3rd party libraries:

The FAQ says under Q. (Windows Users) Is there "resource" module in Windows?, "one possible workaround is to use third-party module only if the machine is Windows:"

However this contradicts the lesson instructions which state: "In particular, do not use third-party libraries and packages. We do not guarantee that they will work on the platform, even if they work on your personal computer. For the purposes of this project, everything that comes with the standard Python library should be more than sufficient."

I couldn't find any standard Python libraries that support peak memory measurement for Windows. Because of how strict the lesson instructions are everywhere, I don't feel comfortable trying any 3rd party libraries and risking that the grader errors out on them. Perhaps the lesson could include a supported 3rd party memory library for Windows users that it can guarantee won't fail in the grader?

title: What Python type is recommended for the queue/stack in Assignment 1?
text:
Hello everyone!

I'm using the skeleton code to get started, which imports the queue library.  However, it looks like queue does not allow for a membership test when expanding the frontier.  This means that if I use a queue, I run the risk of inserting the same mode twice.  I'm thinking that it would be better to use a list and treat it as a queue, but not sure about speed and what is industry practice.  Thanks!

I'm thinking that it would be better to use a list and treat it as a queue, but not sure about speed and what is industry practice.  Thanks!</paragraph></document>

title: Is UCS actually a Dijkstra algorithm in disguise?
text:
Hello,

For me the idea of UCS explains how the Dijkstra algorithm for finding the shortest paths works. Am I'm missing something important about UCS method?



Thanks,

Alexander
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello,</paragraph><paragraph>For me the idea of UCS explains how the Dijkstra algorithm for finding the shortest paths works. Am I'm missing something important about UCS method?</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>Thanks,</paragraph><paragraph>Alexander</paragraph></document>

answers.text: They are similar in implementation, but have different goals. UCS is searching for the "goal" state, where Dijkstra is searching for the shortest path to every other node in the graph.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>They are similar in implementation, but have different goals. UCS is searching for the "goal" state, where Dijkstra is searching for the shortest path to every other node in the graph.</paragraph></document>

title: Questions about matrices
text:
Hi,

I have a question about this slide.

Video: 5.4 Linear Models for Regression/ Normal Equation and Gradient Descent

a. I'm not very good with differentiating matrices. In (4), I don't understand where the - (minus) sign comes from. When I calculate, the two minuses from (3) cancel out (-1/n and -X/B) so I end up with a positive sign in (4). Other than the wrong sign, I find the correct equation.

b. I don't really understand why the second derivative indicates that the matrix is positive definite, and why that indicates that B is a minimum.

Thanks for your help!
document: Hi,I have a question about this slide.Video: 5.4 Linear Models for Regression/ Normal Equation and Gradient Descenta. I'm not very good with differentiating matrices. In (4), I don't understand where the - (minus) sign comes from. When I calculate, the two minuses from (3) cancel out (-1/n and -X/B) so I end up with a positive sign in (4). Other than the wrong sign, I find the correct equation.b. I don't really understand why the second derivative indicates that the matrix is positive definite, and why that indicates that B is a minimum.Thanks for your help!

answers.text:
Hi there,

What this really boils down to is differentiating matrices and a little bit of insight on what we are trying to achieve, and if you spend a little bit of time getting comfortable with them, you'll see how the math works out. 

What I am going to do is point you in the right direction. Hopefully if you work through the following two resources, the differentiation of matrices within the context of Least Squares should make more sense. 

The Matrix Cookbook is a good resource that I recommend everyone interested in Machine Learning go through. It will walk you through Matrix operations in general, the section on Second Order Derivatives on page 11 will specifically help you understand the normal equations. If you have time, I recommend skimming through the whole book.

Understanding OLS within the context of Econometrics might be a good idea. This paper lies outside of the scope of our class(because it is related to Econometrics), but the derivation of the normal equation is identical to what we are doing here. Note that the terminology may be slightly different, but the idea is the same.

I really encourage you to work through these two resources on your own, because having a robust understanding of Matrix properties(and a little bit of interdisciplinary knowledge) will go a long way! If you still have some issues after that, we can work through them together.

It will walk you through Matrix operations in general, the section on Second Order Derivatives on page 11 will specifically help you understand the normal equations. If you have time, I recommend skimming through the whole book.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph><link href="https://web.stanford.edu/~mrosenfe/soc_meth_proj3/matrix_OLS_NYU_notes.pdf">Understanding OLS</link> within the context of Econometrics might be a good idea. This paper lies outside of the scope of our class(because it is related to Econometrics), but the derivation of the normal equation is identical to what we are doing here. If you still have some issues after that, we can work through them together. </paragraph></document>

title: How do i make the queue store more than one element?
text:
Hi,

I have a problem that is blocking my BFS search. My frontier queue is only keeping the last element that I add to the queue. 

def bfs_search(initial_state):

    """BFS search"""

    ### STUDENT CODE GOES HERE ###
    'Initialisation of the variables'
    frontier = Q.Queue(maxsize=0)
    frontier.put(initial_state)
    explored = set()
    iterations = 0
    
    'Search loop'
    while not frontier.empty():
        iterations+=1
        print('Queue Status')
        for i in list(frontier.queue):
            print(i.config)
        
        state = frontier.get()
        print('Taken from queue: ',state.config)
        explored.add(state.config)
        if test_goal(state):
            return state
        for neighbour in state.expand():
            if not element_in_queue(neighbour,frontier):
                if not neighbour.config in explored:
                    frontier.put(neighbour)
                    print('Added to queue: ',neighbour.config)
        print('Iteration number: ',iterations)

When I try to add the neighbours that have not been visited yet, even though I get the confirmation that the code has been run and they were added, the queue just has one element which corresponds to the last one to be added. I don't know if i am missing something important in the queue definition but it makes it impossible to run the search as it only keeps one node.

Thank you in advance.

PD: I tested it with a very simple case, where the solution is just 'LEFT'.

'1,0,2,3,4,5,6,7,8'



Effectively the three possible nodes are added to the queue, but when I make the queue.get() I just get the last node added.

comments.text:
After some more investigation I think the problem comes from checking if the element is in the queue or not. If I just check if it is on the explored set it works, but if I  check if it is on the queue it deletes other elements when going through the queue. 

Queues are not iterable, so you can't just say 'If neighbour in frontier'.

answers.text:
Hi, 

It seems that your element_in_queue() method might be modifying the frontier, could you also post the method here so we could take a look?

Additionally, you might want to look at collections.deque for your queue data structure, as it has a count() method, that would allow you check membership of an object in the queue.

Last, an optimization you might look into is having an additional set of configs "configs_added_to_frontier", that would mirror the frontier and allow you O(1) membership checking instead of iterating through the entire queue, which might be sometimes slow.

Suppose the program is executed for depth-first search as follows:

$ python3 driver.py dfs 1,2,5,3,4,0,6,7,8

document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi,</paragraph><paragraph>For DFS in all of <link href="https://learning.edx.org/course/course-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@sequential+block@a1f977f8f5ab4e79a123133a94d77c7e/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@vertical+block@ea497a813e3a43f59c9228a3ada87950">the FAQ examples</link> except the below example <link href="https://learning.edx.org/course/course-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@sequential+block@a1f977f8f5ab4e79a123133a94d77c7e/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@vertical+block@452174b453a84c2a85f61a5dde428993">from the instructions</link>, the max search depth tends to match the total nodes expanded. I'm a bit stumped about how to get the DFS node max search depth in the case where the max depth is 1/3 the total nodes expanded. </paragraph><paragraph>Any hints for how to get this? Thanks!</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph/><paragraph><bold><italic>Example #2: Depth-First Search</italic></bold></paragraph><paragraph><italic>Suppose the program is executed for depth-first search as follows:</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>$ python3 driver.py dfs 1,2,5,3,4,0,6,7,8</italic></paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph><italic>path_to_goal: ['Up', 'Left', 'Left']</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>cost_of_path: 3</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic><bold>nodes_expanded: 181437</bold></italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>search_depth: 3</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic><bold>max_search_depth: 66125</bold></italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>running_time: 5.01608433</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>max_ram_usage: 4.23940217</italic></paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text:
Nevermind, I figured it out. 😶 It took me way too many hours to learn that the skeleton code's "self.cost" in the PuzzleState stores not what I intuitively assumed to be a "path cost" (until I finally checked the values) , -- it's actually the node's depth relative to the initial state node. The lesson's description uses the term "path cost" and is different from the skeleton code's meaning of the term "cost" '. 

The lesson description: "max_search_depth: the maximum depth of the search tree in the lifetime of the algorithm".  While that's true, the skeleton code then refers to "depth" as "cost". To prevent this horrible rabbit hole, I'd suggest making the skeleton code's name or lesson description consistent.

The lesson's description uses the term "path cost" and is different from the skeleton code's meaning of the term "cost" '. </paragraph><paragraph>The lesson description: <italic>"max_search_depth: the maximum depth of the search tree in the lifetime of the algorithm".</italic>  While that's true, the skeleton code then refers to "depth" as "cost". To prevent this horrible rabbit hole, I'd suggest making the skeleton code's name or lesson description consistent.</paragraph></document>

title: A* questions
text:
Hi everyone,

I have two questions about A*.

1) In the lecture and the text, it states that A*'s big drawback is that all nodes are stored in memory.  Why is this?  Aren't nodes popped from the frontier when explored?  I don't see why this search necessarily takes more memory than others.  

2) (Sort of a follow-up to above).  What constitutes a unique node in A*, especially for our project?  Because we are now considering total cost, is a unique node any node with a specific configuration (state) and a unique total cost?  Or does it go deeper, and consider a node to be unique only if configuration, total cost and action to get there are unique?  Along these lines, does the frontier store each unique node, meaning that there might be multiple nodes with the same state, but different in other aspects, such as total cost?  

Thanks!
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi everyone,</paragraph><paragraph>I have two questions about A*.</paragraph><paragraph>1) In the lecture and the text, it states that A*'s big drawback is that all nodes are stored in memory.  Why is this?  Aren't nodes popped from the frontier when explored?  I don't see why this search necessarily takes more memory than others.  </paragraph><paragraph>2) (Sort of a follow-up to above).  What constitutes a unique node in A*, especially for our project?  Because we are now considering total cost, is a unique node any node with a specific configuration (state) and a unique total cost?  Or does it go deeper, and consider a node to be unique only if configuration, total cost and action to get there are unique?  Along these lines, does the frontier store each unique node, meaning that there might be multiple nodes with the same state, but different in other aspects, such as total cost?  </paragraph><paragraph>Thanks!</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
After more programming and solving all the search puzzles :) I have more or less answered my questions, but I wanted to share what I came up with if anyone else has the same questions.

1) A* doesn't store all the nodes in memory, but it stores a lot more since it jumps around according to lowest total cost.

2) A unique node in A* is simply a unique game state.  If the same state comes up twice, we just replace the higher cost with the lower in our frontier (as clearly stated in the UCS lecture, but I had missed that).  

One follow up question though.  I used the heap module in Python for my priority queue, but kept getting errors because Python does not allow duplicate keys in a list.   This came up even after accounting for prioritizing according to UDLR.  To make each key unique, I added a second priority key, which was simply based off a counter that increased for each node as expanded.  It worked and doesn't add much code, but to me it seems a little bit like programmatic duct tape.  I wonder if there is a more eloquent way...  

Thanks!

answers.text:
Hi David,

I suggest using the python heapq module. For it to work, it needs the objects to be comparable, so you'll need to define the "less than" method in your PuzzleState class. It would look something like this:

def __lt__(self, other):
        return (self.some_cost_metric, self.heap_order) < (other.some_cost_metric, other.heap_order)


Note the second comparison value, "heap_order", would be needed to differentiate between two states that have the same cost, but originated from different directions (remember the assignment description says " we always visit child nodes in the "UDLR" order"). 
This way you can add duplicate PuzzleState objects to the heap and be sure they will be differentiated first by the cost, and then by move order. Let me know if you have any other question!

Best,
Nicolae

        return (self.some_cost_metric, self.heap_order) < (other.some_cost_metric, other.heap_order)
Note the second comparison value, "heap_order", would be needed to differentiate between two states that have the same cost, but originated from different directions (remember the assignment description says " we always visit child nodes in the "UDLR" order"). This way you can add duplicate PuzzleState objects to the heap and be sure they will be differentiated first by the cost, and then by move order. Let me know if you have any other question!Best,Nicolae

comments.text:
Hi Nicolae, 

This looks like a more elegant way to sort things.  I have a follow up question for you.  My code does use heapq.  What I had done originally was use cost (number of moves to reach a state) + Manhattan Distance + a nominal value for direction of action (.25 for down, .5 for left, etc), to prioritize the states as per the assignment.  The problem I ran into was that I still had duplicate numbers (3.75 for two different states that both happened to use "right").  My work around of indexing additionally according to when a mode was added to the frontier does work because I put tuples of three values into the heap (total cost, index, puzzle_state).  So I guess my question is, what about those case where the cost metric is identical and the action is identical too?  This throws a key error, unless I use that index work around.

Thanks!



David

title: how many times can we write final exam?
text: if i failed to score 60% in final exam...can i have chance to re write final exam?
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>if i failed to score 60% in final exam...can i have chance to re write final exam?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text:
The final exam can be taken only once. The final exam is only 30% of total grade. Below is the grade policy for the course, 



Grading



Quizzes (20%): There will be 11 quizzes worth 2% each for a total of 20%. The lowest score will be dropped. 



Projects (50%): There will be 5 projects in Python worth 10% each for a total of 50%. All projects count. 



Final Exam (30%): There will be a final exam one week after the last lecture. 



Passing Grade



To pass the course, you must score 60% or above. 

Verified track students must complete the proctor final exam to earn a certificate.

Best,

Adam

title: DFS: I really can't see my error/problem
text:
Hi All,

I really need some enlightenment :)

In my words, DFS is about go all deep possible in one 'branch', all way down, if the solution isn't found, try the next path.

My code does that (allegedly :) ), but my result are completely different from the grade (no surprise).

I'm using this: we always visit child nodes in the "UDLR" order; that is, [‘Up’, ‘Down’, ‘Left’, ‘Right’] in that exact order.

I took couple hours (I'm not good plotting things) and I made graphically what my code is doing. It takes one path and in only 31 steps/expanding it finds the solution for $ python3 driver.py dfs 1,2,5,3,4,0,6,7,8:  (orange: visited, red: repeated)

Could some good soul take a look in the graphic and see what is wrong? (it goes all way down the same branch via visited ones, which means, the next level are the expansion of the visited)

Tks in advance.

You might check the week 2 FAQ for hints. I read it like 10x. 

Also, from your graphic it looks like you may be going in UDLR order which works for BFS but not DFS. Make sure you're stacking the frontier in reverse UDLR order (to do LIFO), and using pop() to take the item from the right end of the queue (i.e. LIFO as shown in the lectures). Python has a reverse() function that can help you reverse the children UDLRs before you add them to the stack. You can then use pop() to take them from the top of the stack (remember the plate example in lecture). 

Print out the steps to terminal to make sure your stack queue is working properly as LIFO.

comments.text:
Hello fer_goldbach!

I was running into the exact same problem as you and found your post. After reviewing both your comments and PDF, I took a look at the FAQ as suggested by others. I was able to find my mistake to go from 31 moves to the answer provided by the example case. See from the FAQ regarding goal states already in the frontier: 



From the FAQ: Combining those two facts reaches to the conclusion: since the goal state is already pushed into frontier (i.e. the state corresponding to ['Up', 'Left', 'Left'] move), any subsequent encounter to the solution state cannot execute frontier.push() or goalTest() and is effectively meaningless. Thus, the dfs algorithm extensively searches through numerous states in 8-puzzle (without putting the solution state into frontier again), gradually goes back to the previously pushed states, and finally find the solution state which is pushed at the very beginning of the search.

def bfs_search(PuzzleState.config,PuzzleState.goal_test):

    """BFS search"""

    ### STUDENT CODE GOES HERE ###
    node = PuzzleState.expand()

    frontier = node.reverse()

    while len(frontier) != 0:
        # if frontier is not empty

        explored.add(state)

            return state

        for PuzzleState.config in state:
            if PuzzleState.config not in explored:

text: To my mind, autonomous cars are going to be available at some time, it will save lives and reduce the cost that the governments pay each year. The problem is, we are not ready yet, because it can not be fully automated while other cars are not. All the cars should be automated to make sure everything will go the right way. For now, we can improve our streets and develop autonomous cars to make it more possible and more reliable on the streets.

title: AStar frontier.decreaseKey seems unclear
text:
Hi,

In the Week 3 lecture for A* Search at minute 4:54 the professor doesn't seem to adequately cover how the frontier.decreaseKey(neighbor) part of the algorithm works, even though there are 2 Oklahoma's added to the frontier (see image below from lecture). In the Week 2 UCS algorithm lectures this decreaseKey isn't covered well either. I'm currently adding every node to the Heap with its self.cost+manhattan_cost as the "Key" for the Heap values (which is the same as g(n)+h(n)). However, to "decrease" this key for a child node, do I need to remove the child node with the lessor "Key" value from the Heap (which if using a list remove function would be O(n) time)? I've been guessing at what "decrease" means so I'm wondering if I can get any hints. :-)

I know I could just try adding duplicate nodes (e.g. 2 "oklahoma" frontier nodes with their key values) to the Heap since they have unique object IDs with keys. The Heap would likely still pick the one with the smallest key value anyway. So the only drawback would be my Heap could grow a little larger when two parents have the same child -- which would use up more memory.

Any ideas? I'm 10 days from receiving my AI textbook in the mail, so I'll check that as well.
Thanks!

Allan

answers.text:
Hi George,

As python's heapq or queue class don't provide decrease key methods, adding duplicates to the priority queue is an acceptable solution, as memory isn't a constraint in this exercise.

If you wanted to minimize space usage, once you find a lower cost path, you can mark as invalid the old higher cost state, and then remove all invalid states from the heap after each iteration.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi George,</paragraph><paragraph>As python's heapq or queue class don't provide decrease key methods, adding duplicates to the priority queue is an acceptable solution, as memory isn't a constraint in this exercise.</paragraph><paragraph>If you wanted to minimize space usage, once you find a lower cost path, you can mark as invalid the old higher cost state, and then remove all invalid states from the heap after each iteration.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: Thanks Nicolae. I found that removing the lower cost child from the heapq each time a duplicate was found didn't have a detrimental effect on performance.

title: python question on updateAlarm() in GameManager.py
document:
Edit: I previously incorrectly tagged this post's subcategory as Assignment 4 (I was think week 4). It's now corrected as Assignment 2 (the 2048 game).Regarding updateAlarm inGameManager.py :
    def updateAlarm(self, currTime):
        if currTime - self.prevTime > timeLimit + allowance:
            self.over = True
        else:
            while time.clock() - self.prevTime < timeLimit + allowance:
                pass

            self.prevTime = time.clock()
What is the purpose of the while loop? It seems to me all that it's doing is stalling and making every turn take 0.25 seconds (timeLimit+allowance), even if computerAI or playerAI took much less time? If that's true, then why have such a statement? Doesn't seem necessary to ensure fairness in Vocareum's grading (which only looks at final score as long as time limit not exceeded).

answers.text:
The computerAI take a lot less time than the playerAI since the moves are just randomly generated. So, it does not take time away from the playerAI to make a move because the algorithm call updateAlarm after the playerAI made the move to see if the playerAI have used more time than allowed. 

Although it is fair, we will look into why it was exactly place in there. We will update you with whatever we find.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The computerAI take a lot less time than the playerAI since the moves are just randomly generated. So, it does not take time away from the playerAI to make a move because the algorithm call updateAlarm after the playerAI made the move to see if the playerAI have used more time than allowed. </paragraph><paragraph>Although it is fair, we will look into why it was exactly place in there. We will update you with whatever we find.</paragraph></document>

title: Is AI a threat to humankind?
text: AI has the potential to be very valuable to humankind, when used correctly. One important point in the development of AI applications is the diversity of people working in these projects, so that we don't have algorithm bias towards a specific group.

title: Minimax algorithm - Tic-Tac-Toe
text:
Hello there,

If I got it correctly, "Minimax algorithm" video states that the total number of nodes of the search tree for Tic-Tac-Toe is 5^9 = 1'953'125. I would expect something different:

Level 1: 9 nodes
Level 2: 9 x 8 = 72 nodes
Level 3: 72 x 7 = 504 nodes
Level 4: 504 x 6 = 3'024 nodes
Level 5: 3'024 x 5 = 15'120 nodes
Level 6: 15'120 x 4 = 60'480 nodes
Level 7: 60'480 x 3 = 181'440 nodes
Level 8: 181'440 x 2 = 362'880 nodes

The sum is 623'530 nodes, but some of them actually don't exist because of premature game endings. So I would definitely expect less than announced 1'953'125. Does it make sense ?

Cheers
Antonin

I would expect something different:</paragraph><paragraph>Level 1: 9 nodes<break/>Level 2: 9 x 8 = 72 nodes<break/>Level 3: 72 x 7 = 504 nodes<break/>Level 4: 504 x 6 = 3'024 nodes<break/>Level 5: 3'024 x 5 = 15'120 nodes<break/>Level 6: 15'120 x 4 = 60'480 nodes<break/>Level 7: 60'480 x 3 = 181'440 nodes<break/>Level 8: 181'440 x 2 = 362'880 nodes</paragraph><paragraph>The sum is 623'530 nodes, but some of them actually don't exist because of premature game endings. So I would definitely expect less than announced 1'953'125. Does it make sense ?</paragraph><paragraph>Cheers<break/>Antonin </paragraph></document>

title: A* hints on how to implement the heap ?
text:
Hello, 

Any hints on how to implement an efficient heap in the A* algorithm ? 

I've used dictionnaries for the queues  and stack in DFS and BFS, but for A*, I'm a bit lost (have to admit)

Regards

Denis.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello, </paragraph><paragraph>Any hints on how to implement an efficient heap in the A* algorithm ? </paragraph><paragraph>I've used dictionnaries for the queues  and stack in DFS and BFS, but for A*, I'm a bit lost (have to admit)</paragraph><paragraph>Regards</paragraph><paragraph>Denis.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
Hi Denis,

I suggest using the python heapq module. For it to work, it needs the objects to be comparable, so you'll need to define the "less than" method in your PuzzleState class. It would look something like this:

def __lt__(self, other):
        return (self.some_cost_metric, self.heap_order) < (other.some_cost_metric, other.heap_order)


Note the second comparison value, "heap_order", would be needed to differentiate between two states that have the same cost, but originated from different directions (remember the assignment description says " we always visit child nodes in the "UDLR" order"). 

Best,

Nicolae
