answers.text:
Hi there,

30 minutes does seem like a lot of time to solve the puzzle. There's a chance that there may be something redundant in your implementation. 

With that said, I want to take this as a chance to go through why you might want to consider not using AC3 to check to see if constraints are being met. 

The thing about AC3 is that it is an algorithm that checks to see if binary constraints are met. Before you decide to adopt AC3 for backtracking, you need to ask yourself this question: in its most intuitive form, are the constraints presented in sudoku binary, or are they some other kind of n-ary constraint?

While you can definitely take an n-ary constraint, and convert to a binary constraint, that process may cost you unnecessary time.

Especially with the way in which the sudoku board is represented, there may be an easier way to enforce constraint satisfaction. Considering this way of going about sudoku may make your code run fast, and it may end up simplifying a lot of code.

Hope that helps!

answers.text:
Your program takes that much time either because of the type of heuristics you used for backtracking or the data structures you used to represent the sudoku / csp.

I implemented the AC3 algorithm so that it can work with my Sudoku class using sets, therefore it ignores repetitions in arcs for example. This example only took 40 seconds to compute with my program.

title: set up a time limit in the IDS
text:
Hi,

I think I have figured out how to implement IDS with fixed maxdepth correctly. On Vocareum it gives 50% 512 and 50% 256 with dumb heuristic of number of available tiles.

Before moving to improve the heuristic, I need to implement a time limit instead of hard depth in the IDS, because I have no idea how much the heuristic functions I want to implement will take and so a hard depth is a bad idea. I saw there was another post on this called "Time Limit..." by @burricks.

I implemented something similar to @burricks :

depth = 1
while not timesup:
    find solution with current depth
    depth += 1
    updateTime()

def updateTime:
    timesup = True if current time - init time > timelimit
    

The problem with this is that the time of each depth increases exponentially. So let's say at depth 4, my time difference is << the limit of 0.2 (say 0.05), I go into depth 5 and that time difference is now 0.7. The 5th depth search actually finishes and the search is halted by the while loop, but once the result goes to the game manager it is halted it took  >0.2.

Here are my questions:
1- do we even allow the 5th depth to start if we know for instance that it will blow through the time. By that I mean should the time limit be enforced inside the search function as well or should we halt before calling the 5th depth?

2- Is there a better way to do this time update.



Thank you
document:
Hi,I think I have figured out how to implement IDS with fixed maxdepth correctly. On Vocareum it gives 50% 512 and 50% 256 with dumb heuristic of number of available tiles.Before moving to improve the heuristic, I need to implement a time limit instead of hard depth in the IDS, because I have no idea how much the heuristic functions I want to implement will take and so a hard depth is a bad idea. I saw there was another post on this called "Time Limit..." by @burricks.I implemented something similar to @burricks :
depth = 1
while not timesup:
    find solution with current depth
    depth += 1
    updateTime()

def updateTime:
    timesup = True if current time - init time > timelimit
The problem with this is that the time of each depth increases exponentially. So let's say at depth 4, my time difference is << the limit of 0.2 (say 0.05), I go into depth 5 and that time difference is now 0.7. The 5th depth search actually finishes and the search is halted by the while loop, but once the result goes to the game manager it is halted it took >0.2.Here are my questions:1- do we even allow the 5th depth to start if we know for instance that it will blow through the time. By that I mean should the time limit be enforced inside the search function as well or should we halt before calling the 5th depth?2- Is there a better way to do this time update.Thank you

answers.text: As you'd want the solution to be independent of the CPU speed, you can't just stop before exploring depth=5, as you don't really know when it will time out. I'd suggest passing the time to the search function, as it's more granular, and there you could say "if timeLeft() < smallDelta then return current solution". The delta will ensure that you will return the value you want and the code won't just time out.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>As you'd want the solution to be independent of the CPU speed, you can't just stop before exploring depth=5, as you don't really know when it will time out. I'd suggest passing the time to the search function, as it's more granular, and there you could say "if timeLeft() < smallDelta then return current solution". The delta will ensure that you will return the value you want and the code won't just time out.</paragraph></document>

title: Prob 3: "Precision is ill-defined" error
text:
Hi, 

Has anyone else run into this and solved it?

\sklearn\metrics_classification.py:1221: UndefinedMetricWarning: Precision is ill-defined and being set to 0.0 in labels with no predicted samples. Use zero_division parameter to control this behavior. _warn_prf(average, modifier, msg_start, len(result))

I'm using the sklearn GridSearchCV function, and feeding it a parameter grid to run through the 3 SVM Kernal examples, then using Sklearn's classification_report function to report the results.

I've read some threads online about it which seem to indicate it's not an issue, but I'm wondering whether it should be expected for this assignment (e.g. this one, and this one). "You're not doing anything wrong. These metrics include the number of predictions of a class in the denominator so they divide by zero in this case. The NN, for some of your workloads, just never predicts that class. You could ensure that there are plenty of examples of that class in the training set. Apart from that all you can do is choose to report F and precision only when there are plenty of samples in the test set."

title: Generating strong association rules: What is (l - C)?
text:
Hi, I don't understand this rule:  (l − C) → C

Can you provide an example for this? 

What does the "−" sign means?

On the same page, can you please explain further (based on the lecture example) the calculations to determine if a rule is strong or not?

Thanks!
document: Hi, I don't understand this rule: (l − C) → CCan you provide an example for this? What does the "−" sign means?On the same page, can you please explain further (based on the lecture example) the calculations to determine if a rule is strong or not?Thanks!

answers.text:
l is a frequent set and C is a proper subset of l.

l - C is the set generated by removing subset C from l.

Example:

l = ab

C = b

l - C = a

Therefore, (l - C) --> C is:

a --> b

Because a, b, and ab are item sets, we can calculate supp(a), supp(b), and supp(ab). Therefore we can calculate:

conf(a --> b) = supp(ab) / supp(a)

That's how you fill out the Confidence column of the chart above.

Whether it is strong or not just depends on the chosen MinConf.

I don't know the methods for choosing a good MinConf though.



Hope that helps!

Therefore we can calculate:</paragraph><paragraph>conf(a --> b) = supp(ab) / supp(a)</paragraph><paragraph>That's how you fill out the Confidence column of the chart above.</paragraph><paragraph>Whether it is strong or not just depends on the chosen MinConf.</paragraph><paragraph>I don't know the methods for choosing a good MinConf though.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>Hope that helps!</paragraph></document>

title: Informing Informed Search Agents
text: This lecture series prompts me to think about the applications of informed search agents.  For instance, Google Maps; how often information is updated to ensure the best possible route when looking for directions.  Google maps offers street views and with how often landscaped can change in this country--or in other parts of the world--due to development, re-development, natural disasters, etc.; it is necessary for Google to shoot as often as possible various locations to maintain visual accuracy. On their website, they post a map detailing the places that they have been ( https://www.google.com/streetview/explore/ ) and the schedule of their next locations.  I am becoming aware of the amount of work that goes into preparing data AI technologies such as visual recognition, recommender systems, and, of course, search agent.  Data quality is imperative in this respect to ensure optimal performance of any AI applications that incorporate some of the aforementioned technologies.

We read in the csv like in the other two problems, but should it go into a list of lists[feature 1, feature 2, label], or does the label need to be separated?  For splitting the data into test and training sets, where is the information on how to do that in this extensive user guide?  Thanks!

title: Heuristics + Alpha-Beta pruning
text:
Hello, 

I am really struggling getting the utility function to drive the miinmax algorithm. I have tried various different options for the utility function, including sorting the children of getChildren based on the utility. I have been working on this assignment for the past 3 weeks (par- time but stil over 80hrs investedl..d) and read every single post on this forum, plus multiple of those available on stackoverflow, towardsdatascience, etc.

It might be that my max and min functions are not pruning correctly? I am really not sure but I only got my PlayerAI to score a max tile value of 128 (see below) with depth = 4. I have not tried submitting in Vocareum yet.

I would be extremely grateful if someone could provide some tips as to what I am doing wrong or could improve. 

Thanks a lot! 

These are my maximise and minimise functions:

def maximise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int, int]:

        """
        This is the max method representing PlayerAI from the minimax algorithm takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a: alpha from α-β pruning
        b: beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth
        returns: a tuple of the form (maxChild, maxUtility, move), where:
                    maxChild is the children of the current grid object (in the minimax algorithm tree) 
                    that maximizes the utility, and 
                    maxUtility is the utility value of maxChild game grid.
                    move is the move of the child object
        """
        # at the beginning we set maxUtility to (-sys.maxint - 1) and maxChild to None
        (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (None, MIN_INT, -1)

        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        d -= 1

        #if no children are generated, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            return (maxChild, maxUtility, -1)

        # iterate on children to find child with minimum  utility value
        for _, child, dir in self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            move = dir
            #get the utility of the minimise method on the child grid
            (_, utility) = self.minimise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility > maxUtility:
                (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (child, utility, dir)
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility >= b:
                break
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility > a:
                a = maxUtility
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)



    def minimise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int]:

        """
        This is the min method from the minimax algorithm representing the ComputerAI player
        and takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a: alpha from α-β pruning
        b: beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth

        returns: a tuple of the form (minChild, minUtility), where:
                    minChild is the children of the current grid object (in the minimax algorithm tree) 
                    that minimises the utility, and 
                    minUtility is the utility value of minChild game grid.
        """

        # at the begining we set minUtility to the max it can be ('MAX_INT') and minChild to None
        (minChild, minUtility) = (None, MAX_INT)
        
        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        d -= 1
        
        # no children are obtained, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            return (minChild, minUtility)
        
        # iterate on children to find child with minimum utility value
        for _, child in self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            (_, utility, _) = self.maximise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility < minUtility:
                (minChild, minUtility) = (child, utility)
                return (minChild, minUtility)
            if minUtility <= a:
                return (minChild, minUtility)
                break
            if minUtility < b:
                b = minUtility
                return (minChild, minUtility)

This is my getChildren function, which varies depending on whether we are trying to get the children of max player or the children of min player. For min player, we get the possible configurations of the min player when throwing in the tiles '2' or '4' on any empty cells:

    def getChildren(self, grid, minmax: str) -> Tuple[int, Grid, int]:
        """gets all children and the moving directions for max player
           gets all empty cells and attempts new tiles configurations for "2" and "4" for min player
        """
        children = []
        moving = []
        scores = []

        if minmax == "max":
            for direction in grid.getAvailableMoves():
                #clone the current grid here to avoid loosing it after .move()
                gridcopy = grid.clone()
                #move method returns True if moved and makes the change to gridcopy itself
                moved = gridcopy.move(direction)
                if moved == True:
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    moving.append(direction)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            evaluated = list(zip(scores, children, moving))
            sorted(evaluated, key=lambda x: x[0])
            return evaluated
        if minmax == "min":
            for cell in grid.getAvailableCells():
                #insert a new tile "2" and "4" in empty cell to cover this posibility
                for tile in (2,4):
                    #clone the grid object first 
                    gridcopy = grid.clone()
                    gridcopy.insertTile(cell, tile)
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            evaluated = list(zip(scores, children))
            sorted(evaluated, key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True)
            return evaluated

This is my utility function to evaluate how good or bad the grid layout is. I have tried different heuristics and applied weights to them after normalising them with log10 :



    def utility(self, grid: Grid) -> int:
        """
        This method evaluates “how good” our game grid is by calculating:
        how many tiles of same value,
        how close to each other,
        highest tile,
        number of non-zero elements.
        """
        #how many tiles are non-zero
        count = 0
        #sum all the tiles which are non-zero
        sum = 0
        #list of all tile values
        tileval = []
        #count number of cells with adjacent values being same
        adjCellCount = 0
        adjCellValues = [1]
        #clone the current grid to avoid modifying after using .move() on it
        gridCopy = grid.clone()
        #establish weights for each heuristics
        w1 = 4
        w2 = 1
        w3 = 2
        w4 = 10

        for i in range(grid.size):
            for j in range(grid.size):
                sum += grid.map[i][j]
                tileval.append(grid.map[i][j])
                if grid.map[i][j] != 0:
                    count += 1
                    for m in range(1):
                        #store gridCopy after move to pass same grid layout to getCellValue, i, j
                        x = gridCopy.move(m)
                        adjCellValue = gridCopy.getCellValue((i + x, j + x))
                        #compare gridCopy after move to the previous grid
                        if adjCellValue == grid.map[i][j] * 2:
                            adjCellCount += 1
                            adjCellValues.append(adjCellValue)
                        score = (m, adjCellCount, adjCellValues)
                        #clone the current grid to avoid modifying after using .move() on it
                        gridCopy = grid.clone()
        max_tile = max(max(tileval, key= tileval.count), 1)
        tilemedian = max(self.middle(tileval), 1)
        max_adjCellCount = max(score[2])
        adjCellCount = max(adjCellCount, 1)
        return int(w1 * math.log10(sum/count) + w2 * math.log10(tilemedian) + w3 * math.log10(max_tile) + w4 * math.log10(adjCellCount + max_adjCellCount))
        

Finally, this is the function that passes the move to GameManager.py:

def getMove(self, grid: Grid, depth: int = 4) -> int:
         timeLimit = 0.2
         prevTime = time.process_time()
         while time.process_time() - prevTime < timeLimit:
            (child, utility, bestmove) = self.maximise(grid, MIN_INT, MAX_INT, depth)
            print("utility: ", utility, sep=' ')
            print("bestmove: ", bestmove, sep=' ')
            return bestmove

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Best,

Maria

I spent 80-100 hours on this assignment too. This is the most poorly designed assignment I've come across -- this is my 4th computer science MOOC. I'd just see what you can do to wrap it up and move on. The later assignments are easier and will average out your course score.

This assignment lacks basic sanity checks or assistance to help establish whether students have bug-free minimax code and/or any hints to make it work in places where it diverges from the book/lecture. Heuristics are also vastly more complex than the lesson suggests.

answers.text:
After a few hours spent researching strategies for playing the 2048 game, including having my husband paying it himself for quite some time ;), I have managed to improve the heuristics to give 512 max tile value. I have also cleaned the code a bit to make it easier to read and a bit faster. 

Spending time in coming up with the right heuristics does pay off. I never got it to pass the 64 threshold just with the alpha-beta pruning alone. I think the assignment documents are misleading on that front. The heuristics need to be way more sophisticated than just the average tile value or median of the tile values. They really need to 'draw a strategy' for playing the game.T

Either way, in case anyone is feeling a bit lost (as I was), here is the code I have written for the PlayerAI.py. It is also available on GitHub here: https://github.com/mariamingallonMM/AI-SearchAlgorithm-A2-2048puzzle. Note that I have modified GameManager.py from that provided in the assignment to include for selenium to run the game on a html page. It is work-in-progress though as explained in the docs.

from BaseAI import BaseAI
from typing import Tuple, List
from Grid import Grid
from sys import maxsize as MAX_INT
import math
import time
from itertools import chain


class PlayerAI(BaseAI):

    global MIN_INT, timeLimit
    MIN_INT = -MAX_INT - 1
    timeLimit = 0.2

       
    def getChildren(self, grid: Grid, minmax: str) -> Tuple[int, Grid, int]:
        """gets all children and the moving directions for max player
           gets all empty cells and attempts new tiles configurations for "2" and "4" for min player
        """
        children, moving, scores = ([] for _ in range(3))

        if minmax == "max":
            for direction in grid.getAvailableMoves():
                #clone the current grid here to avoid loosing it after .move()
                gridcopy = grid.clone()
                #move method returns True if moved and makes the change to gridcopy itself
                moved = gridcopy.move(direction)
                if moved == True:
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    moving.append(direction)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            return sorted(list(zip(scores, children, moving)), key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True)
        if minmax == "min":
            for cell in grid.getAvailableCells():
                #insert a new tile "2" and "4" in empty cell to cover this posibility
                for tile in (2,4):
                    #clone the grid object first 
                    gridcopy = grid.clone()
                    gridcopy.insertTile(cell, tile)
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            return sorted(list(zip(scores, children)), key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=False)


  
    def utility(self, grid: Grid) -> int:
        """
        This method evaluates “how good” our game grid is by using the following heuristics:
        # value of topleft corner tile
        # max tile value
        # sum of all tiles
        # sum of first column
        # how many tiles are zeros
        # max tile is at topleft corner
        # second max tile are near topleft corner
        """
        #clone the current grid to avoid modifying after using .move() on it
        gridCopy = grid.clone()
        
        #establish weights for each heuristics
        w1 = 100000 #value of topleft corner tile
        w2 = 10 #max tile value
        w3 = 0 #sum of all tiles divided by non-empty tiles
        w4 = 0 #sum of first column
        w5 = 100 #how many tiles are zeros
        w6 = 100000 #max tile is at corner

        weigths = [w1, w2, w3, w4, w5, w6]

        ## Define heuristics used:

        topleft_corner = int(grid.map[0][0])    #value of top left corner
        tileval = tuple(chain.from_iterable(grid.map))  #max tile value
        sum = int(math.fsum(tileval))   #sum value of all tiles which are non-zero
        max_tile = max(list(tileval))   #sum of tiles in first column
        max_sum_col1 = grid.map[0][0] + grid.map[1][0] + grid.map[2][0] + grid.map[3][0] #sum of tiles in first column
        count_0 = len([x for x in list(tileval) if x == 0]) #how many tiles are zero
        max_tile_topleft_corner = 0 #max tile is at corner, start with '0'
        if int(grid.map[0][0]) == int(max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner = 1
        #second max tile is near the corner
        list(tileval).remove(int(max_tile))
        second_max_tile = max(tileval)
        if int(grid.map[1][0]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        if int(grid.map[0][1]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        #second max tile is near corner
        if int(grid.map[0][1]) and int(grid.map[1][0]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        #if int(grid.map[0][1]) == int(second_max_tile):
        #    max_tile_topleft_corner += 1

        heuristics = [topleft_corner, max_tile, sum // (16 - count_0), max_sum_col1, count_0, max_tile_topleft_corner]

        return int(math.fsum([a * b for a, b in zip(weigths, heuristics)]))
    
    def maximise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int, int]:

        """
        This is the max method representing PlayerAI from the minimax algorithm takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a, b: alpha and beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth (how many games ahead we let the AI algorithm see and evaluate)
        returns: a tuple of the form (maxChild, maxUtility, move), where:
                maxChild: is children of current grid object (in minimax algorithm tree) that maximizes the utility, 
                maxUtility: is the utility value of maxChild game grid, and
                move: is the move of the child object.
        """
        # at the beginning we set maxUtility to (-sys.maxint - 1) and maxChild to None
        (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (None, MIN_INT, -1)

        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        d -= 1 #reduce depth recursively until d == 0 to generate the children

        #if no children are generated, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            return (maxChild, maxUtility, -1)

        # iterate on children to find child with minimum  utility value
        for _, child, dir in self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            move = dir
            #get the utility of the minimise method on the child grid
            (_, utility) = self.minimise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility > maxUtility:
                (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (child, utility, dir)
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility >= b:
                break
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility > a:
                a = maxUtility
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)

    def minimise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int]:

        """
        This is the min method from the minimax algorithm representing the ComputerAI player and takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a, b: alpha and beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth (how many games ahead we let the AI algorithm see and evaluate)

        returns: a tuple of the form (minChild, minUtility), where:
                minChild is children of current grid object (in the minimax algorithm tree) that minimises the utility, and 
                minUtility is the utility value of minChild game grid.
        """

        # at the begining we set minUtility to the max it can be ('MAX_INT') and minChild to None
        (minChild, minUtility) = (None, MAX_INT)
        
        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        d -= 1
        
        # no children are obtained, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            return (minChild, minUtility)
        
        # iterate on children to find child with minimum utility value
        for _, child in self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            (_, utility, _) = self.maximise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility < minUtility:
                (minChild, minUtility) = (child, utility)
                return (minChild, minUtility)
            if minUtility <= a:
                return (minChild, minUtility)
                break
            if minUtility < b:
                b = minUtility
                return (minChild, minUtility)


    def getMove(self, grid: Grid, depth: int = 20) -> int:

        """
        Gets the best move for PlayerAI for a given:
        grid: an object of the class Grid
        depth: the depth of the tree to generate, how many games ahead does PlayerAI see to take decision
        returns:
            bestmove: an integer from [0,1,2,3] indicating whether to move ["UP", "DOWN", "LEFT","RIGHT"]
            depending on the resulting best move from applying minimax method
        """
        # get time for time limit of PlayerAI move
        prevTime = time.process_time()

        while time.process_time() - prevTime < timeLimit:
            (child, utility, bestmove) = self.maximise(grid, MIN_INT, MAX_INT, depth)
            print("Utility: ", utility, sep=' ', end='\n')
            print("Bestmove: ", bestmove, sep=' ', end='\n')
            return bestmove
answers.document:
After a few hours spent researching strategies for playing the 2048 game, including having my husband paying it himself for quite some time ;), I have managed to improve the heuristics to give 512 max tile value. I have also cleaned the code a bit to make it easier to read and a bit faster. Spending time in coming up with the right heuristics does pay off. I never got it to pass the 64 threshold just with the alpha-beta pruning alone. I think the assignment documents are misleading on that front. The heuristics need to be way more sophisticated than just the average tile value or median of the tile values. They really need to 'draw a strategy' for playing the game.TEither way, in case anyone is feeling a bit lost (as I was), here is the code I have written for the PlayerAI.py. It is also available on GitHub here: https://github.com/mariamingallonMM/AI-SearchAlgorithm-A2-2048puzzle. Note that I have modified GameManager.py from that provided in the assignment to include for selenium to run the game on a html page. It is work-in-progress though as explained in the docs.
from BaseAI import BaseAI
from typing import Tuple, List
from Grid import Grid
from sys import maxsize as MAX_INT
import math
import time
from itertools import chain


class PlayerAI(BaseAI):

    global MIN_INT, timeLimit
    MIN_INT = -MAX_INT - 1
    timeLimit = 0.2

       
    def getChildren(self, grid: Grid, minmax: str) -> Tuple[int, Grid, int]:
        """gets all children and the moving directions for max player
           gets all empty cells and attempts new tiles configurations for "2" and "4" for min player
        """
        children, moving, scores = ([] for _ in range(3))

        if minmax == "max":
            for direction in grid.getAvailableMoves():
                #clone the current grid here to avoid loosing it after .move()
                gridcopy = grid.clone()
                #move method returns True if moved and makes the change to gridcopy itself
                moved = gridcopy.move(direction)
                if moved == True:
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    moving.append(direction)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            return sorted(list(zip(scores, children, moving)), key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=True)
        if minmax == "min":
            for cell in grid.getAvailableCells():
                #insert a new tile "2" and "4" in empty cell to cover this posibility
                for tile in (2,4):
                    #clone the grid object first 
                    gridcopy = grid.clone()
                    gridcopy.insertTile(cell, tile)
                    children.append(gridcopy)
                    scores.append(self.utility(gridcopy))
            return sorted(list(zip(scores, children)), key=lambda x: x[0], reverse=False)


  
    def utility(self, grid: Grid) -> int:
        """
        This method evaluates “how good” our game grid is by using the following heuristics:
        # value of topleft corner tile
        # max tile value
        # sum of all tiles
        # sum of first column
        # how many tiles are zeros
        # max tile is at topleft corner
        # second max tile are near topleft corner
        """
        #clone the current grid to avoid modifying after using .move() on it
        gridCopy = grid.clone()
        
        #establish weights for each heuristics
        w1 = 100000 #value of topleft corner tile
        w2 = 10 #max tile value
        w3 = 0 #sum of all tiles divided by non-empty tiles
        w4 = 0 #sum of first column
        w5 = 100 #how many tiles are zeros
        w6 = 100000 #max tile is at corner

        weigths = [w1, w2, w3, w4, w5, w6]

        ## Define heuristics used:

        topleft_corner = int(grid.map[0][0])    #value of top left corner
        tileval = tuple(chain.from_iterable(grid.map))  #max tile value
        sum = int(math.fsum(tileval))   #sum value of all tiles which are non-zero
        max_tile = max(list(tileval))   #sum of tiles in first column
        max_sum_col1 = grid.map[0][0] + grid.map[1][0] + grid.map[2][0] + grid.map[3][0] #sum of tiles in first column
        count_0 = len([x for x in list(tileval) if x == 0]) #how many tiles are zero
        max_tile_topleft_corner = 0 #max tile is at corner, start with '0'
        if int(grid.map[0][0]) == int(max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner = 1
        #second max tile is near the corner
        list(tileval).remove(int(max_tile))
        second_max_tile = max(tileval)
        if int(grid.map[1][0]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        if int(grid.map[0][1]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        #second max tile is near corner
        if int(grid.map[0][1]) and int(grid.map[1][0]) == int(second_max_tile):
            max_tile_topleft_corner += 1
        #if int(grid.map[0][1]) == int(second_max_tile):
        #    max_tile_topleft_corner += 1

        heuristics = [topleft_corner, max_tile, sum // (16 - count_0), max_sum_col1, count_0, max_tile_topleft_corner]

        return int(math.fsum([a * b for a, b in zip(weigths, heuristics)]))
    
    def maximise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int, int]:

        """
        This is the max method representing PlayerAI from the minimax algorithm takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a, b: alpha and beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth (how many games ahead we let the AI algorithm see and evaluate)
        returns: a tuple of the form (maxChild, maxUtility, move), where:
                maxChild: is children of current grid object (in minimax algorithm tree) that maximizes the utility, 
                maxUtility: is the utility value of maxChild game grid, and
                move: is the move of the child object.
        """
        # at the beginning we set maxUtility to (-sys.maxint - 1) and maxChild to None
        (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (None, MIN_INT, -1)

        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid), -1)
        d -= 1 #reduce depth recursively until d == 0 to generate the children

        #if no children are generated, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            return (maxChild, maxUtility, -1)

        # iterate on children to find child with minimum  utility value
        for _, child, dir in self.getChildren(grid, "max"):
            move = dir
            #get the utility of the minimise method on the child grid
            (_, utility) = self.minimise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility > maxUtility:
                (maxChild, maxUtility, move) = (child, utility, dir)
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility >= b:
                break
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)
            if maxUtility > a:
                a = maxUtility
                return (maxChild, maxUtility, move)

    def minimise(self, grid: Grid, a: int, b: int, d: int)-> Tuple[Grid, int]:

        """
        This is the min method from the minimax algorithm representing the ComputerAI player and takes the following parameters:
        grid: is an object of the Grid class
        a, b: alpha and beta from α-β pruning
        d: maximum allowed depth (how many games ahead we let the AI algorithm see and evaluate)

        returns: a tuple of the form (minChild, minUtility), where:
                minChild is children of current grid object (in the minimax algorithm tree) that minimises the utility, and 
                minUtility is the utility value of minChild game grid.
        """

        # at the begining we set minUtility to the max it can be ('MAX_INT') and minChild to None
        (minChild, minUtility) = (None, MAX_INT)
        
        if not grid.canMove():
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        if d == 0:
            return (None, self.utility(grid))
        d -= 1
        
        # no children are obtained, stop here
        if not self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            return (minChild, minUtility)
        
        # iterate on children to find child with minimum utility value
        for _, child in self.getChildren(grid, "min"):
            (_, utility, _) = self.maximise(child, a, b, d)
            if utility < minUtility:
                (minChild, minUtility) = (child, utility)
                return (minChild, minUtility)
            if minUtility <= a:
                return (minChild, minUtility)
                break
            if minUtility < b:
                b = minUtility
                return (minChild, minUtility)


    def getMove(self, grid: Grid, depth: int = 20) -> int:

        """
        Gets the best move for PlayerAI for a given:
        grid: an object of the class Grid
        depth: the depth of the tree to generate, how many games ahead does PlayerAI see to take decision
        returns:
            bestmove: an integer from [0,1,2,3] indicating whether to move ["UP", "DOWN", "LEFT","RIGHT"]
            depending on the resulting best move from applying minimax method
        """
        # get time for time limit of PlayerAI move
        prevTime = time.process_time()

        while time.process_time() - prevTime < timeLimit:
            (child, utility, bestmove) = self.maximise(grid, MIN_INT, MAX_INT, depth)
            print("Utility: ", utility, sep=' ', end='\n')
            print("Bestmove: ", bestmove, sep=' ', end='\n')
            return bestmove

title: From Association Rules: Why is ABD not an itemset consideration?
text:
This is a picture taken from the slides in Lecture 7.3 Association Rules. Per the title, in Itemset C3, why is abd not included as an itemset to check the support for?

Thanks!
document: This is a picture taken from the slides in Lecture 7.3 Association Rules. Per the title, in Itemset C3, why is abd not included as an itemset to check the support for?Thanks!

answers.text:
Notice that in C2, supp(ad) is less than the MinSupp.

ad is a subset of abd.

By support downward closure we know that if ad is not frequent then abd is not frequent (contrapositive of the stated rule). Therefore, it's not a candidate

It's kinda confusing but this is stated explicitly in formula given to produce the Candidate list:

Ck is the set of sets (ck, supp(ck)) such that for all X which are the proper subsets of ck, X != Null and supp(X) >= MinSupp

In this case, we are considering abd as the ck. ab is X and it fails the second condition of Supp(ab) >= MinSupp. Therefore we don't include abd in the candidate set.

Pardon the terrible formatting. I tried to figure out LaTex but failed miserably.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Notice that in C2, supp(ad) is less than the MinSupp.</paragraph><paragraph>ad is a subset of abd.</paragraph><paragraph>By support downward closure we know that if ad is not frequent then abd is not frequent (contrapositive of the stated rule). Therefore, it's not a candidate</paragraph><paragraph>It's kinda confusing but this is stated explicitly in formula given to produce the Candidate list:</paragraph><paragraph>Ck is the set of sets (ck, supp(ck)) such that for all X which are the proper subsets of ck, X != Null and supp(X) >= MinSupp</paragraph><paragraph>In this case, we are considering abd as the ck. ab is X and it fails the second condition of Supp(ab) >= MinSupp. Therefore we don't include abd in the candidate set.</paragraph><paragraph>Pardon the terrible formatting. I tried to figure out LaTex but failed miserably.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: So every possible 2 item set that is a component of a 3 item set needs to satisfy the minimum support? Even if, in the case of abd, it can be created by ab and bd which both satisfy the minimum support.

title: About what can and can't be used in assignments

So this is a question related to all assignments, not only the first one, but I'll take the first assignment as an example. Esteban.

I have checked my normalized data and looks the same as this post, so I would think it is OK. Also, running my code 10000 times seems to converge for alpha 0.005 as show in image below:

I just saw this other post, and there are some people with the same issue and same results, so it seems a recurrent problem.

Thanks!

title: Question for course staff
text:
Hallo, I've just enrolled the course but I don't think I'll be able to complete it for the scheduled date (I'm 1 month and a half late!).

Is there any possibility to repeat the course in some other dates?

Or is there the possibility to try the exams in other dates?

This is because I've to decide if to upgrade to verified track paying or not what is requested!

Thank you...

answers.text:
Hi, 

Welcome to join the AI course. I am curious if you have any experience with AI or ML topics and have you done any coding before. We had statistics supporting that there are learners passing the course even enrolling late (i.e w8-w12). However, each person has different amount of prior experience and resources (i.e study time). 

If you are confident with the topics in this course, I think it is still doable. However, if you are new to the topic, I'd suggest you to take the chance to watch the videos and start with the project preview. The advantage of upgrading now is you have a lot of learning tips shared by the cohorts. You can use that to tackle the assignments. We also have learners enrolling more than one time because it gives them more time studying and working on the assignments. 

Our course will be offered again next Spring starting in early February. You are very welcomed to join us again. Please let us know if you have any other questions. 

Thank you. 



Best, 

Shu-Yi

title: Can we be more exact with notations?
text:
Hi everyone,

Would like to request some help in understanding notations in some of the lessons. In particular I'm looking at the week 7's assignment, which took me some time to understand:

The second equation portraits how to update the beta weights. I was very intrigued to see 

$$x_i$$

both as f's input and as well being multiplied at the end. After all, x_i is a vector, so how would beta get a vector as result?

After some research and some time digging in the interwebs I always able to find: https://ic.unicamp.br/~sandra/pdf/class/2019-2/mc886/2019-08-14-MC886-Linear-Regression.pdf, which better specifies that the last x_i being multiplied is actually the jth feature of the ith row of the feature matrix.

Is that correct? Could we try to be more precise with notations? That would improve understanding for us. Also, the lesson did not give any practical numerical example of that.

Best,

Leal
document: Hi everyone,Would like to request some help in understanding notations in some of the lessons. In particular I'm looking at the week 7's assignment, which took me some time to understand:The second equation portraits how to update the beta weights. I was very intrigued to see x_iboth as f's input and as well being multiplied at the end. After all, x_i is a vector, so how would beta get a vector as result?After some research and some time digging in the interwebs I always able to find: https://ic.unicamp.br/~sandra/pdf/class/2019-2/mc886/2019-08-14-MC886-Linear-Regression.pdf, which better specifies that the last x_i being multiplied is actually the jth feature of the ith row of the feature matrix.Is that correct? Could we try to be more precise with notations? That would improve understanding for us. Also, the lesson did not give any practical numerical example of that.Best,Leal

comments.text:
yes, that is correct.

the gradient descent algo "descends" one dimension at a time. the assignment copied the course notifications where there was one 2 betas, one of them was the intercept (and corresponding xi were 1). I think the objective of the assignment is precisely to make you think about it.

Note: you can replace all these "forall j" equations below, with one matrix multiplication.

$$\forall j,\ \beta_j\ :=\beta_j\ -\alpha\frac{1}{n}\sum(f(x_i) - y_i)x_i$$
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>yes, that is correct.</paragraph><paragraph>the gradient descent algo "descends" one dimension at a time. the assignment copied the course notifications where there was one 2 betas, one of them was the intercept (and corresponding xi were 1). I think the objective of the assignment is precisely to make you think about it.</paragraph><paragraph>Note: you can replace all these "forall j" equations below, with one matrix multiplication.</paragraph><math>\forall j,\ \beta_j\ :=\beta_j\ -\alpha\frac{1}{n}\sum(f(x_i) - y_i)x_i</math></document>

answers.text:
Yeah, that formula can be improved, for instance, i goes from 1 to n, since the index is used to iterate over all the examples (there is no example 0 as far as i know).

Also, the last term x_i lacks of an index, should be x_{ij} as Leal is saying. It also took me some time to figure it out.

Which I also think is not clear is "update all betas simultaneously". First beta will use the current weights to calculate the predicted labels when updating it, second beta will use the just updated weight with first beta? or we should use the initial weight vector while updating all the betas?

I guess this kind of things produce small discrepancies between our results and Vocarerum as indicated in this post

answers.text:
Hi everyone, 

I echo the messages on this post. The notation should be clarified in the assignment materials or a post by the Instructors to everyone clarifying it all. 

In case it helps anyone who is feeling as lost as I was on this assignment (specifically on problem2.py), I have included below a couple of links that really helped me. I have found them very useful to understand what was going on with the different notations and in particular understanding where beta_0 comes from. 

Youtube video explaining difference between single feature and multivariate by Intrigano

Multivariate Linear Regression from Scratch in Python by Lope.AI

Multivariate Linear Regression in Python Step by Step by Rashida Nasrin Sucky

Gradient Descent in Python by Sagar Mainkar

Implement Gradient Descent in Python by Rohan Joseph

Best,

Maria

title: AC3: what is "- { Xj }" in Xi.NEIGHBORS - { Xj }
text:
Hi, the lecture "Constraint Propagation" doesn't explain the "- { Xj }" part in AC3's line that contains for each Xk in Xi.NEIGHBORS - { Xj } do.

Is this just saying to remove the Xj value from the set of Xi's neighbors? For example, if Xi == 'A2' and its neighbor set is therefore {'A1', 'A3',...'A9'...'B2', 'C2'...} and Xj == 'A9', would it just be a removal of 'A9' from Xi's set? Or, is it saying to do Xi's neighbors but remove Xj's neighbors from the resulting set?
document: Hi, the lecture "Constraint Propagation" doesn't explain the "- { Xj }" part in AC3's line that contains for each Xk in Xi.NEIGHBORS - { Xj } do.Is this just saying to remove the Xj value from the set of Xi's neighbors? For example, if Xi == 'A2' and its neighbor set is therefore {'A1', 'A3',...'A9'...'B2', 'C2'...} and Xj == 'A9', would it just be a removal of 'A9' from Xi's set? Or, is it saying to do Xi's neighbors but remove Xj's neighbors from the resulting set?

answers.text:
Hi there,

The former of what you said is correct: you are just to remove XJ from the set of XI's neighbors. The notation presented:

$$X_ineighbors\ -\ \left\{X_j\right\}$$

Just indicates set difference: you are subtracting the latter(as a set) from the former. 



Hope this helps!
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi there,</paragraph><paragraph>The former of what you said is correct: you are just to remove XJ from the set of XI's neighbors. The notation presented:</paragraph><math>X_ineighbors\ -\ \left\{X_j\right\}</math><paragraph>Just indicates set difference: you are subtracting the latter(as a set) from the former. </paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>Hope this helps!</paragraph></document>

comments.text: Thanks! This helped. I just removed the single neighbor Xj from the set of neighbors returned for Xi.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Thanks! This helped. I just removed the single neighbor Xj from the set of neighbors returned for Xi.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

title: Question from video 9.7 in Iteration Method for finding optimal policy.
text:
From the image above, when we are evaluating the change to 'fast action' in the standing state, the instructor uses the value vector based on the slow policy. My interpretation of the equation (which leads to the 1.48 total) is you take the immediate reward of the fast action, then add the 'discounted value' of the policy by using the probability vector of the fast policy in conjunction with the values vector of the slow policy. Why do we not use an updated value vector that accounts for the policy taking the fast action in the moving state?



Thank you in advance!
document: From the image above, when we are evaluating the change to 'fast action' in the standing state, the instructor uses the value vector based on the slow policy. My interpretation of the equation (which leads to the 1.48 total) is you take the immediate reward of the fast action, then add the 'discounted value' of the policy by using the probability vector of the fast policy in conjunction with the values vector of the slow policy. Why do we not use an updated value vector that accounts for the policy taking the fast action in the moving state?Thank you in advance!

answers.text: We don't update yet the vector to account for a new action in the moving state as this is only our first iteration, and we have to start somewhere. After we computed the first iteration for a state and we found a better policy, we can then update the value vector for further iterations.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>We don't update yet the vector to account for a new action in the moving state as this is only our first iteration, and we have to start somewhere. After we computed the first iteration for a state and we found a better policy, we can then update the value vector for further iterations.</paragraph></document>

document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Could someone please explain the logic behind this question?  I answered incorrectly, but there was no explanation as to what this diagram represented or how to interpret it.  Thanks!</paragraph></document>

answers.text: That's the truth table for a boolean function f(a, b). Where the first 2 columns are the the possible input and the last one is the corresponding truth value. For example if f = a AND b, f(0, 1) = 0, f(1, 1) = 1.

title: Vocareum 1st row/line fails
text:
Hi,

I've passed every puzzle but the very first sudoku line, which is one that AC3 solves successfully in my local IDE. I think Vocareum or my code is off by the very first 1 row or something?

Input board string: 00302060......5010300

My IDE output string: 483921.....17382 AC3

I checked all rows and columns, and they're all different.

Any idea why this could be?
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi,</paragraph><paragraph>I've passed every puzzle but the very first sudoku line, which is one that AC3 solves successfully in my local IDE. I think Vocareum or my code is off by the very first 1 row or something?</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Input board string:</bold> 00302060......5010300</paragraph><paragraph><bold>My IDE output string:</bold> 483921.....17382 AC3</paragraph><paragraph>I checked all rows and columns, and they're all different.</paragraph><paragraph>Any idea why this could be?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text:
I figured it out. In my code for generating the output.txt, I set an open() parameter as "a" for append, so when I submitted my work, it also submitted my /work/ folder's output.txt file to the grader's directory and when the grader ran it'd just append to it instead of overwriting.

Because I'd do a test "Run" before submitting, I'd always have the 1st line occupied with the BTS test run instance, and so my code would then in Line 1 just append the successful AC3 string to the end of the test BTS string. This caused the Line 1 to fail the grader.

I resolved it by deleting the "output.txt" from my  /work/ folder before submitting. I hope this helps anyone else who runs into this. Perhaps my code could be better, or the submission process could be improved to exclude the local output.txt file.

title: Backpropagation Algorithm typo?
text:
Hi everyone.

I was watching the Neural network lecture, Backpropagation algorithm section. The thing is that in the Backpropagation rules, when the notation is being explained, it's defined:

$$z_j=\sum_i w_{ij}x_j$$

And all the results are derived with this, but the sum shouldn't include also the feature vector components? As it is x_j is not summed. I think it should be written as:

$$z_{j } = \sum_i w_{ij}x_i$$

Or maybe I'm missing something?

Thanks.

Esteban.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi everyone.</paragraph><paragraph>I was watching the Neural network lecture, Backpropagation algorithm section. The thing is that in the Backpropagation rules, when the notation is being explained, it's defined:</paragraph><math>z_j=\sum_i w_{ij}x_j</math><paragraph>And all the results are derived with this, but the sum shouldn't include also the feature vector components? As it is x_j is not summed. I think it should be written as:</paragraph><math>z_{j } = \sum_i w_{ij}x_i</math><paragraph>Or maybe I'm missing something?</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks.</paragraph><paragraph>Esteban.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
Hi there,

You've noticed something quite interesting, but I think a little bit of clarification will help you work this one out.

What $w_{ij}$ represents is the directed, weighted connection from neurons $x_i$ to $x_j$. Therefore,

$$z_j\ =\ \sum_i^{ }w_{ij}x_j$$

represents the weighted sum of all inputs going into $x_j$. If you were to replace the aforementioned formula with

$$\sum_i^{ }w_{ij}x_i$$

Then you'd be finding the weighted sum of outputs from $x_i$ to all of its connections(all of the $x_j$s). That isn't quite what we are doing here as we are interested in the inputs going into neuron $x_j$ to pass into our threshold function.



Hope that helps
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi there,</paragraph><paragraph>You've noticed something quite interesting, but I think a little bit of clarification will help you work this one out.</paragraph><paragraph>What $w_{ij}$ represents is the directed, weighted connection from neurons $x_i$ to $x_j$. Therefore,</paragraph><math>z_j\ =\ \sum_i^{ }w_{ij}x_j</math><paragraph>represents the weighted sum of all inputs going into $x_j$. If you were to replace the aforementioned formula with</paragraph><math>\sum_i^{ }w_{ij}x_i</math><paragraph>Then you'd be finding the weighted sum of <bold>outputs</bold> from $x_i$ to all of its connections(all of the $x_j$s). That isn't quite what we are doing here as we are interested in the inputs going into neuron $x_j$ to pass into our threshold function.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>Hope that helps</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Thanks you very much! This helped me a lot!

Esteban.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Thanks you very much! This helped me a lot!</paragraph><paragraph>Esteban.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
I think I found the point of conflict, and i think is just a matter of notation. If $z_{j}$ represents in fact the weighted sum of inputs into $x_{j}$, then according to the notation provided by the lecture, $z_{j}$ reads as:

$$z_j = \sum_i w_{ij} x_{ij}$$

Meaning that in the lectures equation the first subscript of x, which represents from where the input comes from, is ignored to make notation shorter.

If $z_{j}$ represents in fact the weighted sum of inputs into $x_{j}$, then according to the notation provided by the lecture, $z_{j}$ reads as:</paragraph><math>z_j = \sum_i w_{ij} x_{ij}</math><paragraph>Meaning that in the lectures equation the first subscript of x, which represents from where the input comes from, is ignored to make notation shorter.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Assignment complete means #2 of what you've mentioned. All variables should have a value and no constraint should be violated.

The input to order domain values depends on the kind of ordering logic you want to go with. You may opt to collapse both variable selection and domain ordering into one, along with forward checking or AC3 - there is really no hard and fast rule for this. It depends on your problem situation.

title: my AC3 isn't able to completely solve any of the puzzles from sudokus_start.txt
document:
Does that mean it's implemented wrong? For example, for the 2nd line from sudokus_start.txt, after my AC3 runs, the domains for the X's were reduced, some to only 1 element. But the largest of the domains still had 3. Here are a few examples from my domains:
position(row,col), {domain}
(4, 0), {3}
(3, 4), {9}
(5, 4), {9, 4}
(0, 2), {5}
I got the sameresult on local and vocareum. My question is, can different (correct) implementations of AC3 result in different results (in terms of whether the puzzle is solved by AC3)?

answers.text:
Turns out to be a bug in my Find Neighbor code, in which I used the "queue of arcs" to find the neighbors.  So I was looking for neighbor arcs from within the same queue I was trying to add to, therefore never finding anything to add.

So it seems the answer to my last question in the original post is No - different but correct implementations of AC3 should result in the same solved-or-not conclusion for the same puzzle.

answers.text:
Hi there, 

To be honest, you really don't even need to implement AC3 here: I actually think that AC3 is an unnatural choice for sudoku because the algorithm operates purely on binary constraints. Before you pull the trigger on implementing AC3, you should ask yourself if sudoku requires binary constraints to be satisfied, or some other kind of n-ary constraint. Depending on the answer to your question, you should be able to come up with your own domain-restricting algorithm that may be easier to implement. Your domain-restricting algorithm with backtracking search would be able to solve the problem

title: Graph Axes
text:
Hello everyone,

Could someone please explain what are the axes of the perceptron graph in lecture 6.1?  What is the horizontal axis measuring and what is the vertical measuring?  This would really help me in understanding.  (I just finished the Perceptron project successfully, and would like to try to matplotlib optional assignment, but am not sure how to get started.). Thanks!
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello everyone,</paragraph><paragraph>Could someone please explain what are the axes of the perceptron graph in lecture 6.1?  What is the horizontal axis measuring and what is the vertical measuring?  This would really help me in understanding.  (I just finished the Perceptron project successfully, and would like to try to matplotlib optional assignment, but am not sure how to get started.). Thanks!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

answers.text:
As far as I understand:

In general the axes are the features. If we have one feature, let's call it X, we can have the label Y described with a linear function like f(X) = Y = betaX. We can also have another weight for it like Y = beta0 + beta1X. 

Having one feature means we can plot the label in the same graph with X and Y in the horizontal and vertical coordinates.

Having 2 features (X1, X2) will create a hyperplane, since we have an extra dimension. X1 in the horizontal and X2 in the vertical coordinates, then the hyperplane will be in the 3D space like in the image above:

Having more features will lead us to a multidimensional space which is hard to visualize.

Hope that helps, and please, if I'm wrong I'll appreciate your updates.



Best!

title: What does INFERENCE(csp, var, value) returns?
text:
Hi,

I'm confused with the backtracking search, perhaps somebody can help me to understand it better.

I understand that the INFERENCE method uses Forward Checking or a version of AC-3 in order to reduce the domain of the variable (var before the for loop) we are currently reviewing right?

But, what does INFERENCE returns? I think a tuple inferences = (boolean, list) where boolean is False if while reducing domains we got an empty one, and list contains those domains with a single value? Are those single values the ones that are added to assignment in the 8th line of the BACKTRACK method?

Am I right with my assumptions?

Thanks!
document: Hi,I'm confused with the backtracking search, perhaps somebody can help me to understand it better.I understand that the INFERENCE method uses Forward Checking or a version of AC-3 in order to reduce the domain of the variable (var before the for loop) we are currently reviewing right?But, what does INFERENCE returns? I think a tuple inferences = (boolean, list) where boolean is False if while reducing domains we got an empty one, and list contains those domains with a single value? Are those single values the ones that are added to assignment in the 8th line of the BACKTRACK method?Am I right with my assumptions?Thanks!

comments.text:
Hi igopepra,

You are right indeed about the the Inference method reducing variable domain.

About the return type it is a boolean, if "False" is returned then the algorithm won't pursue this path since it violates the constraints, consequently the preceding if is also exited and the for each loop gets the next value , but if "True" is returned then the algorithm will go one more recursion level deeper carrying on with the inferred value since no constraints were violated.

Hope that helps

comments.text: Thanks Ahmed. So inferences will return a single value?

answers.text:
Hi there,

The pseudo-code is purposefully vague to allow the reader to implement the algorithm in whatever way they are most comfortable with. There are no mentioned of the kind of data structures to use. This is up to the reader to decide.

I just want to write in to clarify that the actual data structure that inferences use is pretty irrelevant, so long as that choice is well-informed. When I implemented backtracking, I chose a dictionary to represent the further constrained domains of my inferences , but that shouldn't really matter.

title: some notes on CSP and BTS
text:
Hi,

I would like to share a bit my experience with the CSP assignment. I found myself very confused during this assignment, even after I went through the lectures and the handouts several times. In the end I had to go to the text book, and I don't think I could have done the assignment without it. In particular, read the section Backtracking for CSPs in the book (6.3 in my version). 

Here are a few notes I hope will be of help to others:

1- the SELECT-UNASSIGNED-VARIABLE. This function needs to implement to Minimum-remaining-value heuristic, and the output needs to be sorted according to this heuristic. The book explains well why is that, but in short, when we start with the variables with the smallest domain, we get to prune the tree more, and failures will be detected quickly.

2- Order-DOMAIN-VALUE. This function needs to implement a least-constraint-heuristic, meaning that the values of the selected values above, should prune the neighbours of that variables the least. This gives an advantage in case we want to find the first solution and terminates, instead of finding all solutions. In the case of sudoku there is one solution anyway, so it does not matter.

3- INFERENCE. INFERENCE is just a way to prune the neighbours of a selected variable. The case be done via Forward Checking. The book says that if the arcs are already consistent, Forward Checking will not do anything, and here is what I still don't understand. Which I don't understand. If we make an assignment to a non assigned variable (ie its domain is still not of size 1), there must be opportunities to prune the neighbours using Forward Checking.  Can someone please explain what I am getting wrong?

So in my program I ran the AC3 algorithm, which is an overkill. But, I wasn't that much off. Indeed, the book says to implement the MAC algorithm, which is AC3 but with arcs being the unassigned variables only that are neighbours to the selected variables.



That's most of it. I think the lecture can be more detailed, or at least make requirement to read the CSP chapter in the AI a modern approach book. I hope this is helpful.

But, I wasn't that much off. Indeed, the book says to implement the MAC algorithm, which is AC3 but with arcs being the unassigned variables only that are neighbours to the selected variables.</paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>That's most of it. answers.text:
[EDIT: There are some serious problems with my answer below. I've italicized problem paragraphs]

Hi Anton,

I'll try to answer your question about the redundancy of forward checking in the case of having already reached arc consistency.

The forward checking suggested in the book is, as you said, running AC-3 on a subset of all arcs in the CSP. Specifically, the arcs involving the variable in question and its neighbors.

Arc consistency is achieved by running AC-3 on all the arcs in the CSP. If we reach arc consistency and then run forward checking, we will be checking arcs that have already been considered and made consistent by exactly the same algorithm. Therefore, it's redundant.

I'm going to take a guess about what's confusing you and try to address that, please correct me if I'm wrong or just ignore what follows:

You mention "making an assignment to a non assigned variable" and then running forward checking. I'm guessing you're thinking that, because we make an assignment before checking, we are constraining the problem more and should be able to make more inferences.

However, consider the nature of arc consistency. Namely, for an arc (X1, X2) it is consistent iff all the values of X1 have some value of X2 for which they are consistent. I.e. the arc (X1, X2), if consistent, is consistent for all the values of X1, so when the algorithm assigns a value to X1 we know that value is consistent already and forward checking won't tell us anything else.

Hope that helps.

Mark

Specifically, the arcs involving the variable in question and its neighbors.</italic></paragraph><paragraph><italic>Arc consistency is achieved by running AC-3 on all the arcs in the CSP. If we reach arc consistency and then run forward checking, we will be checking arcs that have already been considered and made consistent by exactly the same algorithm. Therefore, it's redundant.</italic></paragraph><paragraph>I'm going to take a guess about what's confusing you and try to address that, please correct me if I'm wrong or just ignore what follows:</paragraph><paragraph>You mention "making an assignment to a non assigned variable" and then running forward checking. I'm guessing you're thinking that, because we make an assignment before checking, we are constraining the problem more and should be able to make more inferences.</paragraph><paragraph>However, consider the nature of arc consistency. Namely, for an arc (X1, X2) it is consistent iff <bold>all</bold> the values of X1 have some value of X2 for which they are consistent. I.e. the arc (X1, X2), if consistent, is consistent for all the values of X1, <italic>so when the algorithm assigns a value to X1 we know that value is consistent already and forward checking won't tell us anything else.</italic></paragraph><paragraph>Hope that helps.</paragraph><paragraph>Mark</paragraph></document>

title: Timing of adjusting betas in linear regression
text:
Hi Everyone, 

I'm getting a 36/50 with betas being the culprit, but in a random way that's hard to discern what is wrong.  I am updating betas simultaneously with temporary variables, but I might be updating at the wrong point.  I am updating at the end of each iteration (of the 100 iterations) and not after each element.  

Also, I used statistics.mean and statistics.stdev for scaling, but I'm seeing that there may be a different stdev called population standard deviance.  What is the difference?

Thanks!

I am updating betas simultaneously with temporary variables, but I might be updating at the wrong point.  I am updating at the end of each iteration (of the 100 iterations) and not after each element.  </paragraph><paragraph>Also, I used statistics.mean and statistics.stdev for scaling, but I'm seeing that there may be a different stdev called population standard deviance.  What is the difference?</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text: Just an update - I was calculating the betas correctly - for others'  edification the error was two-fold.  1) not understanding that in Python stdev just takes a sample and makes an estimate of standard deviation, whereas population stdev takes it from the entire population and 2) a typical bug of miscoding one index in that same calculation.  Now it's 50/50!  :)

Now it's 50/50!  :)</paragraph></document>

title: Project Assignment 3 (Week 7) - FAQ would be useful
text:
In the Week 2 and Week 4 Project assignments, there are FAQ pages to review and respond many useful and critical questions to validate the ultimate solution. This has given the students opportunity to seriously challenge ourselves to improve our logical thinking about the problem. It has greatly enhanced my ability to grasp the elegant problem solving techniques in Python and strive for the best solution. 

From the discussions in the FAQ page, being a relatively novice Python programmer, I have learnt a lot to push my code to perform at the topmost level. In the past few days I have immersed myself in the problem understanding, repeatedly going back to lectures to fish out the exact knowledge required to build the steps for the solution. Being the first-time AI learner and having some prior knowledge about data science and ML, I come across multitudes of what-if scenarios, which play around in my thoughts. These thoughts need additional support from such FAQ discussions to converge to solution.  

I believe if the instructors and examiners provide FAQ for Project Assignment 3 (Week 7) to help students look for real-life programming pitfalls that we should also be learning to avoid in our real life too. Also, by choosing the best possible native Python libraries and methods and technique, we can sharpen our skills to stand up for any data science, ML and AI challenge   in future.

Browser/Server related issues:

Unable to reach the server(such as internal server errors)

Site going down:

Unable to access certain parts of EdX or EdX even if they are made public on our end.

Other miscellaneous, IT-related questions.

Course staff

title: Do you really need to use AC3 for Backtracking?
text:
Hi everyone,

First off, I hope you guys are having fun with the course. You guys are doing a great job! With that said, however, I'm starting to see that a lot of people are beginning to struggle with AC3 for their implementation of the sudoku solving program. What I want you guys to ask yourselves is this: do you really need to use AC3 to solve sudoku puzzles?

Remember, AC3 operates on binary constraints. 

Ask yourself if sudoku deals with binary constraints or some other kind of constraint. Keep in mind that once you make a variable assignment in sudoku, you can immediately make reductions in the domain of the variable's neighbors. Does each variable have only one neighbor, or does it have several?

Now, while you can technically convert an n-ary constraint to a set of binary constraints to then use AC3, that process might get hairy and involved; you might need to put in more elbow grease than necessary. Can you instead come up with your own, sudoku specific way of reducing domains? Can you leverage the data structure used to implement the board to your favor in this sudoku-specific implementation of domain-reduction? Remember, the backtracking algorithm presented in the course doesn't specifically ask to use AC3, it just asks to make an inference of some kind.

By questioning this basic assumption about the algorithm you are using within BTS, you might be able to come up with a far easier solution to implement.

Remember guys, engineering is all about making assumptions about your problem, and then acting as though all those assumptions are wrong.

Good Luck!

Can you leverage the data structure used to implement the board to your favor in this sudoku-specific implementation of domain-reduction? Remember, the backtracking algorithm presented in the course doesn't specifically ask to use AC3, it just asks to make an inference of some kind.</paragraph><paragraph>By questioning this basic assumption about the algorithm you are using within BTS, you might be able to come up with a far easier solution to implement.</paragraph><paragraph>Remember guys, engineering is all about making assumptions about your problem, and then acting as though all those assumptions are wrong.</paragraph><paragraph>Good Luck!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Hi Ashvin, we can use Forward Checking, but why bother to code more if we already have coded the AC-3 as requested in the first part of the assignment. Given that, it makes sense to use it in the inference method right?.

Norvig's book explains how to do it:

The algorithm called MAC (for Maintaining Arc Consistency (MAC)) detects this inconsistency. After a variable Xi is assigned a value, the INFERENCE procedure calls AC-3, but instead of a queue of all arcs in the CSP, we start with only the arcs (Xj , Xi ) for all Xj that are unassigned variables that are neighbors of Xi . From there, AC-3 does constraint propagation in the usual way, and if any variable has its domain reduced to the empty set, the call to AC-3 fails and we know to backtrack immediately. We can see that MAC is strictly more powerful than forward checking because forward checking does the same thing as MAC on the initial arcs in MAC’s queue; but unlike MAC, forward checking does not recursively propagate constraints when changes are made to the domains of variables.

Given that, it makes sense to use it in the inference method right?.</paragraph><paragraph>Norvig's book explains how to do it:</paragraph><paragraph><italic>The algorithm called MAC (for Maintaining Arc Consistency (MAC)) detects this inconsistency. After a variable Xi is assigned a value, the INFERENCE procedure calls AC-3, but instead of a queue of all arcs in the CSP, we start with only the arcs (Xj , Xi ) for <bold>all Xj that are unassigned variables that are neighbors of Xi</bold> . From there, AC-3 does constraint propagation in the usual way, and if any variable has its domain reduced to the empty set, the call to AC-3 fails and we know to backtrack immediately. We can see that MAC is strictly more powerful than forward checking because forward checking does the same thing as MAC on the initial arcs in MAC’s queue; but unlike MAC, forward checking does not recursively propagate constraints when changes are made to the domains of variables.</italic></paragraph></document>

Hope that helps

No. I completed week 11's project, and it's all about applying NLP, which its own lecture material covers adequately. The Week 11 project's FAQ shows what tools you'll be using primarily. Everything you need for week 11 is in week 11.

pandas.read_csv(filename, encoding = "ISO-8859-1")


sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer

sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfTransformer

sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer

sklearn.linear_model.SGDClassifier

title: Some extra notes for CSP: AC-3 and BTS
text:
Finally, I finish my CSP implementation and I can tell it was the most difficult one up to now. It is not that complex, the problem is the pseudo-code algorithms, which I find vague and open to many assumptions.

I'm ok assuming things but I think it is needed to provide extra info.

Note: Please be aware I'm not an expert, and my assumptions might not be accurate. I just want to share them to help others that might be confused like I was.

Assignments vs Domains: Assignment data structure stores the variables and a single value assigned to them. Domains is another data structure holding the possible values a variable can have. Both are related and should be synchronized meaning if we have assigned variable C3 = 4 then Domains[C3] = [4]. I  would say you can use a single data structure but the pseudo-code for both algorithms treat them as 2 separate parameters (assignment and csp["DOMAINS"] - if you choose a dictionary)

Arcs: What is an arc? a tuple of 2 variables (Xi, Xj), both related through a constraint (in this case !=). Since the AllDiff constraints work at row, col, and box level we need to transform  each one of them to binary constraints (AC-3 receives a binary CSP). For sudoku I got 1620 arcs.

Neighbours: What is a neighbour for variable X? In general neighbours are all variables  that are related to X through all of the constraints. I got 20 neighbours per sudoku variable.

Arc consistency with AC-3: AC-3 returns True if every arc in the CSP is arc consistent. Returns False if not, meaning the CSP can not be solved (there is at least one variable with an empty domain). When checking consistency it is helpful to think in terms of tail and head: An arc (tail, head) applies the constraint from tail -> head. When we find an inconsistent value we remove it from the tail

Assignments in BTS: The pseudo-code for BTS indicates assignment starts like an empty dictionary, but since we have already used AC-3 in the first part of the assignment it makes sense to me to use the reduced domains as input for BTS.

What is INFERENCE(csp, var , value)?: It is a procedure that calls Forward Checking or another method to determine if it is possible to reduce the domain for neighbour variables (neighbours of X, which is the variable BTS is currently analyzing). We can use FC or AC-3 to do this, since we already have coded AC-3 I found it obvious to use it. Artificial Intelligence A Modern Approach book calls it MAC and explains how to do it. A very important thing to take into account is the need to restore original values for assignment and domains if the variable/value used led us to a dead-end or an inconsistent CSP! Probably this is the hardest part to accomplish.

I guess that's all.

Hope you find it useful!
