When checking consistency it is helpful to think in terms of tail and head: An arc (tail, head) applies the constraint from tail -> head. When we find an inconsistent value we remove it from the tailAssignments in BTS: The pseudo-code for BTS indicates assignment starts like an empty dictionary, but since we have already used AC-3 in the first part of the assignment it makes sense to me to use the reduced domains as input for BTS.What is INFERENCE(csp, var , value)?: It is a procedure that calls Forward Checking or another method to determine if it is possible to reduce the domain for neighbour variables (neighbours of X, which is the variable BTS is currently analyzing). We can use FC or AC-3 to do this, since we already have coded AC-3 I found it obvious to use it. Artificial Intelligence A Modern Approach book calls it MAC and explains how to do it. A very important thing to take into account is the need to restore original values for assignment and domains if the variable/value used led us to a dead-end or an inconsistent CSP! Probably this is the hardest part to accomplish.I guess that's all.Hope you find it useful!

comments.text:
Sorry if I'm not an instructor, but this might help you:

Can I have some pre-processed files (like my own version of stopwords/vocabulary) in the folder submission? Or shall I create all that I need on the fly?

I finished the assignment, and got near full points even when using the project's own default stopwords.en.txt file. I didn't use my own or any other stopwords. Perhaps you could try your own, but their stopwords file works sufficiently well I think. I just tested my score using the default stopwords provided by the assignment, versus using Python's own 'english' stopwords, and my score went down 5 points when using the 'english' stopwords.

So in a nutshell, your score may actually be +5 points better within the grader's criteria if you use assignment's stopwords and refine based on those.

Can I have the trained model saved and load it for the test prediction and output files creation?

The instructions say to generate all files at run-time, and so this probably means everything including the training of the model has to happen at run-time in Vocareum (i.e. no local files will help). I trained my model on whatever files are in the Vocareum ../resource/lib/publicdata/ folders.

The driver.py skeleton code is this, and the 2 paths are in it:

train_path = "../resource/lib/publicdata/aclImdb/train/" # use terminal to ls files under this directory
test_path = "../resource/lib/publicdata/imdb_te.csv" # test data for grade evaluation


def imdb_data_preprocess(inpath, outpath="./", name="imdb_tr.csv", mix=False):
     '''Implement this module to extract
    and combine text files under train_path directory into 
    imdb_tr.csv. Each text file in train_path should be stored 
    as a row in imdb_tr.csv. And imdb_tr.csv should have two 
    columns, "text" and label'''
    pass
  
if __name__ == "__main__":
     '''train a SGD classifier using unigram representation,
    predict sentiments on imdb_te.csv, and write output to
    unigram.output.txt'''
      
    '''train a SGD classifier using bigram representation,
    predict sentiments on imdb_te.csv, and write output to
    bigram.output.txt'''
     
     '''train a SGD classifier using unigram representation
     with tf-idf, predict sentiments on imdb_te.csv, and write 
     output to unigramtfidf.output.txt'''
      
     '''train a SGD classifier using bigram representation
     with tf-idf, predict sentiments on imdb_te.csv, and write 
     output to bigramtfidf.output.txt'''
     pass

title: tautologies Week 10 Self-Check Questions
text:
Hi,

in the Week 10 Self-Check Questions Q2: why is the first a tautology?



The first formula is:

$$\left(x\wedge\left(x\longrightarrow y\right)\right)\ \Leftrightarrow\ \left(x\wedge\left(-x\vee y\right)\right)\ \Leftrightarrow\left(x\wedge-x\right)\vee\left(x\wedge y\right)\Leftrightarrow x\wedge y$$

That's does not imply $y$ . Did I misunderstand something?
document: Hi,in the Week 10 Self-Check Questions Q2: why is the first a tautology?The first formula is:\left(x\wedge\left(x\longrightarrow y\right)\right)\ \Leftrightarrow\ \left(x\wedge\left(-x\vee y\right)\right)\ \Leftrightarrow\left(x\wedge-x\right)\vee\left(x\wedge y\right)\Leftrightarrow x\wedge yThat's does not imply $y$ . Did I misunderstand something?

comments.text: You might check out the Reduced Wumpus World video at minute 6:00.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>You might check out <link href="https://learning.edx.org/course/course-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@sequential+block@1d7724a994fe440c8cc5d17fe902a674/block-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020+type@vertical+block@e70e470f776d4f06bf039c5c55083763">the Reduced Wumpus World video</link> at minute 6:00.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text: Also check Theorem Proving and Proof by Resolution video starting at 1:20. It's the modus ponens inference rule. "X implies Y and X is true, therefore Y must be true.". See the truth table on modus ponens.
comments.document: Also check Theorem Proving and Proof by Resolution video starting at 1:20. It's the modus ponens inference rule. "X implies Y and X is true, therefore Y must be true.". See the truth table on modus ponens.

comments.text: thanks. my bad. I guess, I was thinking in terms of equivalence, not implication.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>thanks. my bad. I guess, I was thinking in terms of equivalence, not implication.</paragraph></document>

answers.text: A tautology is a logic statement that has a "TRUE" value for any assignment of the variables, which holds for the first one.

A. Yes. You might find the following functions are useful (note that there are other ways/functions to do the same task):

pandas.read_csv(filename, encoding = "ISO-8859-1")

sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer

sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfTransformer

sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfVectorizer

sklearn.linear_model.SGDClassifier

title: Self-Check Question 2
text:
The answer to this question is 16 according to "Show Answer":



But it seems to me 16 is wrong on multiple levels. First, dimension of a 2 (or higher) dimensional matrix is not a single number, but the answer seems to be the product of the row and column dimensions, i.e. 4x4. Second, my understanding is that it should be a 2x2 matrix, and is independent of number of actions, since a particular policy would only dictate 1 action at any given state.

title: test vocabulary for bigram
text:
Hi,

In order for the fitted SGC Classifier to predict the test sample, I had the test countvectorizer function use the vocabulary that was given by the training countvectorizer. That worked well in the unigram and I am getting 23-24/25.

When I do the bigram, the instructions is too add the bigram to the unigram, and when using the same method, it seems to work fine as well. However, I can't help thinking that when the vocabulary is made of bigrams, the vocabulary is then made of a two words list, and so the filtering of the test test must be done at an earlier stage, so that we filter the words that were not used in the training first, instead of filtering whole couple of words. But if I do that, the language really stops making sense.

So the question, do we filter the test text before using the count vectorizer? or do we do it using the vocab attribute like I explained above. And what is the best way to do this? Using for loops takes for ever.

title: A Question regarding the time and space complexity of the Uniform Cost Search (USC)
text:
In the lecture, the teacher mentioned that the time and space complexity (big O) is b to the power of C_star divided by epsilon.

However, in the reference book written by Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig, the writers stated that the time and space complexity is b to the power of one plus C_star divided by epsilon.

Where does this "plus 1" come from? And Why is it not : when all action costs are equal, UCS is "exactly like"?
document: In the lecture, the teacher mentioned that the time and space complexity (big O) is b to the power of C_star divided by epsilon.However, in the reference book written by Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig, the writers stated that the time and space complexity is b to the power of one plus C_star divided by epsilon.Where does this "plus 1" come from? And Why is it not : when all action costs are equal, UCS is "exactly like"?

title: BTS never returning a solution
text:
Hi,

I have managed to do an AC3 algorithmthat works. However, when I do the BTS algorithm it basically never returns a success.

The result is the same every time ([]). I don't know if I am missing something. 

My check_constraints function is fairly simple. I store the cells that have and have not been assigned, and remove the values that have been assigned from the domains of the cells in conflict.



    def check_constraints(self):
        for cell_1 in self.not_assigned_cells:
            for cell_2 in self.assigned_cells:
                if self.is_constrainted(cell_1,cell_2):
                    if self.state[cell_2] in self.domain[cell_1]: 
                        self.domain[cell_1].remove(self.state[cell_2])
                if not self.domain[cell_1]: return False                   
        return True




My BTS algorithm follows the structure of the lessons:



    def Backtrack(self):
        temp_sudoku = deepcopy(self)
        if not temp_sudoku.not_assigned_cells: return temp_sudoku
        assigned_cell = temp_sudoku.Select_cell()
        cell_domain = temp_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell]
        temp_sudoku.assigned_cells.add(assigned_cell)
        temp_sudoku.not_assigned_cells.remove(assigned_cell)
        
        for cell_value in cell_domain:
            # Assign var
            temp_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell] = [cell_value]
            temp_sudoku.state[assigned_cell] = cell_value
            # Check
            check_assignment =  temp_sudoku.check_constraints()
            if check_assignment:
                result = temp_sudoku.Backtrack()
                if result: return result        
        return []




I am trying to run the first case of the txt, but the result is a failure. If you have any idea on how to fix this, it would really help. 

Best regards.

Raul

EDIT: QUESTION SOLVED

The problem was that the sudoku needs to be copied inside the loop. and not before. If someone is having the same trouble as me, my final Backtrack looks like this:

    def Backtrack(self):
        if not self.not_assigned_cells: return self
        assigned_cell = self.Select_cell()
        cell_domain = self.domain[assigned_cell]
        
        for cell_value in cell_domain:
            # Assign var
            loop_sudoku = deepcopy(self)
            loop_sudoku.assigned_cells.add(assigned_cell)
            loop_sudoku.not_assigned_cells.remove(assigned_cell)
            loop_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell] = [cell_value]
            loop_sudoku.state[assigned_cell] = cell_value
            # Check
            check_assignment =  loop_sudoku.check_constraints()
            if check_assignment:
                result = loop_sudoku.Backtrack()
                if result: return result        
        return []

I store the cells that have and have not been assigned, and remove the values that have been assigned from the domains of the cells in conflict.
    def check_constraints(self):
        for cell_1 in self.not_assigned_cells:
            for cell_2 in self.assigned_cells:
                if self.is_constrainted(cell_1,cell_2):
                    if self.state[cell_2] in self.domain[cell_1]: 
                        self.domain[cell_1].remove(self.state[cell_2])
                if not self.domain[cell_1]: return False                   
        return True
My BTS algorithm follows the structure of the lessons:
    def Backtrack(self):
        temp_sudoku = deepcopy(self)
        if not temp_sudoku.not_assigned_cells: return temp_sudoku
        assigned_cell = temp_sudoku.Select_cell()
        cell_domain = temp_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell]
        temp_sudoku.assigned_cells.add(assigned_cell)
        temp_sudoku.not_assigned_cells.remove(assigned_cell)
        
        for cell_value in cell_domain:
            # Assign var
            temp_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell] = [cell_value]
            temp_sudoku.state[assigned_cell] = cell_value
            # Check
            check_assignment =  temp_sudoku.check_constraints()
            if check_assignment:
                result = temp_sudoku.Backtrack()
                if result: return result        
        return []
I am trying to run the first case of the txt, but the result is a failure. If you have any idea on how to fix this, it would really help. Best regards.RaulEDIT: QUESTION SOLVEDThe problem was that the sudoku needs to be copied inside the loop. and not before. If someone is having the same trouble as me, my final Backtrack looks like this:
    def Backtrack(self):
        if not self.not_assigned_cells: return self
        assigned_cell = self.Select_cell()
        cell_domain = self.domain[assigned_cell]
        
        for cell_value in cell_domain:
            # Assign var
            loop_sudoku = deepcopy(self)
            loop_sudoku.assigned_cells.add(assigned_cell)
            loop_sudoku.not_assigned_cells.remove(assigned_cell)
            loop_sudoku.domain[assigned_cell] = [cell_value]
            loop_sudoku.state[assigned_cell] = cell_value
            # Check
            check_assignment =  loop_sudoku.check_constraints()
            if check_assignment:
                result = loop_sudoku.Backtrack()
                if result: return result        
        return []

answers.text: I think you need to create a copy of your temp_sudoku before checking it since check_constraints modifies the board. Also, you are not removing the cell_value if you check_constraints is False
answers.document: I think you need to create a copy of your temp_sudoku before checking it since check_constraints modifies the board. Also, you are not removing the cell_value if you check_constraints is False

comments.text: Thank you. Indeed the problem was the copying of the sudoku. The check_constraints modifies the board possible domain, so it is not a problem as it does not changes the current assignments.
comments.document: Thank you. Indeed the problem was the copying of the sudoku. The check_constraints modifies the board possible domain, so it is not a problem as it does not changes the current assignments.

answers.text: It seems that you might need a deepcopy in your Backtrack() for loop, to avoid modifying the same cell.

Same here. My program is outputting a valid solution to every puzzle, but the first one is always marked as 0. I even solved the puzzle by hand to make sure.

There was another post where someone suggested not using the append option to output the file, and to delete the output file before submitting, but neither of those solved it for me.

answers.text:
I dug down through the discussion and found this post https://us.edstem.org/courses/2345/discussion/175415 which suggested deleting the output file from Vocareum before submitting and now everything works fine.  

Another possibility that I haven't tested might be changing from "a" to "w" in the open file command.  That way you could ensure starting fresh with each run.   Just a thought, not sure if it would fix @andersala 's problem.

title: Final Exam Info
text:
Dear Students,

Your final exam will be available on 12/14/2020, 00:00 UTC until 12/21/2020, 23:30 UTC. 

Here’s a list of things you should DO before the exam:

Complete the Proctortrack Onboarding and make sure your Proctoring Software works on your computer by 12/1/2020, 23:30 UTC. Learn the proctor rules and requirements here

Complete ID verification before 12/1/2020, 23:30 UTC. See detail here

The name on your ID must exactly match the full name you have on your edX account, including being in the same language/alphabet. If needed, you can change the name on your account to match your ID

Take Dos and Don’ts quiz (Required to take the final exam)

Take the Practice Final Exams (Optional)

Here’s a list of things you should KNOW before the exam:

To earn a certificate, you must score 60% or above for the total grades and take the final proctored exam

The exam is 90 minutes long

It is a timed exam that needs to be completed in one sitting

You are allowed to take the final exam at any time during the final exam period

The style of the final exam will be similar to the quizzes 

Students can bring a calculator, paper, and pencil

No books, no videos allowed

No access to any other browser tabs except the exam

No other digital devices such as phones, tablets, smartwatches, etc. are allowed

Open notes. Students can use physical notes or digital notes with program like Adobe Reader or Preview to access the file


Note: Proctortrack does not support Linux, Virtual Machines, Chromebooks, iPads, Tablets, Android Mobile devices and computers or networks with firewall restrictions.

Please read the detailed information about the final exam here. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to reach out to us!



-Your Course Staff

title: Question 7: 3 choices are correct?
text:
Hello everyone.

So recently I did week 6 quizz, and there's something I found strange in question 7. The new feature has the highest gain from all the variables, then why it should be considered a useless?

Esteban.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello everyone.</paragraph><paragraph>So recently I did week 6 quizz, and there's something I found strange in question 7. The new feature has the highest gain from all the variables, then why it should be considered a useless?</paragraph><paragraph>Esteban.</paragraph></document>

answers.text: Intuitively, the application number does not have an affect on if a person should be hired or not. Also, it is discriminative since the model just remember the label for each of the applicants since each of the application number is unique.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Intuitively, the application number does not have an affect on if a person should be hired or not. Also, it is discriminative since the model just remember the label for each of the applicants since each of the application number is unique. </paragraph><paragraph/></document>

title: 7.3 Association Rules: question about support percentage
text:
Hello!

In Lecture 7.3, video about multi-dimensional rules:

I didn't understand how the support value for "(age, 20..29) -> (#cars, 1)" is 60%. For me it seems that it should be 40%, once we have only two samples in the table with people within the age 20..29 and have only one car, while the total number of people are 5. So wouldn't it be 2/5: 40%?

I would appreciate if someone could clarify that.

Thank you!
document: Hello!In Lecture 7.3, video about multi-dimensional rules:I didn't understand how the support value for "(age, 20..29) -> (#cars, 1)" is 60%. For me it seems that it should be 40%, once we have only two samples in the table with people within the age 20..29 and have only one car, while the total number of people are 5. So wouldn't it be 2/5: 40%?I would appreciate if someone could clarify that.Thank you!

answers.text: I think you need to look at the bottom table (age, 20 .. 29) is 3 on the bottom. So, it is 3/5 = .60.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I think you need to look at the bottom table (age, 20 .. 29) is 3 on the bottom. So, it is 3/5 = .60.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
So I was reviewing this and have to say that the explanation is correct:

"5. Now we have A and H in the frontier and A has the minimum cost, 5. Hence A gets expanded. It has just one child, D with cost 9 which is added to the frontier."

but the diagram is missing D and therefore should yield the answer False.  But that is marked as the "wrong" answer.  (For the record, I got the "right" answer, apparently through dumb luck.)

This is probably why the question is ungraded - some staff realized this mistake at some point but was unable or unwilling to correct it, so they just made it ungraded.

title: Additional notes and tips on this assignment
text:
Hi everyone, 

I thought I would do a brief post on some of the bottlenecks I have found on this assignment and how I have managed to resolve them in case it helps anyone else.

Testing your code on Vocareum:

The following is a one-line script to run in the 'bash' window to get the line 'NR' from the 'sudokus_start.txt' file (e.g. 'NR==1' for the first line) and pass it to a variable ($line in the code below). We do this in Vocareum before executing 'driver.py': 

line=$(awk 'NR==5 {print; exit}' sudokus_start.txt)

where NR == 5 is for the fifth line

we can print the value of the variable $line in bash by doing:

echo "$line"

Finally, we execute 'driver.py' to run with $line:

python3 driver.py "$line"


Using AC3 and Backtrack Search:

I have found the explanation of the assignment somewhat confusing at first. Reading the assignment about ten times and reading all the various posts from the rest of the students, things started to make more sense. 

What they mean by "To check how powerful BTS is compared to AC3, you must execute AC-3 algorithm before Backtracking Search algorithm.", or at least my interpretation is as follows:

Create a function/method (or a class) that executes AC3 as per Fig 6.3 in the AIMA book (including the function revise used inside the main AC3.

Create a function that executes BTS as per Fig 6.5 in the AIMA book, so there is a backtracking-search and a backtrack function; the latter is called in the former.

The backtrack function is actually where the 'search' for the solution happens.

If you implement 'backtrack' per fig 6.5 in AIMA book, the first thing is actually to check that the puzzle at that stage is not already 'solved'.

Then inside 'backtrack' call a function (e.g. 'get_unassigned') that gets you the values from the puzzle board which are 'unassigned'; it should give you the 'key' of the value (e.g. 'A1', 'A2', etc) and the domain of that value (e.g. [1,2,3,4]) which will depend on other values in the same row, column or 3x3 square. This is represented by "var < - SELECT-UNASSIGNED-VARIABLE(csp, assignment)" in the pseudo code of fig 6.5.

Then for each 'var' in the 'domain of var', as given by the 'get_unassigned' function, assign the value to a copy of the starting 'csp' (e.g. local_assignment dict) and set the value of the 'unassigned' dict as False for the 'key' just assigned. 

If the value 'var' is consistent with the assignment, then continue to call AC3 inside BTS (backtrack-search, backtrack). 

Next, test if it has been able to 'solve' the puzzle. If AC3 alone is capable of resolving it, then return the result at that point. In that case, the 'method' will be 'AC3.

If AC3 was not able to 'solve' the puzzle, then carry one with the puzzle in the state that AC3 has left it and call in 'backtrack' (recursively inside backtrack). Before doing that, check that the value is still consistent. 

Note that you need to update the dict 'unassigned' with the latest puzzle achieved by AC3 before calling 'backtrack'. I was not doing that and I was passing on the starting 'unassigned' dict which did not align with the 'local_assignment' dict for the puzzle at that time. It cost me a few days to figure it out and I felt a bit hopeless for a while so if I can make someone avoid that error that would make very happy ;)

Next, we test the resulting puzzle from calling 'backtrack'; if the result from 'backtrack' did not return a valid result (not empty), then we call 'forward_checking' as an additional inference to reduce the domain of the unassigned variables when we step out of the loop 'for each value in ORDER-DOMAIN-VALUES'. Again we apply 'forward_checking' on the latest version of the 'local_ssignment' and 'unassigned' dicts.  

If the assignment is not consistent, ensure those values are reverted back to their original values and 'unassigned' status so that when we call 'get_unassigned' again we can try with a different domain. 

Finally, when running 'get_unassigned' it is essential to order the (key, vars) results considering the length of the array/list 'vars' so that the 'keys' with the smallest domain (smallest length of the possible values) get assigned first. This will implement the 'minimum-remaining-values' (MRV) heuristic as explained in section 6.3.1. of the AIMA book. 

I also spent a bit of time trying to get rid of the "" when saving to txt because I was using dataframe and .to_csv to do so. It turns out it is best to use 'with open() and .write' as follows:

def write_txt(filename_outputs:str = 'output.txt', final_str:str = None): 

    # write the outputs csv file 
    filepath = os.path.join(os.getcwd(),'data', filename_outputs) 
    var = final_str 

    with open(filepath, 'a') as out: 
        out.write(var + '\n') 
    return print("New Outputs file saved to: <<", filename_outputs, ">>", sep='', end='\n')


Also, my code is not the most beautiful thing ever (could improve how it reads with more time) but in case it helps as you read the above, it is all available on GitHub here:

 https://github.com/mariamingallonMM/AI-CSP-Sudoku-A4

Hope this helps!

Best,

Maria

title: Edx-certificate for ColumbiaX CSMM.101xArtificial Intelligence (AI)
text:
I have few questions

1)  I am planning a certificate only for one course "ColumbiaX CSMM.101xArtificial Intelligence (AI)". Do I need to take proctored exam ?

2) Do I need to pay any extra free for this proctored exam ( in addition to fee paid for the course)?

3) Can I get certificate  for this course from Edx without proctored exam ? If , yes, what is the process I need to follow
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I have few questions</paragraph><paragraph>1)  I am planning a certificate only for one course "<bold>ColumbiaX CSMM.101xArtificial Intelligence (AI)</bold>". Do I need to take <bold>proctored exam ?</bold></paragraph><paragraph>2) Do I need to pay any extra free for this proctored exam ( in addition to fee paid for the course)?</paragraph><paragraph>3) Can I get certificate  for this course from Edx without proctored exam ? If , yes, what is the process I need to follow </paragraph></document>

comments.text:
1 & 3) You need to take proctored exam to be eligible to receive certificate for verified track learners.

2) No, not that I am aware.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>1 & 3) You need to take proctored exam to be eligible to receive certificate for verified track learners.</paragraph><paragraph>2) No, not that I am aware.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: Be sure to perform the proctor track setup before trying to sit for the exam. There is a delay to account for after doing the test environment setup before the actual test will be able to be taken.

Please let us know if you have any questions. 



Shu-Yi

comments.text:
Hi ArmanDoskaliyev,

Thank you for your efforts in this course, and we understand your frustration. Unfortunately this is an instructor-led course, so we cannot extend the deadlines. If you have been impacted by the pandemic and would like to reenroll/refund, we suggest that you reach out to edX support to inquire in details.

That said, we encourage you to continue working on this course and finish as much as you can. As long as you submit some of the assignments, take the final exam, and achieve 60% of the total grade, you will pass the course and get the certificate. The course staff are always here to support you and answer your questions on the discussion forum. We sincerely wish you all the best with your career, family and academic pursuit during this challenging time. Thank you very much for your understanding!

Best,

Eva

title: End of Micromasters?
text:
Hi,

I received a mail stating that the AI Micromasters is ending with the Feb 2021 run. I have a couple of questions regarding this:

1. Are there plans for new Micromasters courses (repackaging these subjects in some other format)?

2. Will the Analytics Micromasters also be discontinued after Feb 2021?

PS: I really liked this course, and was hoping the other courses would stick around for some more time. It's tough to do more than one at a time if you really want to dive into some of the topics introduced.

comments.text:
This is the entire contents of the email.

Hello, 

 We're reaching out because we see that you have purchased verified certificate(s) in Columbia’s Artificial Intelligence MicroMasters® program. This MicroMasters program will be ending in May 2021 and no additional program runs are planned. We continue to support our learners in their professional and academic pursuits, which is why we're offering an opportunity to complete the program by enrolling in any remaining courses and purchasing the associated verified certificates. 

 You may enroll and upgrade in any courses you have not already enrolled in or completed. Please visit your program dashboard to enroll in your remaining courses. 

Final Course Schedule Start Dates: 
 Artificial Intelligence (AI) - 2/1/21 
 Machine Learning - 2/1/21 
 Robotics - 2/1/21 
 Animation and CGI Motion - 2/1/21

title: Program run command is super important!!!
text:
I have learned it the hard way, indeed! I have used uppercase for my python file name as Problem2.py in my submissions so far and was dumb-faced to see that Vocareum did not process my file at all. 

Having been spent enormous time to debug and trying to understand what is going wrong, frustrated  to the core and low on confidence, this morning took the final chance to change the name of the file and re-submit.

BINGO! 50/50 the first time.

Moral of the story - run the exact command as provided in the Project pages, letter to letter, digit to digit and symbols to get past the first hurdle of Vocareum recognize your submission properly!!!!!! 

Be well and keep safe.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I have learned it the hard way, indeed! I have used uppercase for my python file name as Problem2.py in my submissions so far and was dumb-faced to see that Vocareum did not process my file at all. </paragraph><paragraph>Having been spent enormous time to debug and trying to understand what is going wrong, frustrated  to the core and low on confidence, this morning took the final chance to change the name of the file and re-submit.</paragraph><paragraph>BINGO! 50/50 the first time.</paragraph><paragraph>Moral of the story - run the exact command as provided in the Project pages, letter to letter, digit to digit and symbols to get past the first hurdle of Vocareum recognize your submission properly!!!!!! </paragraph><paragraph>Be well and keep safe.</paragraph></document>

title: A Neural Network for everything?
text: Every time I read a post or watch a video about NNs, they mention problems like classification, speech recognition, object identification, reinforcement learning etc. If deep NNs can do everything, then what's the point of learning and coding the other algorithms? What can Linear Regression, SVMs, HMMs, Q-Learning etc do that NNs cannot? If you can use both algorithms, how do you decide which one to use?

What can Linear Regression, SVMs, HMMs, Q-Learning etc do that NNs cannot? If you can use both algorithms, how do you decide which one to use?</paragraph></document>

title: MicroMasters Program 2021 Plan
text:
Dear Students,

We are reaching out because we have an announcement to share about our plan for the MicroMasters program.

This Artificial Intelligence MicroMasters program will be ending in May 2021 and no additional program runs are planned. 


You may enroll and upgrade in any courses you have not already enrolled in or completed. Please visit your program dashboard to enroll in your remaining courses. 

Final Course Schedule Dates: 2/1/2021 - 5/3/2021

The last day for enrollment: 3/1/2021

Thanks for your understanding, and we do apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. Please reach out to info@edx.org if you have any questions or need assistance.

Best,

Your Course Staff

Please visit your <link href="https://courses.edx.org/dashboard/programs/?utm_source=sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=jira_mm_columbia_ai_retirement_20201128">program dashboard</link> to enroll in your remaining courses. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Final Course Schedule Dates:</bold> 2/1/2021 - 5/3/2021</paragraph><paragraph><bold>The last day for enrollment:</bold> 3/1/2021</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks for your understanding, and we do apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. Please reach out to info@edx.org if you have any questions or need assistance.</paragraph><paragraph>Best,</paragraph><paragraph>Your Course Staff</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Hi,

Adding my voice to the chorus of broken hearts. I was planning to do this course and the Machine Learning one (which I will now attempt in Feb), followed by the Analytics Micromasters (which I now won't be able to do). I really like these course because they aim to teach an extensive syllabus. Although online learning has been on the rise, most of it seem to me like cash grab attempts. Want to learn deep learning in 2 weeks even if you don't know what regression is, sure why not? Most ML courses simply teach you the libraries, without going any deeper. The prof in this course actually derived the backpropagation algorithm. Although it takes only a few mins, it makes a big difference to someone who is really interested.

You have to understand that in parts of the world where higher education is mediocre at best, courses like these are a godsend. I can only speculate to the reason for discontinuing these programs (maybe Columbia wants its own online platform, maybe the Vocareum charges and TA effort make the course unsustainable...), but one idea I would like to put forward which you might consider at a later date is to make these courses more quiz driven (maybe write the program, but enter only a final value as the answer to a quiz); you already have all the material, all it would take is a one time effort. Harvard does it for a lot of their courses. Also peer reviewed assignments are another option. All of them come with their own challenges of course.

Finally if we are to part ways, I would like to offer my sincere thanks to the staff for making these available for so long. A 12 week course is rare in a time of instant gratification, and ones with so much breadth and depth is much appreciated.

Thanks a lot, 

George.

comments.text:
Dear students,

We sincerely apologize for the short notice as we are also devastated by the end of one of our most cherished programs. Please note, however, that the MicroMasters was never intended to be a program to increase your chances of acceptance into the MS in Computer Science program. It was merely an introduction to AI to help learners decide whether they were willing to commit to a full-length graduate-length program in this field. Rest assured that most students accepted into our MS in Computer Science have not taken the MicroMasters in AI. Furthermore, those who have completed the MicroMasters are not given an advantage over those who have not. Those who will not have completed all four courses by the end of June can still include the individual courses you have already taken in the MOOC section of the application (this should only be an option for those who are not requesting refunds). Although this would not qualify you to receive the 7.5 transfer credits, it will demonstrate to the Admissions Committee that you have had some exposure to the material. 

We will also share some tips to help you strengthen you application for the MS in Computer Science program in a separate post. 



Thanks, 

Shu-Yi

Although this would not qualify you to receive the 7.5 transfer credits, it will demonstrate to the Admissions Committee that you have had some exposure to the material. </paragraph><paragraph>We will also share some tips to help you strengthen you application for the MS in Computer Science program in a separate post. </paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>Thanks, </paragraph><paragraph>Shu-Yi</paragraph></document>

title: Treating uppercase and punctuation
text:
Hi, 

For the creation of the database csv file,  how should we treat the uppercase letters and punctuation symbols.

For example, for python 'while' or 'While' are different words, and if I try to remove 'the' it wont remove 'The'. Is this something we need to address at this stage (should the csv file be all in lowercase and without full stops and commas, or this will be treated later? 

I assume that the stopwords have to be removed whatever the uppercase or lowercase.

Best regards.

Raul
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi, </paragraph><paragraph>For the creation of the database csv file,  how should we treat the uppercase letters and punctuation symbols.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, for python 'while' or 'While' are different words, and if I try to remove 'the' it wont remove 'The'. Is this something we need to address at this stage (should the csv file be all in lowercase and without full stops and commas, or this will be treated later? </paragraph><paragraph>I assume that the stopwords have to be removed whatever the uppercase or lowercase.</paragraph><paragraph>Best regards.</paragraph><paragraph>Raul</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
str.lower() function will convert all characters in a string to lowercase. Then you can safely remove words in your stopwords (which are already lowercase!!)

You can check Python documentation for str data type to get more information on string functions.

title: My results to the optional Assignment Week 9 (Reinforcement Learning)
text:
Greetings!

I finished my program for the Optional Assignment of Week 9 about Reinforcement Learning and I want to share my results and insights.

This was a really interesting side-project and I'm glad I tried it. By doing it I was able to understand better the reinforcement learning lectures and now I'm more interested in this topic of AI.

The policy iteration and value iteration algorithms were kind off easy to code, but the QLearning one was more challenging, because I had to adapt the code to serve as a simulation without explicitly giving any information of the probability of transition to an specific state or the structure of transitions.

You can check out my code here: https://github.com/Carlitos5336/ReinforcementLearning

These are my answers to the questions from the assignment:

Question 1

We used the policy iteration method to find optimal policy for discount factor 0.1. Try using this method with a different discount factor, for example a much larger discount factor like 0.9 or 0.99, or a much smaller one like 0.01. Does the optimal policy change?

These are my results with different values of lambda:

The greater the lambda, the more the policy values the future rewards, so it prefers to keep a safe strategy by always choosing the Slow Action.

In contrast, when the lambda is close to zero, the policy values more the nearer rewards, so it prefers to take the Fast Action in the Moving State.

Question 2

Now, try using the value iteration method instead. How does the number of iterations change? What about the complexity of implementing each iteration?

These are the number of iteration my algorithm takes for each method using lambda = 0.1.

In fact, the number of iterations using value iteration method is higher than the ones using policy iteration method as proffesor Shipra Agrawal said in one of the lectures.

In terms of complexity,  the most important difference between the two is that in policy iteration method the algorithm calculates the VPI (value function pi) for each iteration, and to calculate the VPI we need to find the inverse of the following matrix:

$$I-\lambda P_{\pi}$$

That is based on the bellman equations for MDPs.

$$v_{\pi}=\left(I-\lambda P_{\pi}\right)^{-1}\cdot r_{\pi}$$

So this operation of calculating the inverse adds a lot of complexity to the algorithm specially because it will repeat several times. In a system with hundreds and thousands of states and transitions, to calculate the inverse of the matrix would be too time consuming. That's why in terms of the number of states and transitions, the policy iteration method is more complex than the value iteration method.

Question 3

Write a python script to implement the Q-learning method (without exploration) for this simple MDP. Run this script several times. Does the algorithm always converge? Now, try adding a simple epsilon greedy exploration and rerun. 

I tested the epsilon-greedy exploration case with an epsilon value of 10%

When using the QLearning method alone just with a greedy exploration by using the action that maximizes the q-value it rarely converges to the same answer in terms of q-values, but it yields almost always the same policy. In the case of the one with epsilon -greedy exploration, the q-values converges almost always and sometimes gets the best policy we found with the other method.

For example, in this case, it yielded a different and better value.

Question 4

Pick your favorite single player computer game, for example, Cart-pole balancing. How would you model the problem of learning to play this game (without needing to know the physics of the game) as a reinforcement learning problem? Define the state space, action space, transition model, reward function and goal of the underlying MDP.

One of the games in wich I'd like to develop an AI using Reinforcement Learning is Tetris.

The goal for the AI would be to fill each cell of the different rows with the different random pieces completely without leaving holes, so the pieces never get to the top of the board.

For every time step of the game, the action space would be [do nothing, move left, move right, rotate]

The state space would be the set of all possible combinations of filled and non-filled cells of the board.

The transition model will be based on the position of filled and non-filled cells that produces an action from a state.

The positive reward could be relative to the amount of filled cells in a row, and negative reward for the amount of holes in the board.

comments.text:
Hi Carlos,

while working on this project I also noticed that the Q-Learning alg as presented in the lectures does not converge for the given MDP. In https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning and https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~arielpro/15780/lec/VelosoRLGradAI2012.pdf (last slide) I found out that the problem lies in the non-deterministic nature of the "fallen, standing, moving" MDP. Adding an alpha learning rate as the weighted sum of past QValues does the job (of course after sufficient iterations). 

The Q-Leaning algorithm presented in the lectures only converges in deterministic environments (actions always lead to the same rewards) and has therefore a learning rate alpha of 1. This means that the QValues are fully determined by the current reward and the max(QValue) of the new state, completely ignoring past rewards after taking the same action. 

Thanks for your post and I hope this is interesting for you as well.

Rafael

Adding an alpha learning rate as the weighted sum of past QValues does the job (of course after sufficient iterations). </paragraph><paragraph>The Q-Leaning algorithm presented in the lectures only converges in deterministic environments (actions always lead to the same rewards) and has therefore a learning rate alpha of 1. This means that the QValues are fully determined by the current reward and the max(QValue) of the new state, completely ignoring past rewards after taking the same action. </paragraph><paragraph>Thanks for your post and I hope this is interesting for you as well.</paragraph><paragraph>Rafael </paragraph></document>

comments.text:
Hi Rafael,

In fact, that's the exact problem I saw in the Q-Learning algorithm presented in lecture, it just only seemed to care about inmediate rewards even with some reasonable values of lambda. 

I searched the formula you shared on the slide. Thanks for sharing!

It seems that to calculate these expected values we would have to count the frequencies of getting to a state to infer the probabilities of each transition.

Thanks for your comment, it was really insightful and cleared my doubt!

Carlos

title: Bigram probabilities
text:
Hello,

I must be missing something.

Based off the lecture and demo for bigrams probabilities; I'm not sure how to arrive at the correct answer for self-check question 1.

If I am to find the P(Start Sam Stop), wouldn't it be as follows:

P(Sam|Start) and P(Stop|Sam)?  1/3 + 1/3 = 2/3 =.667?

Can someone help me to understand?

Thanks

You have to multiply them to get 1/6.

title: Interested in online MS in Computer Science Program at Columbia University?
text:
Dear students, 

We'd like to share with you some tips and resources which could be beneficial for you if you are interested in applying for an online MS in CS: 

Application requirements: 

An undergraduate degree in Computer Science. If you have an undergraduate degree in a different field, you must take six prerequisites (four grade- and credit-bearing courses in Computer Science and two math courses, preferably Linear Algebra and Differential Equations). These courses must be completed before applying to the MS and can be taken at a university and must be issued on a transcript. MOOCs and work experience do not waive this requirement.

A minimum undergraduate cumulative GPA of 3.3 (around a B+, 87-89% average)

Three letters of recommendation, preferably two should be from professors if you graduated fewer than five years ago from your undergraduate or graduate degree program

GRE General Test scores (optional for Spring, Summer, and Fall 2021)

A resume/cv

A personal/professional statement

$150 application fee 

Tips to strengthen your application:

For those who do not have an undergraduate degree in Computer Science - Again, you must complete the four CS courses and two math prerequisites prior to applying. Aim for at least a B+ in each course. You can take any CS course offered, but here are a few examples of typical CS courses: Intro to Computer Science (COMS W1004 or COMS W1007), Advanced Programming (COMS W3157), Data Structures and Algorithms (COMS W3134 or W3137), which is a prerequisite for most of our graduate-level courses, or/and Discrete Math (COMS W3203). These courses are not offered at CVN so I suggest that you take them at your local community college or four-year university. 

Consider taking the GRE General Test - While the GRE General Test is completely optional for the Spring 2021, Summer 2021, and Fall 2021 terms, doing well on the exam, (i.e., scoring at least a160/170 on the Quantitative section, 158/170 on the Verbal section and 4.5/6.0 on the AWA) can demonstrate your ability to handle a strongly quantitative program. Give yourself about two months to prepare for the exam. 

Enroll in a non-degree course at CVN, no more than 2 - Non-degree courses are essentially the same courses you would take if admitted to the MS program without having to enroll in a degree program. Nearly all of the courses offered can be taken on a non-degree basis, you simply have to meet the prerequisites of the course. Most students choose to take one or two of the core courses listed under the Courses tab. To learn which of these courses will be offered next term, the Spring 2021 course list is now available. The prerequisites can be found in the course descriptions. The credits from these courses, up to six credits(or two courses), can be applied to one of our degree programs. Aim for at least a B+ in these courses and develop a relationship with the professor so that you can request a letter of recommendation when you have completed them. Please note that taking a non degree course does not guarantee admission to the MS program. Since these are the same courses you would take if admitted to the MS, the tuition is the same, about $6,983 per course. To apply, submit a non-degree application via this link. 

Secure strong letters of recommendation, preferably at least two from current or former professors - Think critically about the skills that translate to success in a graduate engineering degree program and find appropriate recommenders who can testify to your ability in these areas: leadership, quantitative, analytical, and English writing/speaking skills, ability to work on a team and independently..etc. 

Explain gaps and/or red flags in your personal statement - Performed poorly your first semester of college? Worked three jobs during your differential equations course? Experienced some personal tragedy that impacted your work/academic performance? Paint a picture for the Admissions Committee about what happened and how you overcame it to assure the Committee that the issue was addressed, and, more importantly, will no longer be a concern if admitted to the program. 

Comprehensive resume/CV - Highlight not only jobs relevant to your intended field of study, but also unrelated positions that have taught you transferable skills (leadership, quantitative, analytical, and English writing/speaking skills, ability to work on a team and independently..etc) that will lead to success in an engineering program. Be sure to include published research, volunteer positions, leadership roles in student or professional organizations, internships, and of course, paid positions.

Please note that CVN Admissions cannot provide guidance on edX/MicroMasters-related matters (upcoming courses, refunds, certificates..etc).

For more information about CVN’s admissions process, I encourage you to attend a weekly informational webinar. Webinars are held every Tuesday and Thursday from 2 pm - 2:30 pm ET. To register, click here. CVN Admissions can be contacted at info@cvn.columbia.edu or via phone at (212) 854-6447 press option 2. 

On-campus residential CS Masters Program Admission website link: https://www.gradengineering.columbia.edu/graduate-admissions/application-requirements

I hope it could help you.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I had a little different approach, when my code runs locally in my Mac (Darwin), the path points to other folder.</paragraph><paragraph>I hope it could help you.</paragraph></document>

comments.text:
I use a MacBook as well and mine works fine.

Remember that the double dots means you are referring to the relative path of the parent folder for the current folder.

That means that if you have a folder called PROJECTS with inside a folder called PROJECT 5 and inside driver.py, your "resource" folder has to be in PROJECTS and not in PROJECT 5.

If it works with one dot it means that you have put "resource" in your PROJECT 5 folder, but it should be in PROJECTS.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I use a MacBook as well and mine works fine.</paragraph><paragraph>Remember that the double dots means you are referring to the relative path of the parent folder for the current folder.</paragraph><paragraph>That means that if you have a folder called PROJECTS with inside a folder called PROJECT 5 and inside driver.py, your "resource" folder has to be in PROJECTS and not in PROJECT 5.</paragraph><paragraph>If it works with one dot it means that you have put "resource" in your PROJECT 5 folder, but it should be in PROJECTS.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
import platform

if platform.system() == 'Darwin':
    train_path = "/Users/myuser/Documents/Columbia/Project5_NLP/aclImdb/train/"  
    test_path = "/Users/myuser/Documents/Columbia/Project5_NLP/aclImdb/imdb_te.csv"  
else:
    train_path = "../resource/lib/publicdata/aclImdb/train/"  # use terminal to ls files under this directory
    test_path = "../resource/lib/publicdata/imdb_te.csv"  # test data for grade evaluation

title: 9.9 Q-Learning Non-Deterministic
text:
Hi all!

the Q-Learning algorithms provided in the lectures converge only in deterministic environments, although some examples provided are of non-deterministic nature.

It would be very beneficial to add an explanation about the learning rate factor (alpha) in the Q-Learning lectures or slides.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning

https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~arielpro/15780/lec/VelosoRLGradAI2012.pdf (last slide)

Thanks,

Rafael
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi all!</paragraph><paragraph>the Q-Learning algorithms provided in the lectures converge only in deterministic environments, although some examples provided are of non-deterministic nature.</paragraph><paragraph>It would be very beneficial to add an explanation about the learning rate factor (alpha) in the Q-Learning lectures or slides.</paragraph><paragraph><link href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning</link></paragraph><paragraph><link href="https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~arielpro/15780/lec/VelosoRLGradAI2012.pdf">https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~arielpro/15780/lec/VelosoRLGradAI2012.pdf</link> (last slide)</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks,</paragraph><paragraph>Rafael</paragraph></document>

comments.text: The course only touches on the very basics of RL. You can only do so much in a week! In practice you'll rarely use Q-Learning. It's more like "approximate Q Learning" since real world problems rarely have manageable sets of states and/ or actions. In the end you're likely to use value functions to determine rewards and approximate a Q value. My point is the lectures are just a starting point - there's much left out. RL is a full semester course in itself.

title: UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x8c in position 2976: invalid start byte
text:
Has anyone else run across this error when trying to read in the test file?  I am using the same code I used for reading in the huge csv of training data, but not having success.

with open(test_path, 'r') as csv_file:
        reader = csv.DictReader(csv_file)
        for row in reader:


This results in:

UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x8c in position 2976: invalid start byte

I also have a separate, but related question.  In the code above, I am just trying to read the rows into a normal Python list.  However, I would prefer to use pandas and csv.read so that I can start learning pandas.  I was able to successfully read in the text, but when this panda array was fed into the CountVectorization function, something obviously went wrong because I would get errors when trying to fit the X and y to the model (both X and y were panda dataframes).  

X = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(outpath, name), usecols=["text"])
y = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(outpath, name), usecols=["polarity"])
X = vectorizer.fit_transform(X)


The error I received stated something to do with having arrays of different lengths, and it did seem like X was quite different using this method as opposed to using a list.  Anyone have anything  suggestions?  Thanks!

answers.text: To answer my other question, about Pandas dataframes for anyone else with a similar problem.  The code I had above would not only pull the data in the "text" and "polarity" columns into the dataframe, it also pulled the header.  For some reason I thought the dataframe would no longer have a header since it only contained info under one column.  My bad.  The easy fix was just to bring all columns into a data frame, and then use data.text, data.polarity to grab those parts I needed for X and y.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>To answer my other question, about Pandas dataframes for anyone else with a similar problem.  The code I had above would not only pull the data in the "text" and "polarity" columns into the dataframe, it also pulled the header.  For some reason I thought the dataframe would no longer have a header since it only contained info under one column.  My bad.  The easy fix was just to bring all columns into a data frame, and then use data.text, data.polarity to grab those parts I needed for X and y.  </paragraph></document>

title: Bigram vs unigram tests
text:
Hi Everyone - In sklearn, is there something fundamentally different that must be done between unigram and bigram tests?  I just submitted, and got almost perfect scores for the two unigram tests, but 3/25 and 0/25 for the bigram tests.  As far as I can tell, the only different between unigram and bigram is changing one vectorizer parameter (ngram_range from (1,1) to (2,2).  All my other code is identical (excepting calling CountVectorizer vs TfidfVectorizer).

I probably have some typographical elsewhere - I'll start debugging.  But given the huge score differences between the two, I wonder if I'm missing something else tiny but essential in sklearn.  Thanks again!

I just submitted, and got almost perfect scores for the two unigram tests, but 3/25 and 0/25 for the bigram tests.  As far as I can tell, the only different between unigram and bigram is changing one vectorizer parameter (ngram_range from (1,1) to (2,2).  All my other code is identical (excepting calling CountVectorizer vs TfidfVectorizer).</paragraph><paragraph>I probably have some typographical elsewhere - I'll start debugging.  But given the huge score differences between the two, I wonder if I'm missing something else tiny but essential in sklearn.  Thanks again!</paragraph></document>

answers.text: Found it! The problem set says "expand to bigram", not "replace unigram with bigram". That gives a big clue how the range should be....
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Found it! The problem set says "expand to bigram", not "replace unigram with bigram". That gives a big clue how the range should be....</paragraph></document>

title: Cross-Validation
text:
Hi Everyone - One last question about cross-validation, which is required by this assignment (even though I am standing at 97% without it, which makes me wonder how essential it is.).  Anyway, I am confused as to which stage of the process to use it, and what it would look like.  The only validate param for SGD is for an early stop at convergence, which I don't think we need since it's not outrageously time-consuming to iterate through the end).  Also, since the assignment tells us which parameters to use (like hinge and l1) we aren't really needing to CV the params.  And I'm not clear on if splitting our training data into training and test will actually increase performance.  

Long story short, at what point do we cross-validate (Vectorization, model fitting or testing) and is it a separate process or a parameter addition in the above three?  

Thanks again.
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi Everyone - One last question about cross-validation, which is required by this assignment (even though I am standing at 97% without it, which makes me wonder how essential it is.).  Anyway, I am confused as to which stage of the process to use it, and what it would look like.  The only validate param for SGD is for an early stop at convergence, which I don't think we need since it's not outrageously time-consuming to iterate through the end).  Also, since the assignment tells us which parameters to use (like hinge and l1) we aren't really needing to CV the params.  And I'm not clear on if splitting our training data into training and test will actually increase performance.  </paragraph><paragraph>Long story short, at what point do we cross-validate (Vectorization, model fitting or testing) and is it a separate process or a parameter addition in the above three?  </paragraph><paragraph>Thanks again.</paragraph></document>

answers.text: I was wondering the same. I did not do cross validation either since we are using the full set of training data. But I also wonder in which scenarios it makes sense to use cross validation or not. I agree it does not seem like cross validation would have made a difference.
answers.document: <document version="1.0"><paragraph>I was wondering the same. I did not do cross validation either since we are using the full set of training data. But I also wonder in which scenarios it makes sense to use cross validation or not. I agree it does not seem like cross validation would have made a difference. </paragraph></document>

answers.text: For this current assignment, although cross-validation does not provide much benefit, but in actual practice cross -validation is very crucial. For example, if you only have one train and test split, we can have some model that works very well on a certain split, but once you do multiple split you can have more confidence on saying that it generalize to new data.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For this current assignment, although cross-validation does not provide much benefit, but in actual practice cross -validation is very crucial. For example, if you only have one train and test split, we can have some model that works very well on a certain split, but once you do multiple split you can have more confidence on saying that it generalize to new data.</paragraph></document>

title: Application of local Search Algorithms
text:
Hello, 

After reviewing the lecture on local search algorithms, I was wondering if local search algorithms--particularly, the hill climbing algorithm--can be applied to figuring out the best route out of a mazes, i.e., the labyrinth game or a garden maze?

Upon looking at the illustration of the graph presented, I was wondering if dead-ends and turn-about in mazes could be represented as local maximums (or local minimums) and shoulders, respectively.  Perhaps, too, that the exit from a maze could be represented as the global maximum.

This was just a notion I got from the lecture.

Thanks,
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hello, </paragraph><paragraph>After reviewing the lecture on local search algorithms, I was wondering if local search algorithms--particularly, the hill climbing algorithm--can be applied to figuring out the best route out of a mazes, i.e., the labyrinth game or a garden maze?</paragraph><paragraph>Upon looking at the illustration of the graph presented, I was wondering if dead-ends and turn-about in mazes could be represented as local maximums (or local minimums) and shoulders, respectively.  Perhaps, too, that the exit from a maze could be represented as the global maximum.</paragraph><paragraph>This was just a notion I got from the lecture.</paragraph><paragraph>Thanks,</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text:
Local search is a family of powerful algorithms that usually solve problems in the category of optimization. CSPs are an example of optimization problems. Here the path from the source to the target is often known and the task is to optimize it. You usually have a cost function for that path, and the algorithms aim to minimize/ maximize that cost. For example, in the map coloring problem, a solution is assigning random colors to all the territories and a cost can be the number of neighboring territories that have the same color. The task of the algorithm would then be to minimize that cost.

You can retrofit a maze search problem to be solved by hill climbing - take some random path and then attempt to lower the cost of parts of it until the overall cost is minimum. There are however better suited algorithms like A-star to achieve this in a much more efficient way.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Local search is a family of powerful algorithms that usually solve problems in the category of optimization. CSPs are an example of optimization problems. Here the path from the source to the target is often known and the task is to optimize it. You usually have a cost function for that path, and the algorithms aim to minimize/ maximize that cost. For example, in the map coloring problem, a solution is assigning random colors to all the territories and a cost can be the number of neighboring territories that have the same color. The task of the algorithm would then be to minimize that cost.</paragraph><paragraph>You can retrofit a maze search problem to be solved by hill climbing - take some random path and then attempt to lower the cost of parts of it until the overall cost is minimum. There are however better suited algorithms like A-star to achieve this in a much more efficient way. </paragraph></document>

 Your onboarding profile was reviewed successfully

title: Practice  exam and certification
text:
Hi Greetings,

I cannot find pratice exam link in my course so kindly please help as I would like to give it before the final exam. I have one more query due to some reason I have only 14% in grade if I do not get 60% grade still can I get a certificate after the final exam?

Thank you
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi Greetings,</paragraph><paragraph>I cannot find pratice exam link in my course so kindly please help as I would like to give it before the final exam. I have one more query due to some reason I have only 14% in grade if I do not get 60% grade still can I get a certificate after the final exam?</paragraph><paragraph>Thank you</paragraph> </document>

answers.text:
Hi hvaghela116,

Please find the practice final here. You can also find it in the Practice Final Exam module on your course page.

In order to pass the course and get the certificate, you need to score 60% or above of the total grade, and take the final exam. The total score in this course consists of:

Quizzes (20%): There will be 11 quizzes worth 2% each for a total of 20%. The lowest score will be dropped. 

Projects (50%): There will be 5 projects in Python worth 10% each for a total of 50%. All projects count. 

Final Exam (30%): There will be a final exam one week after the last lecture.

title: More details about the open notes please
text: I did the practice test and they specified that no notes were allowed. I am a bit confused. I can open any file in adobe while taking the test? Can I open the calculator software from my computer? Can I use excel in my computer to calculate things? Can I use python to calculate things? Can I use Word to take notes during the test?
document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph/><paragraph>I did the practice test and they specified that no notes were allowed. I am a bit confused. I can open any file in adobe while taking the test? Can I open the calculator software from my computer? Can I use excel in my computer to calculate things? Can I use python to calculate things? Can I use Word to take notes during the test?</paragraph><paragraph><break/></paragraph></document>

comments.text:
The practice test is confusing only because it is setting up an artificial set of rules to give you the idea that rules will be set.   It's a generic "ProctorTrack" sample test.

 As explained below are the actual rules for this course. Hope that helps, it is confusing.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The practice test is confusing only because it is setting up an artificial set of rules to give you the idea that rules will be set.   It's a generic "ProctorTrack" sample test.</paragraph><paragraph> As explained below are the actual rules for this course. Hope that helps, it is confusing.</paragraph></document>

answers.text:
Taking an online proctored exam is not much different from doing an in person proctored exam. You can only use the materials and software specified in the final exam instructions. 

For Verified Track Students: 

1. Students can bring a calculator, paper, and pencil. 
2. No books, no videos allowed.
3. No access to any other browser tabs except the exam.
4. Open notes. Students can use physical notes or digital notes with program like Adobe Reader or Preview to access the file.
5. It is a timed exam that needs to be completed in one sitting. 



As explained, You can use adoebe reader or preview to access the digital notes. 

You can use a physical calculator (a computer   calculator is ok).

Using any other software or materials such as python, or excel will result in violation of the exam. 

Thus, no Word, no Excel, no Python.

Students can bring a calculator, paper, and pencil. <break/>2. No books, no videos allowed.<break/>3. No access to any other browser tabs except the exam.<break/>4. Open notes. Students can use physical notes or digital notes with program like Adobe Reader or Preview to access the file.<break/>5. It is a timed exam that needs to be completed in one sitting. </paragraph><paragraph/><paragraph>As explained, You can use adoebe reader or preview to access the digital notes. </paragraph><paragraph>You can use a physical calculator (a computer   calculator is ok).</paragraph><paragraph>Using any other software or materials such as python, or excel will result in violation of the exam. </paragraph><paragraph>Thus, no Word, no Excel, no Python. </paragraph><paragraph/></document>

Hi Zil Fang,

Yes, you still have time to take the proctored practice exam. Sorry to hear about the issues you're experiencing. You need to take the proctored practice exam again because onboarding process is a 1-time attempt and needs to be completed in one sitting. We need to reset your previous attempt for you to try again.

Let us know when you would like us to reset your profile!

Also, we highly encourage you to reach out proctortrack support team for live chat if you have any technical issues (It's located at the bottom right corner of the website). 

-Course staff

title: Final Exam Info and Prerequisites
text:
Dear Students, 

Your final exam will be open until 12/21/2020, 23:30 UTC. Please finish it as early as possible in case you encounter any technical issues

Before the Exam

Make sure you completed all of the following three prerequisites. You will not be able to take the final without them

Complete the Proctortrack Onboarding and make sure your Proctoring Software works on your computer

Learn the proctor rules and requirements here (Note that Test environment rules on this page does not apply to every course. Please refer to the Test environment rules in the During the Exam section below)

It takes 2 business days for Proctortrack to review your profile

Complete ID verification. See detail here

The name on your ID must exactly match the full name you have on your edX account, including being in the same language/alphabet. If needed, you can change the name on your account to match your ID

It takes 5-7 business days for edX to verify your ID

Take Dos and Don'ts quiz



During the Exam

You are required to take the final exam to earn the certificate. 

The exam is 90 minutes long. 

It is a timed exam that needs to be completed in one sitting.

The style of the final exam will be similar to the quizzes.

You are allowed to take the final exam at any time during the final exam period

If you encounter technical issues during the proctored exam, contact the live customer service and the course staff on the discussion forum immediately

Note: Proctortrack does not support Linux, Virtual Machines, Chromebooks, iPads, Tablets, Android Mobile devices and computers or networks with firewall restrictions.

Test environment rules:

You must take the exam in the same room that you scanned during the proctoring setup for the current exam.
Note: You must complete a webcam scan of the room where you will take the exam every time you take a proctored exam. However, you do not have to take all of your proctored exams in the same room.

No other person is allowed to enter the room while you are taking the proctored exam.

The lighting in the room must be bright enough to be considered “daylight” quality. Overhead lighting is preferred. If overhead lighting is not available, the source of light must not be behind you.

You must sit at a clean desk or table.

The desk or walls around you must not have any writing.

The room must be as quiet as possible. Sounds such as music or television are not permitted.

Students can bring a calculator, paper, and pencil. 

No books, no videos allowed.

No access to any other browser tabs except the exam.

Open notes. Students can use physical notes or digital notes with program like Adobe Reader or Preview to access the file. 

You can find more details about the final exam here. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to reach out to us!



Any violation of the proctored exam rules could result in losing the opportunity for earning the certificate



After the Exam

Once the final exam is completed, it takes about 5 business days to receive the proctor exam result. After that, you can find the final exam and the total grades on the progress page. If you do not hear back from the exam result after 5 days, you can reach out to the course staff on the discussion forum

Verified track learners will have lifelong access to the course content (except the coding platform). 

The certification will be available after 1/4/2021. To earn a certificate, you must score 60% or above for the total grades and take the final exam



Good luck with your final!


Your Course Staff

If overhead lighting is not available, the source of light must not be behind you.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>You must sit at a clean desk or table.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>The desk or walls around you must not have any writing.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>The room must be as quiet as possible. Sounds such as music or television are not permitted.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Students can bring a calculator, paper, and pencil. </paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>No books, no videos allowed.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>No access to any other browser tabs except the exam.</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Open notes. Students can use physical notes or digital notes with program like Adobe Reader or Preview to access the file. </paragraph></list-item></list></list-item><list-item><paragraph>You can find more details about the final exam <bold><link href="https://courses.edx.org/courses/course-v1:ColumbiaX+CSMM.101x+3T2020/courseware/9b4f221cbfde442a9aeed5d04c79a667/c241cb751a7d45b6b23176c523859a1d/">here</link></bold>. If you have any questions, don’t hesitate to reach out to us!</paragraph></list-item></list><paragraph/><callout type="error">Any violation of the proctored exam rules could result in losing the opportunity for earning the certificate</callout><paragraph/><callout type="info"><bold>After the Exam</bold></callout><list style="bullet"><list-item><paragraph>Once the final exam is completed, it takes about <bold>5 business days</bold> to receive the proctor exam result. After that, you can find the final exam and the total grades on the progress page. If you do not hear back from the exam result after 5 days, you can reach out to the course staff on the discussion forum</paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>Verified track learners will have lifelong access to the course content (except the coding platform). </paragraph></list-item><list-item><paragraph>The certification will be available after <bold>1/4/2021</bold>. To earn a certificate, you must score 60% or above for the total grades and take the final exam</paragraph></list-item></list><paragraph/><paragraph>Good luck with your final!</paragraph><paragraph><break/>Your Course Staff</paragraph></document>

title: Knowledge Base entails statement type questions
text:
Hi -

In questions with "KB entails a statement"  like below

$$KB\models \alpha$$

where alpha is a statement. My understanding is that we need to show that

$$KB \rightarrow \alpha$$

is valid.

Or as the lecture describes we show that 

$$KB \wedge \neg \alpha$$

is unsatisfiable.  Does this mean that we have to show that the above statement is never a tautology?

Now that quiz deadlines are over, could you potentially walk through the following problem?

If KB is defined as follows:

$$KB = \{P \vee Q \vee R, \neg P \vee R, \neg Q \}$$

does 

$$KB\models R?$$
document: Hi -In questions with "KB entails a statement" like belowKB\models \alphawhere alpha is a statement. My understanding is that we need to show thatKB ightarrow \alphais valid.Or as the lecture describes we show that KB \wedge eg \alphais unsatisfiable. Does this mean that we have to show that the above statement is never a tautology?Now that quiz deadlines are over, could you potentially walk through the following problem?If KB is defined as follows:KB = \{P \vee Q \vee R, eg P \vee R, eg Q \}does KB\models R?

answers.text:
This is how I approach it:

Everything in the KB is known to be true.

So write out the truth table with all 3 variables and required expressions {P∨Q∨R,¬P∨R,¬Q}. Then zoom in on the rows where all three expressions are true. Is the expression in question (R here) also true in all those rows? If yes, then KB⊨R. If R is false in even one of them, then the entailment does not happen.
answers.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>This is how I approach it:</paragraph><paragraph>Everything in the KB is known to be true.</paragraph><paragraph>So write out the truth table with all 3 variables and required expressions {P∨Q∨R,¬P∨R,¬Q}. Then zoom in on the rows where all three expressions are true. Is the expression in question (R here) also true in all those rows? If yes, then KB⊨R. If R is false in even one of them, then the entailment does not happen.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>

comments.text: Thank you for your response ! I agree with you that is how i initially understood it. But I cant imagine how it makes sense in this question. The answer to the above question (i.e. KB |= R) is yes according to the quiz. But how can R be true everywhere ¬Q is true?
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Thank you for your response ! I agree with you that is how i initially understood it. But I cant imagine how it makes sense in this question. The answer to the above question (i.e. KB |= R) is yes according to the quiz. But how can R be true everywhere ¬Q is true?</paragraph></document>

comments.text: It's not everywhere ¬Q is true. It's everywhere P∨Q∨R and ¬P∨R and ¬Q are all together true.
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>It's not everywhere ¬Q is true. It's everywhere P∨Q∨R and ¬P∨R and ¬Q are all together true.</paragraph></document>

comments.text: Ah I see ! Thank you so much!
comments.document: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Ah I see ! Thank you so much! </paragraph></document>

title: Q15: does 𝐾𝐵⊨𝑝?
text:
The "answer" to this question is "Yes" in the system, but that seems wrong to me.

Given the following KB: 𝐾𝐵={𝑝∨¬𝑞,𝑞∨¬𝑟,𝑞∨𝑟} Using resolution for propositional logic or truth table, does 𝐾𝐵⊨𝑝?

My reasoning:

{𝑝∨¬𝑞,𝑞∨¬𝑟,𝑞∨𝑟} ⇒ {𝑝∨¬𝑟,𝑞∨𝑟} ⇒ {𝑝∨𝑞}

And 𝑝∨𝑞 isn't sufficient to entail 𝑝.
document:

My reasoning:{𝑝∨¬𝑞,𝑞∨¬𝑟,𝑞∨𝑟} ⇒ {𝑝∨¬𝑟,𝑞∨𝑟} ⇒ {𝑝∨𝑞}And 𝑝∨𝑞 isn't sufficient to entail 𝑝.

title: Are we robots?
text:
After this wonderful course ... can we be sure we are not robots? Tin robots like the Wizard of Oz, no, but biological robots.

I remember those Star Trek episodes where the Enterprise received updates with biological elements for improved processing.

In a way, our minds are programmable, by our parents, society, and other external agents. After brain injuries, internal changes and updates can recover lost functions.

I also remember that New Generation episode where Data is judged, Starfleet wanted to disassembly him to study his unique positronic brain, so he defended himself and demonstrated he is a life form, self-aware of his existence. To me, that looks like Dr. Soong created a new form of life. Then, what if we are the creation of some sort of superior beings?

Pure speculations and fantasy on my side, but who knows? ... Similarly, can we be sure we are not living in a simulation? :)

Life is so mysterious! Yet, here we are trying to maximize our own objective functions.

Anyway, I just wanted to share these crazy thoughts and say thanks to the instructors, staff and other participants, we helped each other to learn a lot!

Happy holidays all! and stay safe!

answers.text:
Hi camilomv17,

It takes time for proctortrack to review your onboarding, and we have communicated for 12 weeks to urge students to complete the onboarding before the exam week. Please contact proctortrack live support immediately and ask them to expedite your profile review. We've seen students reporting a quicker turn-around time after contacting proctortrack support. Please let us know how it goes.

comments.text:
Hi, 

I just investigated your case and it might be that you ended the monitoring before clicking on the "start exam" button. 

Do not end the monitoring (i.e there should be blue border around the screen) before you click on Start exam button.

I just reset your previous attempt. Please try again and let us know if you continue to experience issues. Good luck!

-Course staff

Please try again and let us know if you continue to experience issues. Good luck!</paragraph><paragraph>-Course staff</paragraph></document>

title: Thanks for an excellent course!
text:
I just wanted to thank the course staff and everyone at ColumbiaX who made this course possible! The lectures were excellent - they were easy to follow and made the content very manageable even though the concepts themselves were not trivial. I'm so glad I discovered this course, it has been a pleasurable learning experience.

Like many others, I'm disappointed that the micro-masters program will not be continuing, but if there is any chance it may be revived in the future, I hope this comment and others like it would help to let everyone at Columbia know that this course is appreciated and valued and we are sad to see it go. 

Again, a big thank you to everyone who made this possible!
